description:
Angkor Borei is such a little gem. I wanted to venture away from something other than my typical Asian fare and coming from the midwest, I never had the chance to try Cambodian food and let me tell you, I was shook when I tried their food. 

We ordered the Cambodian pineapple fried rice, the pumpkin curry with chicken, and the ahmok. 

Honestly the star of this dinner was easily the pumpkin curry. The curry was thick and beautiful with a lovely vegetable medley. BUT THE FACT THAT THIS CURRY WAS SERVED IN A HALF PUMPKIN WAS AMAZING. That's all I wanted to eat after the first bite: the pumpkin and some rice. As a heads up, don't think that ordering fried rice can compensate for rice with curry cause you're gonna be masking the flavor of the fried rice. And unfortunately that's what I did. The pineapple fried rice ended up being a vehicle for the delicious curry and I had so many regrets. But from what I remember of eating the fried rice, it was equally delicious for those not too adventurous on this menu. TL;DR hurry to get that pumpkin curry.

The ahmok was also very tasty! Described as a baked fish mousse, it might not seem too appetizing at first but the flavor is grand. The texture is not my favorite, but that would not deter me from eating it again. Make sure you put some of the sauce on each spoonful too! 

Overall, I would come back to this place in a heartbeat. Three dishes that made us disgustingly but blissfully full came out to be like, $23 each. If you get the curry, just ask for a side of rice. 

The ambience and service was also amazing, our hostess was so precious and kind and the napkin presentation was on point.
author: Michael L.

description:
I'd give this place a 3.5 but rounding down. 

Stopped by on a Saturday for lunch. 

Got the lunch special
- chili pork 2/5
- chili squid 3.5/5
- ginger beef 3/5
- boneless chicken curry 4/5

Also the spinach leaf appetizer 5/5

The spinach leaf appetizer was so tasty and fun to eat. Could have done without the other stuff though. Maybe just a little more fish sauce could fix some of the problems. But overall, bland, not spiced enough, not salty enough, the meats wwre too tough. I typically enjoy more punch in my food. Just my preferred flavor profile.
author: J P.

description:
Not sure why I was expecting it to be a lot more popular than it is...called to ask if I needed a reservation and walked into an empty restaurant. We ordered 3 things: the Larb, the Chili Chicken, and lastly the Ahmohk. 

The larb (we ordered pork) was amazing! Vinaigrette-y and meaty with the fresh taste of lettuce to accompany your bite...did not regret this choice at all! 

We asked for the Chili Chicken to be hot (mild vs hot) and it had like one jalapeno. That was so disappointing, there was no hotness at all. Also, the beans were rock-solid and the chicken was not tender. ): 

The fish however, the Ahmohk, was pretty tasty. Too bad for $13 there was just so little of it.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
One of my closest friends who is Cambodian always griped about the struggle of finding good Cambodian restaurants in the Bay. Needless to say Angkor Borei definitely satisfied that need!

For me, seeing as it was my first time having Cambodian food, I naturally asked my friend to recommend some staples he'd always get, so he ordered ahead for me. I was pretty pleased with the food overall.

Cambodian Crepe ($10)- Really crisp, and the filling inside was rich and had plenty of flavor. Pretty decent!

Beef LARB ($10)- Really solid! The beef larb was really packed with flavor from the rest of the spices and I really enjoyed this. I'd pick this up again if I was back.

Ahmok- A classic Cambodian dish, my friend really enjoyed it and said it tasted very reminiscent of the ahmok he'd get back home. A definite recommend from him!

Fried Bananna & Coconut Ice Cream  ($6) - Pairs off with a scoop of Mitchells Ice Cream. While the fried Bananna was good, it also got soggy way too quickly. Paired with the ice cream it was good. Probably wouldn't get this again here though.

Service here was really sweet. The waitress/assumedly one of the co-owners of Ankor Borei was really accommodating and made us feel right at home, so it was a comfortable and enjoyable experience.

I'd give Angkor Borei a 4.5. Food and service were pretty good, and I don't really have any complaints though I personally will always dislike the parking around this area. Definitely worth a shot for some solid Cambodian food!
author: Allison O.

description:
My husband and I have been here a few times as it's a great local spot. They have a ton of different food options that are sort of a blend of south Asian cuisines. You'll recognize the familiar Thai foods like pad Thai and curries. They have their own flair and a homey vibe. 

The lady who owns the place is really nice and their prices are reasonable-- making it easier for us to eat it without breaking the bank.

This time we came in and ordered takeout (because I wanted to discuss the menu items). However if you already know what you want, you can easily order online or call in. We got the following: 

Chili chicken - very good, just the right spice
Spring rolls - excellent!!! 
Chicken curry (#19) with lemongrass - not really a curry more like a soup
Pad Thai with beef - very good

They have great portions! Last time we got Larb beef and pineapple fried rice. The larb felt healthy and salty. Good snack to start the meal. The pineapple fried rice was great. Not too sweet bunot dry either.

Definitely come by here if you're looking for a delicious meal as a neighborhood favorite. It won't disappoint. If you're unsure what to order, definitely ask. She knows what all the favorites are.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
I have to admit I was underwhelmed by a restaurant I had been meaning to try for the last decade. It's just far enough away from me on the 14-Mission for me to heave an audible sigh before rejecting a trip over here. Well, I finally decided to brace myself for the grittiest MUNI ride in the city next to the 19-Polk. Actually the ride wasn't that bad, and I was looking forward to having some Cambodian cuisine, especially from a family-run place that has been serving it for over thirty years. I was their first customer that day, and they were hawking their $8.95 lunch combination plates. The choices seemed a bit on the generic side to me, but...

How can I argue with that bargain price when you get their house special soup and a scoop of jasmine rice with two entree selections? The soup was a watery broth partially spiced with chunks of tofu and cucumber (photo: http://bit.ly/2HPotG5). It lingered in my tongue longer than in my memory. For my entrees, I chose the BBQ Chicken which consisted of two small pieces nicely charred along with a sweet dipping sauce and a tiny salad. The poultry was tender enough to enjoy. Not as much with the Napa Cabbage with Shrimp, which although sautéed was on the wet side (photo: http://bit.ly/2qZfj0d). Yep, I should come back for their Cambodian specials in the evening.

FOOD - 3 stars...totally hamstrung by the restricted choices for the lunch combos..my bad
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a bit on the dark side but a nice space nonetheless
SERVICE - 4 stars...I think that was co-owner Chinhan Yat who served me, very friendly
TOTAL - 3 stars...Cambodian restaurants can serve generic lunches, too
author: Ed U.

description:
Called around lots of places to see if they were open on New Year's day before finally getting this place.  We're not usually in the area and probably wouldn't have eaten here.  We had just finished our pregnancy photoshoot and to witness the Super Moon at Bernal Heights. I'm so glad they were open

We ordered the Pumpkin Curry, Crepe, a bowl of sticky rice, and sticky black rice with mango for dessert. 

My favorite was the pumpkin curry.  The was curry packed with flavor and the vegetables cooked just right, not mushy and overcooked.  It's literally served with half a pumpkin (not sure what kind), a mix of vegetables, chicken and curry sauce that's lick your bowl clean kind of sauce.  Our server told us that we could actually eat the pumpkin and it's not just a serving bowl to which I assume people don't actually eat?  Paired with a side of sticky rice is a perfect meal. 

The crepe was okay.  It's like Vietnamese banh xeo, served with lettuce, cucumbers, and sauce.  The sauce is not quite the same as the Vietnamese version which I prefer so it was just okay to me. 

We were told that we just got the last sticky black rice with mango and I'm so glad because it was a nice way to end our meal.  Something refreshing and not overly sweet to tie it all in.  

Service is attentive and super friendly.  It felt like eating at home.  Not that we eat with cloth napkins at home but that it was a comfortable setting, small, intimate, and unassumingly nice.

Will definitely come back if we're in the area.
author: Naty D.

description:
In general, I love Southeast Asian food. Absolutely, delicious and perhaps I'm not searching hard enough, but I don't come across that many Cambodian restaurants. 

Stopped here one evening around 7-ish and restaurant was half full. However, within 20 minutes, it was a full house. 

We ordered the Chili Beef (medium spicy), Pineapple Fried Rice and the Spinach Leaves appetizer. 

It took a while to get our main dishes as the kitchen staff lost our order. However, the dining room staff was so sweet that it was easily forgivable and they brought out the food super quickly. 

My favorite was the pineapple fried rice. It was served piping hot so it stayed warm for a while, which was great.

The spinach leaves appetizer was good. It was a unique finger food dish. They give you all these different ingredients to add on your spinach leaf. Kind of like a mini spinach taco. 

For the chili beef, it was a stir fry just served with chilies. It wasn't that spicy. It was just alright.

Would come back for the pineapple fried rice and perhaps a desert next time.
author: Julie L.

description: Exceptional dinning in down town SF. Amazing menu in old school atmosphere. Friend staff and very attentive.
author: John K.

description: Delicious, quite and very enjoyable atmosphere. The food was 10/10 and the service as well. A wonderful restaurant to catch up with a friend as it's not crowded.
author: Gia M.

description:
A quaint but charming Cambodian restaurant. A nice change of flavors to the main stream Asian restaurants that saturate California. 

We found this place on yelp and thought we'd give it a try while visiting SF. As we walked in we were immediately greeted by the owner. She was very friendly and welcoming. Since we've never been there we asked her to recommend us a couple of dishes. She right away suggested Amok and Pumpkin Curry. We also ordered the beef laap to balance out the sweetness of the other dishes. 

The Amok was delicious! It had a smooth coconut and curry flavors. The fish just melts in your mouth. It was creamy and rich. The pumpkin curry was also a hit! We chose chicken as the protein. The fresh vegetables were cooked just right where it still had a bit of a crunch to it. It's sweet and savory. The beef laap balanced out everything very well. It had just the right amount of saltiness and tartness with a bit of a kick to it just as we preferred. We had a side of jasmine rice which complimented the dishes beautifully. 

Good quality food and presentation. Decent portions. It's a hole in the wall so it can be easily missed as you're driving by. Parking is scarce. Overall, the food and service were amazing. Definitely will be coming back to try other dishes!
author: Jessalyn P.

description:
One afternoon while at work I was reminiscing about the Ithaca Farmers Market I used to go to while in college, and started day dreaming about this Cambodian stall that would sell this phenomenal Cambodian crepe. Ohhh that beautiful savory crepe. And then I thought, there's gotta be a place in SF, my new home, where I can again venture into this heavenly cuisine. And there is! It's called Angkor Borei and you have to go! 

This place is FANTASTIC! It's a little off the beaten path towards Bernal Heights and outside of the mission, but you seriously cannot go wrong. If I had a Cambodian grandmother and she served me warm food in her humble abode, it would feel like my experience at Angkor Borei - cozy and delightful. 

I skimmed the menu for a bit, my eyes just eagerly searching for that crepe, and there it was! So naturally, we had to order it as an appetizer. For our main, we ordered the Ahmohk fish, a recommendation from our amicable and down to earth server :). 

When the crepe arrived, my first thought was wow this is big for an appetizer! The crepe is pretty thin, but quite crispy and filled with generous amounts of ground pork, shrimp, shredded coconuts and sprouts. I dipped a piece into the garlic-lemon sauce and placed it on my mouth. My eyes immediately closed in happiness - holy moly an explosion of flavors and textures! This is one heck of a good appetizer and an authentically Cambodian dish that definitely reminded me of what I would get in Ithaca.

Next, the Ahmohk came....UN.REAL. The fish was so perfectly cooked, almost buttery, with this amazing curry leaf flavor. We had asked for it spicy and they delivered,but it was so good! It too came with a similar citrusy sauce as the crepe, which really went brilliantly with the fish. 

We were super satisfied with the meal. Angkor delivered great and fair priced Cambodian food in a humble and unassuming space, with lovely service. I would definitely recommend the crepe and Ahmohk! If you're not feeling that, then ask the server what else is good here (she did mention the pumpkin curry!). But, I would definitely stick to the more Cambodian dishes because why would you come to such a great establishment and order pad Thai eh? :)
author: Sabina S.

description:
Wow!  This place is amazing!  I only wish I had discovered it sooner.  Excellent food, great service, and a cozy, intimate atmosphere.

My husband and I shared the following (and ended up with enough leftovers for another meal):

1) Spinach leaves appetizer - unique and delicious!
2) Spring rolls - good, but probably the weakest link
3) Pumpkin curry with chicken - excellent 
4) Chili prawns - tasty

The service was great - friendly, prompt, and attentive.  

The setting is cozy, warm, and inviting, and the traditional music is nice.

I am so glad to have come here, and look forward to returning!
author: Barnali D.

description:
Really great place! It's unfortunate that SF doesn't have many Cambodian restaurants (there's like 2 or 3 tops) but Angkor Borei makes up for it. We just had the pumpkin curry and BBQ grilled pork and they were both so good!! My gf and I ended up leaving both plates spotless, curry was great cause it was so flavorful but still really light, BBQ pork was great with their fish sauce. 

Best part was the service though, the waitress who I think is also the owner was so sweet and kind, we wanted her to adopt us into her family. 

Highly recommend
author: Nick C.

description:
Very inexpensive food for a cute little date night, or if you're just looking to grab an ethic cuisine.

Nested in Bernal Heights, you'd be a daredevil to try and find parking here. Fortunately, I took the J Line. On other occasions, I'd have to circle the area 2-3 times until I found a parking spot. You've been warned.

As for the restaurant, it's in a cute little building that totally reminds me of a Cambodian restaurant. Dark, clean, but at the same time - a little old-fashioned and a little behind the times.

The auntie taking our orders was super sweet as we exchanged a few Khmer words back and fourth re: recommendations. We eventually settled on:

Cambodian Crepe - 5/5 Totally get this! You can either order this for yourself, or share it with your date.

Ahmok - 5/5 Super tender and the included spicy fish sauce was so good - like seriously so good. I even drenched my Crepe and Pad Thai with the dipping sauce.

Pad Thai with Shrimp 3.5/5 Not the best, but not the worst. Sort of on the sweet side, which was too sugary for my liking.

Overall, I'd come back here again. We paid about $45 bucks with tip and tax. I noticed they also maintain a steady stream of repeat and local clients, which is always good to see.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
I'm told a difference between Thai and Cambodian food is one ferments the shrimp sauce and one doesn't. I'm not sure which is which but the sauce in the papaya salad at Angkor Borei is top notch with just a pinch of something special. Same for the larb which is pretty shrimpy and also has mint. Yum. 

We had the tofu with Napa cabbage because the table next to us ordered it and it looked so good I asked what it was. (Yeah I'm not usually "that guy" but tonight I was). Someone told me that tofu is de-masculinizing. Whatever. It was tofu-licious and I think I'm still male. 

We also had the duck prik king. I'm not a huge fan of duck but my friend is and she was raving about how it was all the best parts of the duck. She's Vietnamese so she knows. The veggies were a bit soft in this one. 

We also had pork with ginger sauce. It was really gingery (a bit of bite and you tasted the ginger) and it had lots  of nice veggies with it. 

We closed it out with mango and sticky rice (black rice so -- score!) and fried banana with Mitchell's coconut ice cream. Delish.
author: Tim P.

description:
My friend recommended this place to me. It's nice to to have Asian food, but not the typical Chinese, Japanese, Thai or Vietnamese that SF seems to thrive on. It was refreshing to have Cambodian food, not your typical Asian cuisine. Coming to the outer Mission was quite a trek, and the parking was terrible (had to circle at least 3x), but this food was really great quality and worth the trip!

Highlight dishes:
-Pumpkin curry. Man oh man! They give you a lot of pumpkin, and I just really loved the curry sauce. It's definitely NOT the same as what you'd get at a Thai restaurant or Chinese place. This curry was on the slightly thicker side, but not OVERLY thick. Just the right amount. Remember to get rice.

-Crispy Tofu appetizer - wow! It was crispy, and also had this really good slightly sour sauce, with basil. So delicious. Never had anything like it. 

-Curry fried rice - it was your typical Southeast Asian type of fried rice, that came with pineapple. It was decent, but I felt like I could get this at other restaurants. 

I didn't realize that Cambodian food doesn't have a focus on noodles. There was only one noodle dish (pad thai), that I think was just there to satisfy picky eaters lol. Also, there were a lot of dishes that I can't wait to try for next time, like the soups, prawns, and meat dishes. 

The lady working here said she's been in the business for 30 years. She took it over from her mother, and now she has a daughter working in the back too. Pretty legit! I'd definitely recommend this place. Just don't lose your temper over the awful parking. Maybe get to go also.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Really really enjoyed this place!

We thoroughly enjoyed the 'FRESH SPINACH LEAVES' Appetizer, which was a bit of an activity and an appetizer in one. For the mains, we had the Shrimp & Chicken Curry and Chili Chicken, both of which we really enjoyed. They were light and flavorful. 

Service was very good -- they were super attentive with water and checking on us. 

Definitely going back!
author: Stephanie M.

description: My 1st time trying Cambodian food and it was one of the best food I have ever tried in my life, everything was on point , it's a family owned resturant for over 30 years the lady and her husband they run the business,I will be back for sure and I will tell everyone about it, I own a deli in south San Francisco called BIG BELLY DELI and I use nothing but the best produce, meats and cheeses I can tell what's fresh and top notch products, now go try this place and see what I'm talking about,
author: Tycoon N.

description: Amazing Cambodian food. I recently discovered this place when I moved back to this neighborhood and was blown away. My favorites have been the Spinach Leaves appetizer, the pumpkin curry, the fried tilapia and the bbq chicken. There's still other items on the menu that I'd like to try out, but so far everything has been delicious. The service is amazing, and I've always had the same lady who works at the front of the house be my server and she's the sweetest person in the whole world. I highly recommend Angkor Borei, if you're fixin' to try Cambodian food. It's the spot.
author: Michelle R.

description:
We came here for a quick dinner and ordered the pumpkin curry and pineapple fried rice. Both were wonderful! The fried rice had a rich curry seasoning, so I personally enjoyed eating it alone. The curry would be perfect with white rice. Just a quick tip, although it's more a personal preference.

The service was quick and the staff were friendly. I look forward to coming back and trying the rest of the menu.
author: Lupita D.

description: Real traditional khmer food, probably can't find anything as good unless you drive to Longbeach. The staff is super nice and gives off motherly vibes, definitely home-made recipes in the sense if you ask them if they can make the food a certain way or off menu they absolutely can. The papaya salad was real fresh but not dark with the shrimp paste, order the beef larb you can taste the dried rice, and finally you can't go wrong with the spicy sour curry (eggplant included).
author: Ricardo H.

description:
If you never had Cambodian food before and you enjoy southeast Asian cuisine, I suggest you try this restaurant. Cambodian cuisine flies under the radar as its not mainstream like Thai or Vietnamese food. This is a family owned restaurant and my experience here was wonderful. I would definitely return. 

Service: 5/5 

Food: 4.5/5 

Price: 5/5
author: R B.

description: This is authentic Cambodian food in a family owned restaurant. I was with a party of 4 so we selected a few dishes suggested by a friend that is Cambodian. We were here for lunch so they have a lunch menu with several options at a great price. There is metered parking outside and if you drive around in the side streets.
author: Shristi R.

description: Great food, even greater service! We were in the mood for spicy food and this really hit the spot! Everything was just spicy enough but still so flavorful. We got the spicy hot and sour soup- very comforting. Super flavorful, lots of good veges and just enough spice! The duck prik king was also very good- we got it pretty spicy as well. The meat was skimp, but it was so tasty! Also, a lot of bones, but what can you do. We also ordered the special whole trout. Fried, with really good sour and spicy sauce. We ate the whole thing. My fresh young coconut was also so cold and delicious with soft meat, it really made my meal. The owner/hostess was so nice and really knew what we wanted to eat. Will definitely return to try more dishes!
author: Vivian D.

description: This place is an absolute gem in the mission. I'd never eaten Cambodian cuisine before and absolutely loved it. The pumpkin curry was a winner for sure - to my unrefined palate it tasted a bit like red Thai curry (but more delicious). The owner was also around and made the experience even more enjoyable with their quick and warm service. They only serve wine and beer (and also fresh coconuts!).
author: Sam M.

description: Yummy food. Tastes like original from South east Asia and has unique dishes which can't try somewhere around Bay Area.
author: Pat P.

description:
Authentic Khmer food! This is exactly what my boyfriend was looking for our entire trip to the Bay. The Cambodian population in the Bay area is quite large - mostly in the Stockton/ Oakland area, but we stayed mostly between SF/ Berkeley.

On the last night of our trip, my boyfriend made it a point that he wanted nothing but Khmer food. It just so happened that I had been saving this place as our last stop - being the cute and thoughtful girlfriend that I am...

All jokes aside, this is the best place for Khmer food on the SF side of the Oakland bridge. We started off with Thai tea after, which was the perfect ratio and quenched our thirst after a short walk down from Billy Goat Hill. We also ordered plea (raw beef salad) that my boyfriend compared to his mom's!! I think it was actually listed as larb, which most people are more familiar with because of its presence in many Thai restaurants. He also got an order of the tom-yum soup that had a nice kick to it, and I got the fried ribs with rice (okay, I know I was having a basic moment)...

While there are many items you would find at a Thai restaurant, there's also an extensive amount of vegetarian options, authentic Cambodian food, and a sweet Khmer lady ready to converse, so what are you waiting for?
author: Niki P.

description:
Super yummy food with sweet and helpful staff. The ambiance is simple and nice. 

We ordered the pad Thai, which was just a little sweet, which I like; sweet and spicy fish, which was fried and delicious and not too spicy; and asparagus in yellow curry. 

I'd order the fish again and try some other dishes next time. Will be back for sure!
author: Noah M.

description:
Not bad, not exceptionally great.  I like that the space is set up like I just walked into Cambodia, and the environment is friendly. It seems like a small family place, and the owner knew a lot of people by name. I'm not sure I'd come often enough to do that, but its pretty cool.

I had the amok and the Cambodian Pineapple Fried Rice. Both...were a bit salty. Like really salty. I should have ordered some plain rice to go with it.

The service was good, albeit a little slow. I was also grateful we ordered the spinach leaves as an appetizer, but it did very little to assuage my hunger as I was literally re-constructing a de-constructed salad. A very good one though. 

I think they make everything fresh, because otherwise I can't justify the wait. We ordered our meal and finished eating before the person who walked in for a to-go order even got their meal. Like literally he ordered 10 minutes after us. And we did NOT inhale our food in 10 min. Or...did we? Hurm.
author: Lily W.

description: Angkor Borei is such a great restaurant if you are craving Southeast Asian food! I would highly recommend the Pumpkin Curry and Fried Pork Rib. The Hoam Lahong is also a refreshing appetizer salad to start off with. The Ahmohk was a bit salty so you should definitely order a side of rice. Service was amazing and super friendly and you can also make reservations!
author: Grace L.

description:
My friend suggested this place. We were seated right away, she was very welcoming and friendly. 

The place is a little bit dark but cozy. But it was also hard to find parking. 

We ordered: Ahmok, sauteed asparagus with garlic, beef skewer and charbroiled pork slices. Everything is delicious except the beef skewer which is just okay. And I just have nothing else to say except Ahmok is to die for!! We ordered it extra spicy!! It took a while to get our food tho so maybe not a best place to go if you are in a hurry. Then again, it was my first visit so I will only know the next time I came back. Yup, definitely coming back and recommend it to people I know!
author: Vonny W.

description:
I love this restaurant!  It's my first time having Cambodian food & I loved every dish we ordered!  The best I can describe their style of cooking is very similar to Thai cooking but BETTER!  Since it's my first time here, so far here are my faves:
1) Vegetarian Crispy Spring Rolls
2) Pad Thai with Shrimp
3) Green Curry with Tofu

I'm only sorry that I've only just recently discovered them even though they have been in business for over thirty years (according to the very nice owner)!

Their green curry with tofu was so delicious I started craving it on my way home from dinner!  I can't wait to go back and try other items on their menu!
author: Ann E.

description: Family owe Cambodian restaurant in the mission district. Went there for dinner on a Friday night. We got seated right away by the owner/ waitress. She was very friendly. We ordered a few dishes to try. The soup we ordered was a bit salty but other than that, most dishes we tried was great. The chicken pumpkin curry was tasty and spicy. The fish was soft and paired with their sauce, it was perfect. The mango sticky rice was fresh and sweetness was perfect for me. Customer services was great. Atmosphere felt like you are dining at home. Very cozy and comfortable. I will definitely come back again.
author: Sandy A.

description: Nothing special. We ordered pumpkin curry with chicken and the shrimp clay pot. Both were underwhelming.
author: Ankit A.

description:
Very mediocre food. Prepared quickly for pickup. Tried several items:

1. Eggplant chicken - lightly sauced, not very flavorful 
2. Sliced beef - very good, nice lean meat, tasty sauce topped on morning glory
3. Mixed seafood - hyped on menu as tons of seafood but arrives in a regular paper take out box; sauce and seafood were ok
4. Pad Thai - very dry, boring
5. Asparagus curry shrimp - got stir fried asparagus (incorrectly)
author: Lance T.

description: Mmmmm, one of the worst fried rice! I can make better at home and I have non cooking experience. The only thing that I like is fried tofu basil, but Thai Stick (now closed) on Fillmore has done it 15 yrs ago when they were a hit. It's so sad that SF foodie scene has changed a lot as well. The fish banana leaves curry was so so. I had a great one in Le Marais, Paris, as there are many Cambodian immigrants existed. I wouldn't order anymore from this place.
author: Clemencia S.

description:
Ahmonk, Ahmonk, Ahmonk... get this dish. Curry steamed in a banana leaf, okay!!! Mousse texture that goes great with rice. We got the fish one and loved it. 

We also got the charboiled pork slices and crispy Cambodian crepe. Both were tasty, though I enjoyed that fish mousse more. Next time I'll get the spinach leaves appetizer. Glad to have a Cambodian food option here in SF! 

Affordable dishes that are less than $10 each. Friendly service. Wasn't busy on a weekday evening. Sliced cucumbers and tomatoes served as garnish for most dishes. Put dem cucumbers in yo eyes... or not.
author: Joanna L.

description: Excellent vegetarian choices.  Good curries.  Nice service.  Papaya salad average and small - skip this.  Hot is hot, without too many chilis, which lets the food come through.
author: Maria C.

description: The food was really good, it was something new for us to try Cambodian food. The service was great and I'd come again!
author: Helen C.

description:
*** In Short ***

Tasty, flavorful, and low-key Cambodian.

*** In Depth ***

While I can't speak for the authenticity here, I will say that their menu, in addition to the typical dishes you'd see in that region (aka curries and pad thai), had a lot of things I'd never even heard of before, so, take that as you will. But, because of that, I ended up asking what looked to be the owner for some recommendations, to which she suggested their prahok: a stewed ground pork with a pinch of anchovy, served up with a bunch of raw veggies.

Now, admittedly, when I read the description of "served with vegetable dip," I assumed the dip was an aside. But nah, rather, the stewed pork itself was the dip, as it came on this large platter surrounded by the aforementioned vegetables. Not at all what I was expecting, but definitely an interesting, and somewhat enjoyable experience. I say somewhat because I still find it weird to eat any sort of Asian cuisine that has meat without any carbs, and in this case, the protein was on the saltier side and would have benefited from it. Likewise, my friend's pla dook pad ped (fried catfish) was not bad, but also on the saltier end of things.

3 stars, all done and said.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The restaurant looks a bit cramped upon entering, but despite appearances, is actually pretty spacious once you're inside.

Bathroom - Didn't use them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
TLDR - Good, flavorful Cambodian food! Try the charbroiled pork slices and the ahmohk!

Ever since visiting Thailand and Cambodia a few months ago, I've had cravings on and off for Thai and Cambodian food. You don't see a lot of restaurants labelled as Cambodian in SF (or in the states in general, I'm guessing), so I was pretty excited when I found Angkor Borei. I'm ashamed to say I don't really know the difference between Thai and Cambodian food (they seemed pretty similar where I went in the two countries), but Angkor Borei did a solid job satisfying my cravings.

The restaurant is your typical Asian restaurant - no frills, probably family-owned/run - and easily overlooked from the outside unless you're specifically looking for it. My group of 5 came around 6pm on a Saturday and the restaurant was surprisingly quiet and empty. A lady, who I assume to be the owner, told us that most of her customers dine a lot later, and true to her word, the restaurant got a lot busier around 7:30-8pm. Also to my surprise, parking was very difficult to find, despite it being in the outskirts of SF.

The menu is pretty extensive here, like at most Asian restaurants, but I had some pretty specific cravings: papaya salad, tom yum soup, fish amok and pumpkin curry. We also ordered the charbroiled pork per Yelp's suggestion, the claypot shrimp for some more seafood, asparagus for some veggies and mango sticky rice for dessert. 

Most of the dishes were pretty good and flavorful, but I'd definitely have to recommend the AHMOHK and CHARBROILED PORK SLICES. Both had great texture and flavor. I also loved that the food in general here wasn't greasy! Most Thai restaurants in the States use a ridiculous amount of oil in their cooking, which was not actually the case in Thailand. Portions are a little on the smaller side given the price and in comparison to similar restaurants, but still very reasonable.

The thai iced tea ($4.45) is pretty sweet here, but I loved the coconut ($4.45) - refreshing and they give you a spoon to scoop out all the coconut meat!

#5 NHOAM LAHONG / PAPAYA SALAD ($7.95) - 4/5
Pretty solid. Ingredients are fresh but it's lacking some of the complexity in flavor that papaya salads are supposed to have. It's a little salty and a tad sweet, but it's missing the spiciness and acidity. Still liked it though!

#13 SPICY HOT & SOUR SOUP ($11.95) - 4/5
Basically like Thai tom yum soup. Light but flavorful soup. Sour and a little bit spicy, but definitely could've used more spiciness.

#30 CHARBROILED PORK SLICES ($9.75) - 5/5
MMM. If you love meat, I definitely recommend this! The pork was super tender (with very little fat) and absolutely delicious. Not greasy either! Tasted amazing on its own or with the sweet and sour/acidic sauce it was served with. 

#48 AHMOHK ($12.95) - 5/5
On 7x7's list of things to eat in SF. I had fish amok for the first time in Thailand and Cambodia a few months ago and I've been craving it ever since. It's not something I normally see at Thai restaurants in the states (or maybe I just never looked for it on the menu before), so I was really excited to see it on the menu here. It's not quite as good as authentic amok, but it definitely didn't disappoint! The amok was rich and flavorful with a perfectly light, creamy mousse texture. The fish was soft and moist, and there was shrimp and scallops in the amok too. Only weird thing was the random piece of broccoli at the bottom. Paired with a salty fish sauce, but I wouldn't add that to the amok. 

#53 CLAYPOT SHRIMP ($12.95) - 3/5
Nothing bad about it but nothing particularly interesting at all. Just some steamed shrimp and steamed veggies, served with some sort of sour sauce, but otherwise rather plain and flavorless without the sauce. Great healthy option though. 

#65 ASPARAGUS SAUTEED WITH SPICES & COCONUT MILK ($9.95) - 3/5
Served with your choice of meat (chicken, beef, pork or squid) but my group chose to leave out the meat. Pretty much tasted like the pumpkin curry. Nothing special and not sure if asparagus is really authentic to Cambodia (I definitely didn't see anything asparagus while I was there)

PUMPKIN CURRY ($14.95) - 3.5/5
Solid but didn't stand out that much. The curry was light rather than creamy/heavy and pretty flavorful, and the pumpkin had a nice soft texture. We got ours with chicken, which was just okay. 

MANGO STICKY RICE ($4.95) - 3.5/5
Not bad but not authentic.. Rather than actual sticky rice, they used purple rice, which isn't sticky and has a firmer texture than sticky rice. The mango was fresh and very ripe and sweet though, and the cream was sweet and salty.
author: Jessie L.

description: Not sure if the quality of their food goes down when it's for delivery, because my shrimp pad thai was super bland. The shrimp was under seasoned and so were the noodles and especially the tofu, which wasn't even cooked...
author: Kim P.

description:
Situated in the outskirts of the Mission, Angkor Borei isn't the hot spot you'd wander into with happy-hour drunchies; it's tucked away in a peaceful little niche. Inside, the traditional decor is serene, unlike some flashy Thai restaurants with gold-embellished everything. 

Yelp recommends the spinach leaves appetizer, amok, and pumpkin curry. I've had Cambodian food before with a Cambodian friend, so I guess can claim that I have some knowledge of this unique cuisine. In my opinion, the spinach leaves appetizer is a victim of the Yelp syndrome--it seems more for show because all the little clear containers for the sauces and toppings look really neat, but I can't imagine an exceptional appetizer emerging from raw spinach leaves and a small platter of miscellany. The amok and pumpkin curry tho.....!!

(++) We started off with the CHARBOILED CHICKEN SKEWERS, a traditional Cambodian festive food. It was a bit charred but juicy and tender, made even better with the interesting sauce (interesting in a good sense).

(+++) The PUMPKIN CURRY sounds plain, but there is something about Angkor Borei's rendition that's addicting. I believe they use kabocha squash, and it's cooked to soft perfection soaked up with the rich curry. Orange on orange, with complimentary flavors and textures. (Pretty presentation too: an artistic contrast of roundly cut pumpkin in a square plate. Among the more artsy curries you'll ever see.) 

(++) I loved the AMOK with its characteristic fluffy texture, but this one seemed to have more spices and was only partially wrapped in the leaf when it's usually cooked entirely wrapped. This left a delicious slightly crispy exterior... the muffin tops of amok. Be warned though, my friends weren't too fond of this so fish mousse (understandably strange-sounding) may not be for everyone. Not complaining, more to myself! 

It's a little pricey at a little under $20 per person (albeit for lots of food), though reasonable for the specialties, especially since I believe this is the only Cambodian place in SF. After all, how many people can pull off fish mousse wrapped in banana leaf?
author: Edna C.

description:
So-so/okay food with ridiculously tiny portions. Seems like they are slacking off on preparation and trying to push profit margins by giving 1/4th a plate rather than a full plate. I am not even into large portions-- but some of the dishes cannot even be split, which is the whole point of ordering family style.

Also, they charge $5 for a tiny cup of rice and try to push as many orders of it as they can.

Food quality was mediocre. Nothing special/memorable. Looked pretty empty on a Friday night and my guess is that their stinginess is the cause.
author: David H.

description: I love this place, particularly the pumpkin curry, hot and sour soup and crispy Cambodian crepe. Well, that's a nice place to start reminiscing.
author: Kashton H.

description:
Cambodian food is a bit like the other Southeast Asian cuisines in that they're really flavorful with lots of traditional ingredients like lemongrass, basil, fish sauce, etc. This place won't be the best Cambodian food you'll ever have but it's pretty good.

We went with the Yelp reviews and ordered the fish ahmok and pumpkin curry. The fish is super flavorful and had a tangy sauce on top. The pumpkin tastes like sweet potato. If you don't like your entrees tasting mildly sweet, then this might not be the dish for you. 

Tried the spinach leaves as an appetizer. It's interesting and different, but also yummy.
author: Josephine C.

description: I craved for Amok so I made my bf drive to Bernal Height, find parking for 30 minutes to get dinnee there. I like the Amok (Ahmok?). Close enough to the one I had in Cambodia but a tad salty. My bf got chili prawn which turned out to be decent. I came herw for their mango sticky rice too but a little disappointed with the very small portion :( Overall the meal is good but going through the hassle of driving and parking isn't worth it.
author: Vy T.

description:
Ventured here on a recommendation, and was pleasantly surprised to find it lively on a Friday night; admittedly, I get into a routine and forget that other neighborhoods, like Bernal, exist!

Pumpkin curry:  Pleasantly surprised at how good this was.  Comes served in the squash itself, great flavor.

Spinach leaves:  Overrated.  Although a visually appealing eating experience with the leaves and all the little bowls of fillings, the leaves don't stay together and overall was not very satisfying.

Pad thai:  Basic good pad thai.

Clay pot shrimp with lemongrass:  Broth had a very nice flavor.  Prawns are not peeled, so this requires a bit of work to eat.
author: Sona P.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect, but I was blown away by the food. The atmosphere was also quaint and the service was on point.
If you go, parking can be a challenge and the neighborhood can be a little edgy.
author: Ima S.

description: Friends brought me here while I was visiting the city-I loved all the Vegan options (while my Omni friends still had lots of options!).  Great food, great service.  I'd never had Cambodian food before-very similar to Thai, which I love!
author: Sandie F.

description: This is a friendly little family-run place at the bottom of Bernal Heights. Although certain dishes on the menu have Thai leanings, there are numerous opportunities to sample authentic Cambodian cuisine. Don't miss the pumpkin curries, the crepe appetizer or the delectable shrimp dishes. The proprietress warmly recommended items that would give us a range of flavors. We can't wait to go back and try even more. This is not a spacious place, and I imagine it can get crowded on weekends. We lucked out on parking, but you should probably think about leaving the driving to someone else.
author: Keith R.

description: The one and only Cambodian restaurant in SF! It's atmosphere and customer service is warm, friendly and the food tastes amazing! My Cambodian friends and I love eating here so we visit often so we can try more options on the menu. No doubt a winner!
author: Julie N.

description:
I feel bad for giving them only 2 stars because their staff were really friendly and attentive. However, their food just didn't do it for me.  

Just like the other yelpers said, this place definitely reminds me of a Thai restaurant. The owner and servers didn't look Khmer to me. None of the dishes we had tasted Cambodian to me. I'm guessing this restaurant has 4 stars because it seemed like a lot of the locals come here.

At first, we ordered the duck in curried paste but quickly changed the order to beef with peanut sauce instead because we saw a negative yelp review. 

Here's my review on the food we ordered:

Crispy spring rolls: the sauce was good, but the spring rolls tasted more like chinese spring rolls from panda express

Slice of beef: probably the worst dish of the night. It tasted like peanut butter and fish sauce with sugar. Nothing special about it.

Charbroiled pork: best dish we had. My bf said it tasted like vietnamese bbq pork and I agree.

Despite their excellent service, I will not return. I think I would rather enjoy some authentic thai food at King of Thai for 1/3 of the price.
author: Carmen A.

description:
Like other reviews note, this too was my introduction to Cambodian cuisine. Overall, I found that it shares similar flavor profiles with other Southeast Asian cultures which I love so the food at Angkor Borei was no exception. I had the: 

-- Crispy Cambodian Crepe: The crepe itself had a savory flavor. It was stuffed with lots of bean sprouts, maybe too much, and ground pork with those tiny shrimps. The lemon garlic sauce it was served with was very tasty. 

-- Duck Prik King: This dish was perfect. The duck was tasty, the green beans were cooked perfectly, and my favorite part was the addition of fresh basil. I wanted more of the sauce to pour on my rice!

-- Ahmohk: It wasn't actually a mousse as described but more like steamed seafood casserole if that makes any sense. It was very flavorful with chunks of fish and shrimp that were not overcooked.

Service was very friendly but a bit slow. The restaurant is very clean and there are about four tables in the front area of the restaurant, with plenty more tables in the back section. My friend and I came on a weeknight, early in the week, and there was no wait.
author: Maya S.

description: Ended up here with two friends 20 minutes before closing and they kindly took us in. We ordered shared dishes to get a taste of the menu and every single one was a unique assortment of flavors. Absolutely phenomenal food and service. Will definitely return.
author: Natalia M.

description:
All the reviews are true! This place is wonderful. 

Of course we came in 30 min before close and ended up being the only ones left in there. They were really nice about it though and closed the restaurant in the mean time. I've never had Cambodian food before. I really liked the food here. The cooks were Cambodian, so I'm sure the food is authentic. I really liked the decor, the outfits they wore, lighting and the music. Wonderful experience. 

On to the food!!! 

As you know, I'm not fond of curry. And I found out later that it's pretty much a signature dish. 

Fried rice:
Very yummy. Had curry but the cucumber and tomato provided helped cleanse the palette so it didn't taste the same throughout. 

Mussels: 
Also had curry. Had a nice kick. Mussels weren't tough. 

Fried pork ribs:
The best dish. I loved the sauce. It wasn't what I expected. 

I really liked this place. I wish I had more room to try the mango and sticky rice. Next time!
author: Lynn C.

description:
My friends and I wanted to try something new for dinner and I suggested something I always wanted to try but never had the chance - Cambodian. This one had the highest rating on yelp and also closest to work so decided to give it a try. 

We were pretty lost when we sat down since no one ever had Cambodian cuisine but the staff were all very nice in giving us their popular suggestions. We agreed on all of them and ordered the following: pumpkin curry, crispy Cambodian crepe, sauteed beef and ahmonk along with 4 Thai iced teas.

Cambodian crepe (7.95)- similar in appearance to Vietnamese cuisines's Banh Xeo. I actually liked this one more than Vietnamese style because there was a hint of coconut flavor with fine minced pork. The skin is super crispy and contrasts well with the soft filling!

Pumpkin curry (14.95) - Once again flavor wasn't super strong but definitely still had the curry flavor similar to creamy coconut flavors of Thai Curry. Mild but tasty over rice. 

Sauteed beef (9.95) - I think this would be my least favorite dish out of the four. I think I'm just not a fan of lemon grass though. 

Ahmohk (10.95) - I never had a fish curry mousse before! This came out looking like a cupcake. I loved the soft texture! The flavor wasn't too strong either, as said in the description its very mild.

If you are a fan of Thai cuisine I would recommend trying Cambodian too! There are a lot of similar flavors. Honestly I have never been to Cambodia so I wouldn't be able to comment on authenticity but it all tasted good at least :). I would definitely recommend trying Ahmohk if you want something different! The Cambodian crepe is also a good one to try. The curry was good but I would say it's not too different from Thai curry so not a must try. Sauteed beef is also not too special so also a possible skip.

Also for pokemon go lovers: restaurant is literally located between 3 poke stops
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Fantastic food. I like trying out Cambodian food in different cities I travel to. I must say this is one of the better Cambodian food I have had the pleasure of coming across.  I highly recommend the beef skewers and pineapple fried rice.

I did not disclose that I was Cambodian to see if they were talking shit about the customers. I can safely say they did not.

I will return!
author: Sokha S.

description: I really enjoyed my meal here. Great food and a nice ambiance. The owner talked to us and was very pleasant. I had the fish mousse and it was so tasty!!!
author: Maxwell L.

description: Clay pot shrimp w/ bean thread noodle is supreme! Not mentioned in a lot of other reviews but I've gotten it twice now and both times did not disappoint. I could easily drink a gallon of the broth on a daily basis, it is THAT good. Noodles also had perfect consistency. Very satisfied!
author: Josh O.

description:
Very nice service here.

Pumpkin Curry, 5/5. We liked this alot. Rather than the usual pumpkin chunks, the pumpkin bowl presentation is very nice. 

Ahmohk, 3/5 for us. It is very very tender, but it's very salty with pungent in your face fish sauce aroma. 

Prahok, 4/5. Great flavors in this seemingly  simple ground pork curry with raw veggies to dip. Note to self, raw eggplant is not my favorite... 

Will be back for sure.
author: John H.

description: Stayed with a friend nearby and decided to come here for dinner. Ordered the yellow curry with shrimp and pineapple, the amok (baked fish mousse in banana leaf) and the sticky black rice with mango. All were excellent. The curry was flavorful and the shrimp was plentiful and fresh. The amok was a unique texture and flavor. The sticky black rice with mango was the perfect ending to our meal. It was the right amount of sweetness and satisfied my sweet tooth without being too much. I almost ordered a second serving because it was so good! Definitely would like to come back before I leave SF again! The prices were a bit on the high side but the quality was worth it.
author: Julesy T.

description: It was good, no complaints.  Servers were friendly and attentive.  Food was good to above average.  Maybe I was looking for more flavor but overall a pleasurable experience.
author: Carlo W.

description:
HOMEY FEEL. FAMILY RESTAURANT.

I don't know how many times I've passed by this place without going in and now I wished I've went in a lot sooner. Cambodian food never really crosses my mind. In fact I don't even consider it an option when choosing what to eat. It was already late and we wanted to eat something Asian in the area. This was the closest option for me and my siblings so we decided to eat here. 

It was REALLLY packed. I didn't expect it to be packed. Most of the people inside where non-Asians so I was a little wary. Prices on the menu are only a tad higher than your typical run of the mill asian restaurant found in the Sunset or Richmond. 

We ordered a couple dishes to share. Nothing special about their fried rice or their duck. What stood out to me was their crepe and their pork stew. OMG. I could eat that all day. Their pork stew is SOOO good.  Kinda reminds me of ground pork in spaghetti but Asian style and served with raw veggies. It was really good. 

Also tried their black sticky rice with mango. It was good but not memorable. Would most definitely come back. The owner also ran out to give me my jacket I had forgotten. She told me to stay warm. So nice. Almost like a mother figure.
author: Tommy L.

description: Angkor Borei is an absolutely excellent, authentic, family-run Cambodian restaurant serving flavorful, delicious food with very clean flavors. My friends and I (group of 6) came on a Sunday night and were seated right away. We started with two appetizers, the spinach leaves and grilled beef skewers (like satay). The spinach leaves dish consisted of raw spinach leaves and a bunch of little fillings like chopped onion, chopped ginger, dried shrimps, chopped bell pepper, chopped lime, peanuts, and a sweet/savory sauce. The idea was to wrap a tiny bit of every topping in the spinach leaf and eat it like a taco--despite being a super simple dish, the flavor mixture from all the different fillings was so complex! The grilled beef satay was also unbelievable. The beef was flavorful, not dry, and came with a perfectly savory, delicious peanut sauce. For the main course, we split a couple items like a shrimp stir-fry, a chicken stir-fry, a beef stir-fry, and the pumpkin curry. The stir-fries were simple (and similar) but tasty--my favorite was the beef, which was tender and garlicy. But the pumpkin curry was by far the favorite dish of the table--the curry was lightly spicy and full of fresh vegetables, including a half kabocha pumpkin. The sauce went perfectly with the brown rice we ordered on the side and we could easily have drunk it up! We also ordered the Amok, a curry fish custard in banana leaf, which was so unique in texture and taste--it was piping hot and spiced perfectly. Unfortunately, they forgot to start this dish after we put in our order (and it also takes the longest to prepare) so we didn't get it until we were basically done with the other dishes, but it was worth the wait. The portion sizes here were also perfect--definitely not huge, but every dish was packed with good, clean flavors.
author: David K.

description:
Had a quick lunch during work on Friday and the food was pretty good.

We each ordered one dish each instead of the lunch specials with two items n soup $7.95.  We ordered the following 3 dishes between us.  
- A pancake wrap.  It had too many bean sprouts and lacked flavor.  Fortunately the fish sauce made it more flavorful. Very light if ur a light eater.
- Pad Thai stir fried Ho fun was very good.  Have to toss it with the egg, cilantro, crushed nuts n lime juice.  Really tasty.
- My favorite was the garlic fish.  Tons of flavor n the sauce was delicious with rice. $11.95.  
- mango black rice with coconut was excellent.  We all shared this as we were all too full $4.95
- Thai tea was really good too.  According to my friends daughter, she said it was the best Thai tea she had n not powdery like other places.

The bill came $47 total with tax n tip.  Not bad for once in while lunch.
Plenty of metered street parking during lunchtime.  Noticed a lot of locals eating alone.  Will return to try other dishes.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
It was OKAY.

I wanted to try something new (Cambodian food!) and this place had good reviews so I was pretty amped to try it! Transportation is easy (near the J and 14 stops) but parking can be pretty bad in this area (wooh Bernal Heights)

Plentiful seating since it's out of Hipster central so I don't think you would ever have to wait in line here!

Got the most talked about items:

Fish mousse (#48 ah mok I think?!) - it was different. Lots of fish packed in this mid-sized bamboo thing, definitely will get you full. Flavorful and moist! Kinda like curry fish but subtle, and not saucy? It was good though, and worth trying but not mind-blowing.

Spinach leaves - basically an appetizer where you wrap toasted coconut, dried shrimp, bell pepper, onion, ginger, peanuts and top it with some kinda fish sauce. It didn't look like that much but it was a good serving size for an app at least, maybe because you had to do so much work to spoon each thing and then wrap it. Otherwise I would feel jipped!

Pumpkin curry - I've had better, honestly, but it wasn't bad!

Service was friendly and fast!

I don't think I would return again since nothing blew my mind, and it's in Bernal Heights (I don't come here often!) but def worth trying!
author: Emily C.

description:
Oh dear god....for a place with hard to find parking besides safway, i had very high expectations of this location because it is the only supposed Cambodian restaurant in the city..
"Angkor Borei"...looks nice sounds nice, and some of the food looks nice but dear flipping god its more of a sham...

A)None of the Servers Speak cambodian, they are mostly of thai origin and background. Even when i listen to the cooks talk in the back, my relatives and I couldn't /didn't hear anything resembling the khmer language....you will be hard pressed to see anything different between this location and King of Thai...furthermore, the papaya salad listed above is dry and more on the bland side..

How exactly is this placed considered by any means "Cambodian" cuisine? This place is more like a westernized location for people who's taste buds can't tell the difference between Asian cuisines; particularly Thai -Cambodian-Laotion..the type of eaters who think all noodle soups are the same.(-1)

Recommendation:Champa garden has a more consistent and flavor salad.

B ) Duck Pri King is recooked "Siu Yap" Chinese roasted duck in spices and curry. Not freshly made.It really burns your lips and throat and you can't eat anything else on the menu... do avoid for safety purposes... (-1)

C) Amok-Fish Mousse is the closes resemblance of what cambodian food can be, but they stuffed a big broccoli in place of the fish in the center, not sure why they needed it to put there but probably just used to maintain the thickness of the mouse?Flavor wise, at least it was passable. (+1)

D)Spring rolls with Sweet and Sour Sauce
Crispy and consistent but nothing special. typical order to keep you busy before the meal comes, but judging by how this taste test turned out. Not really helping the case But not very ethnically special in flavoring (-1).

Verdict: Angkor Borei  is not worth it. no way.
author: Eric C.

description: Lovely family run restaurant. Pumpkin curry is the best! Good location between Bernal and the Mission.
author: Dan R.

description: Their fried pork rib and pan fried fish filet are great here. Great selection of Cambodian food!
author: Leo M.

description:
Hidden treasure! Family style restaurant with excellent food. First Cambodian restaurant I've tried and we are already looking forward to coming back to try other dishes. Can't wait :)
Note: it is a bit pricey and parking is super difficult
author: Chariss I.

description: Delicious and inexpensive! Great for takeout but cute vibe inside too. Love the pumpkin curry!
author: Ashley K.

description: I've been coming here for years, I even had a birthday dinner here a few years back. The food is very flavorful and fresh. I love all of their curries, their shrimp wrapped in bacon, the pineapple fried rice and their dessert, fried banana with coconut ice cream is to die for! The portions are on point and the service is absolutely attentive and everyone that works there is so sweet. Also, the the restaurant is beautifully decorated, very warm and inviting. Excellent Cambodian food!
author: Michi R.

description: Food was delicious (beef skewers, crepe, and pumpkin stew). They were out of the mango sticky rice, so we will be back to try that soon. Our server (possibly the owner?) was the sweetest, friendliest, and most attentive server we could ask for.
author: Stan K.

description:
The closest thing I've come to the Cambodian culture is going into AOL's KhMeR PriDe chat room years ago. I'm not Khmer, I was just a nosey f*ck.

Oh yah and the girl crush I had in hs only to find out she later became a nun?!?! Ugh, what a waste.

Oddly enough, the only Cambodian restaurant in San Francisco is located in the outskirts of The Mission and not in TL's Little Saigon. 

Cambodian food is very similar to Thai and Vietnamese cuisine. Angkor has a well-rounded menu including a vegetarian menu with mock meats. Absolutely no MSG is used as I confirmed it with the owner who said she avoids using this as it gives her headaches. She said, I would be able to "feel it" IF they use MSG (some Asian restaurants claim to use no MSG but they do) and she was right. I didn't get the heart palpitations, dry mouth, and headaches as I usually do with Asian food. Whoo hoo, bonus points!

You can normally tell if an ethnic restaurant is legit if there's natives dining there; I saw none and we were one of the only two Asian parties. And looking through reviews written by Khmer natives, it seems Angkor serves more Americanized Cambodian food which was obvious as some dishes really lacked the big, bold flavors present in Southeast Asian cuisine. However, they do use a lot of anchovies as a base for many of their dishes so you may a detect a pungent saltiness in some dishes and sauces.

F O O D
We ordered a total of 12 dishes for our group of 6; doubling up on some: http://bit.ly/VnUv9O. It's worthless to go through every single dish we ordered so I'll focus on my faves. 

Sorry for some of the blurry pics. I couldn't reach across the table so I asked Mr. NSS to help me take pics of dishes closer to him. Needless to say, he can't aim. =X

*Fresh Spinach Leaves ($6.95): http://bit.ly/XSpXxe
*Crispy Cambodian Crepe ($7.95): http://bit.ly/VnUCCg
*Charbroiled Beef Skewers ($7.95): http://bit.ly/UDh11g
*Cold Cambodian Noodles ($6.95): http://bit.ly/VvVKcn
*Ahmok: Fish Curry Mousse ($9.95 x 2): http://bit.ly/VnUTVP
*Duck Prik King: Duck in Red Curry ($10.95 x 2): http://bit.ly/129NDUF
*Pumpkin Curry w/ Shrimp ($14.95): http://bit.ly/Wy9cdI
*Prahok: Stewed Ground Pork ($9.95 x 2): http://bit.ly/UDhqR7
*Beef Pad Thai ($8.95): http://bit.ly/11fIxRS

If the 2013 7x7 Big Eats List brought you here and steered you wrong again, you can show them the one finger salute again. While the 7x7's Ahmok: Fish Curry Mousse had deliciously tender flakes of fish, the texture was more like a quiche than a mousse. I was not impressed.

Redeeming this, was the Prahok: Stewed Pork in Coconut Milk w/ Anchovies. Forget the raw veggies you're supposed to use for dipping and slather this thick, creamy pork concoction over your rice (they have brown rice). The anchovies gave this dish a surprisingly mouth-watering, salty punch that was purely addicting.

The Pumpkin Curry w/ Shrimp was a second fav. I didn't care for the shrimp because it was all about the rich, savory coconuty sauce and the sweet, tender kabocha it was served in. It definitely needed more of a kick though as the curry was too mild.

The guys loved and killed two orders of the Duck Prik King which was basically Chinese roast duck in a savory, slightly spicy red curry sauce and green beans. You can never go wrong with rich, fatty duck right?

Oh and if you must order an appetizer, get the Fresh Spinach Leaves. Nothing says, "sexy" like eating with your hands. Build your own Cambodian spinach "taco" with dried shrimp, peanuts, ginger, lime, red onion, bell peppers and toasted coconut and dip it into the sweet and sour sauce for a tasty textural sensation in the mouth.

S E R V I C E
Wearing traditional Cambodian Sampots (long cloth worn as a skirt), the owner and staff were very welcoming and friendly as well as socially engaging. However, food service was slow as there was a 35 minute lag from apps to entrees.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Normally, I would never suggest an Asian joint for a date, but Angkor (50 person capacity) is tastefully decorated with glass encased gold embroidered linen place mats, sultry burgundy walls and straws topped with a paper rose which make it quite a romantic yet casual place.

P A R K I N G
Horrendous street parking at night so allot an additional 15 minutes for parking.

Speaking of AOL chat rooms, am I the only that wishes they still existed? Too bad, I can't go into the BaY ArEa AzNs 18-24 no more...oh actually, I can if I wanted to go cub hunting. Cougar status. RAWR!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Was craving Cambodian food for so long. I use to eat homemade Cambodian food at my friend's house. I'm glad I found this place on yelp. I brought my boyfriend here (first time eating Cambodian food). He loved it. Service was good, ambience good and the food was wonderful!
author: A M.

description:
Love love love. Small cozy restaurant with friendly staff and authentic dishes just like how I had them in Cambodia.  Cold Cambodian Noodle is a great appetizer for sharing, and Stewed Ground Pork (Prahok) so flavorful and leaves you wanting to come back for more.  

Also a good place for takeouts, extremely timely with their preparation and always  have the food ready to go when you show for pickup.
author: Angel W.

description:
This place is good. Really really good Cambodian. My mom had been recommending this place for awhile but its just enough out of the way that we haven't found an excuse and when we finally did, I was pleasantly surprised. 

I ordered a Pumpkin Curry, BBQ Chicken, Ahmohk and Pad Thai - it was so worth it. Everything was fantastic. The staff was really great too. I highly recommend it.
author: Analisa S.

description: Delicious. Favorite dishes: charbroiled beef, fish mousse, desserts! Chicken larb at medium spice was quite spicy. Papaya salad needed something...perhaps some citrus for brightness. Charbroiled pork chop was very good too. They were out of the lemongrass tea so can't wait to go back to get that and try out other dishes.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Super stoked to go to this place. Since I miss having Cambodian food on a regular basis. Looking through the menu I asked them if they had curry I can dip with bread. The waitress looked at my like she had no clue what I was talking about. Anyhow, I ended up ordering beef stick, Prahok, and yellow pancake.

Yellow pancake needed real shrimp, but overall good flavors

Prahok wasn't pungent enough! After all I'm Cambodian the smellier the better!

Beef Stick was meh.....

Overall the flavors where alittle bland for my taste. This is a good place to take your non-Cambodian friends to break them into the food. I would never hear to the end of it if I took my parents here.

Overall a pleasant experience and great service.
author: Ejm L.

description: This hidden gem has some of the tastiest food I've had in years.  The pumpkin curry is especially delicious.  Very vegetarian friendly.  And the people are so nice!!
author: Sarah C.

description:
DISCLAIMER: I only ordered a beef pad thai and a shrimp pad thai here for takeout so the two stars are just for those two dishes.

I know, I know, this is a Cambodian place, why the hell would I order pad thai?! I live a few minutes away, and I was craving pad thai late at night....and and and...well I just got lazy about doing my research and ordered from this place because it got pretty good ratings. Sigh. I figured the the pad thai would be passable. NOPE. The noodles were bland, the beef was tough and stringy, and the shrimp didn't taste all too fresh. The only redeeming quality was the quantity. They gave us nice healthy portions.

I'll give this place another try when I'm craving Cambodian food next time though!
author: Catherine C.

description: The staff is amazingly on point and friendly. We got the #51 and 53 and they both were really flavorful. I ended ordering the clay pot and it was delicious. Coming back again!
author: Sandeep C.

description:
My friend and I met up for dinner at Angkor Borei since it wasn't too far from her workplace. We were greeted by a really nice lady, who may be the owner of the restaurant! Our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomachs as we gazed through their menu!

FOODS
-------------------------
- Papaya Salad - It was good, but it wasn't the authentic Cambodian papaya salad!

- Bacon Wrapped Prawn Eggrolls - My favorite dish! Anything with bacon is just delicious and my friend ended up getting another order to go because it was that good!

- Beef Skewers - We liked every bite and it goes well with rice and papaya salad!

- Amok - This is one of those dishes one must try in a Cambodian restaurant! The catfish wrapped in banana leaves was pretty good! Angkor Borei uses fish sauce as a dipping sauce for the dish which we thought was unnecessary. It just made it taste more fishy....

Mango & Sitcky Rice - This is a very common dessert in many Southeast Asian restaurants. And since Cambodian cuisine is very similar to Thai we had to get this and try it! The portion is small compared to other place, but it didn't disappoint.

Overall the food was good and filling. The service was fast and super friendly as well!
author: Glenn L.

description:
My mom is a huge fan of Angkor Borei, so when I mentioned that I was in need of some spicy soup to sooth my sore throat she suggested the Spicy Cambodian Seafood Soup. It was past the dinner hour and didn't feel like cooking myself, so we decided to go. 

We arrived and we seated right away. I ordered hot tea for two and the crispy spring rolls as a appetizer. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/SEDGOmBM_J10LEUR8M-BUQ?select=0DqxU11QYHMWDgF_BCoFYA 

For my main, I ordered the Spicy Cambodian Seafood Soup. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/SEDGOmBM_J10LEUR8M-BUQ?select=0IJ7B-_ipCEf98e_rUlT4w It looked like a lot, but I ate the whole thing. I felt like it helped a little, the heat and great tasting broth. 

My mom ordered the Chicken Larb Salad. It's one of her favorites to order and make at home. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/SEDGOmBM_J10LEUR8M-BUQ?select=W0_RNm7Zv6pBFXNkv0tDAw

I enjoyed my dinner a lot and now I'm a big fan of Angkor Borei too. Sometimes you just have to listen to your Mom and do what is right for you. When you can't have homemade, you should probably find the best soup you can.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Delicious food in an intimate and comfortable place. It's a neighborhood destination that feels like home. Explore the menu and try something new. The veggie green curry is a fantastic departure from the usual curries you find at other places. Service is great and it feels like a friend is waiting on your table.
author: Chester B.

description:
The house we rented for a week in this neighborhood had a binder full of places to eat at, and this was right up front, with bold lettering stating that we "absolutely must eat here". My love of food runs deep, so that was enough to pique my interest and get me over here for lunch. 

The joint was a ghost town at one o'clock on a weekday. We took a table up front by the window. Our waitress brought over two small glasses of water. 

I haven't had much Cambodian food before, but the menu looked very similar to what you'd expect to find at a Thai restaurant. Some ingredients were different (obviously),  but overall if you like Thai you'd like this. The lunch special allows you to pick two entrees, which come with soup, rice, and a small salad. I got the ginger beef and sauteed chicken. The dishes both had a nice refreshing quality to them, thanks to some cilantro in the beef and spearmint in the chicken. Amazing what a little touch of something different can do for an otherwise simple lunch. My beef was a bit tough, the chicken a tad dry, but the overall flavoring and quality were totally good. 

It may not have lived up to the hype our house menu had led us to believe, but this is a perfectly good place to grab a great lunch special.
author: Anthony A.

description:
Stopped here for lunch, after it was recommended highly. I had never had Cambodian food, and must confess, I didn't even know where Cambodia was...Africa?? Wrong. I learned it was by Thailand and Vietnam.. Oops, Geography was never my thing. 

It's similar to Thai food I suppose.  Great price on lunch specials.  I had the BBQ chicken and Egg Rolls. It was all pretty tasty. I also liked the soup and salad that came with it. Food is served on square plates that were all chipped up.  One thing I know, is eating on chipped plates is not healthy. Bacteria can harbor on even the smallest of cracks. Time to buy some new plates guys.
author: Christina P.

description:
I had an amazing experience with the owners. The wife was kind and helpful as I fumbled through ordering a very large order for my child's school. I'd been asked to obtain certain items and although I'm quite versed in many Asian dishes, Cambodian food is not one I've experienced. 

Although I placed my order in advance, I'd asked for the order to be ready essentially 15 after they open their doors. On the day of pick up I was surprised by a phone call indicating the food was almost ready and to please take my time coming to get it. The restaurant is located on a busy street but I found close enough parking. The owners helped me carry the food to my car, explained what was what and they were generous and kind. 

I recommend the restaurant for its amazing food and quaint atmosphere. Inside the restaurant was incredibly clean and the owners are truly welcoming.
author: Anikka G.

description:
We were in the city and decided to have dinner with some friends there. Our friend picked this place. Saw it on the way to work and thought it would be good. 

I found that the front door was a little interesting. It's not really the traditional business door. Looked more like the front door of a house. Should I knock or ring the doorbell? Nevermind, just open the door. Hope they don't mind unannounced guests. 

Pretty small place. I don't think there were more than 10 tables in this place. Since there were 5 of us, we did family style. Ordered about 6 different dishes. Got to try a little bit of everything. 

+ Pumpkin Curry with Chicken
+ Pineapple Fried Rice
+ Sauteed Eggplant
+ Duck Phrik King
+ Fish Mousse
+ Chili Shrimp

I've never really had Cambodian food, but looking at the menu a lot of it looked like Thai food to me. The fish mousse was the most Cambodian dish. I mean, I know that Cambodian food (like most other Asian foods) are often influenced by food of surrounding regions. Hard to tell if it was really Cambodian or more Thai flavors in the food. I wish there was more sauce in the curry as I love to drizzle it over my rice. The portions weren't very big. I was a little disappointed with how small the fish mousse was. Everything was very tasty though!
author: Cindy K.

description: Best authentic Cambodian food outside of Cambodia. The owners are amazing and friendly people. We are neighbors to the restaurant and eat there frequently. Being vegetarian our needs are accommodated very well. I love this place I would give it 10 stars if possible!
author: Andrew P.

description:
Really nice people running the place. The fish mousse, ahmohk ($11) is my fave. But I do think it's an acquired taste. 

Salt and pepper ribs were awesome. And the pumpkin curry is possibly one of the best curries I've ever had. I just wished it came with more curry sauce. We had to order more curry sauce for $2.50.

It's a small place but the tables are spaced out well.

I think it's a total gem.
author: Andy W.

description:
I'm a big fan of this joint!

I came here after a friend recommended it, and they are just consistently good every time! Staff is always attentive and really pleasant, genuine and really friendly in the kitchen as much as outside. It feels like a good family run little restaurant where you could come in and order your usual :)

All their dishes have been really tasty, we're big fans of their chili or basil entrees (keep in mind that "mild" means no spiciness at all, so go at least medium!), as well as their charbroiled ones. Presentation is always really good, almost too good to eat. They accept credit cards, and even do delivery within the area. Weekday nights aren't too busy, but they get more packed on weekends, so I'd recommend making a reservation if you have a party larger than 2!
author: Jade T.

description: This place is definitely a hidden gem in this (not yet gentrified) part of Mission street. The service is excellent, the food is delicious, and it's never crowded. The best part is that you can have a conversation in a normal tone of voice here. Great place to meet a group of friends or for a date. Highly recommended.
author: Mikkel R.

description:
I had high expectation, because I really enjoyed Cambodian restaurants in the South Bay.

Looking at the menu, everything look familiar since the dishes are very similar to what you would find in Thai restaurants.

We ordered the crepe for appetizer, which is yummy. For entree, we got the fried fish fillet with garlic sauce and chili chicken.

The fish filet was great, the filet is still crispy although it has sauce all over. The chili chicken though, was unremarkable, as it's basically just a sauteed chicken and veggies, and even though we ordered it hot spicyness-wise, it's still kinda sweet for me.

I wish the flavor is more bold, or maybe Cambodian dishes are just milder?
author: Novalina N.

description: Great service! But I felt like this is much like Thai food, not as authentic Cambodian??! Doesn't really matter, I will still come back if I'm in the area.
author: Jenn J.

description: Excellent discovery in the neighborhood.  I stumbled upon Angkor Borei by accident and was delighted with the place.  It is a small, intimate family run restaurant with amazingly good food for the price.  I have been back three times and the quality and consistancy of the food and service have never disappointed.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for something different than Chinese or Thai.
author: Steve H.

description: Delicious food, friendly service, and great price! The fresh spinach leaves were the perfect starter. I will come back again to try more of the menu.
author: Angela B.

description:
This place is really tasty and offers some unique dishes and favors. This restaurant is a family-run business that has been in the neighborhood for years, prices are very good and good quality. They offer nice little touches too, like fabric napkins and a nice ambiance. I recommend:

-fresh spinach leaves appetizer (#7): there are so many ingredients that you sandwich in spinach leaves, but they all come together so well with their sauce. Delicious!

-charbroiled pork slices (#30): this is a simple dish, but the marinade they use and the cooking is perfect

-lemongrass tea drink: light, refreshing and not too sweet!

-fried banana and Mitchell's coconut ice cream: how can you not like freshly battered fried banana and I love Mitchell's ice cream! Their shop is in the neighborhood too.

I look forward to my next visit to try the pumpkin curry and the Ahmohk!
author: Anna L.

description:
The food was amazing and the owner was lovely.  She was so attentive and hospitable, I can't believe I missed this place and had never been there!

The pumpkin curry is to die for and the spinach salad is so fun!  Don't miss the sticky mango rice.
author: aliya j.

description:
What a great little find that has been in San Francisco for 29 years.  The husband and wife that run this restaurant couldn't have been any nicer and welcoming for our group.  We had never had Cambodian food so she walked us through everything and suggested some things that we should try.

We started off with the spring rolls which were tasty and the sauce made it.
