5 stars. It's our go-to place on the weekend when the Mission gets mobbed and all the fancier places take forever to get into and are rendered miserable.
author: Willa K.

description:
their lunch deals are super cheap! like so cheap that if they were located downtown they'd be ridonkulously popular. instead they're in bernal heights and people still know about them.

I got this cold noodle thing that the woman told me was the khmer version of bun and it was pretty good, lots of citrus, good herbs, 6 dollars.
author: Misha T.

description:
3.5 Stars

I had the cold noodle with chicken. I liked the hint of coconut sauce, but the cucumber that came with the dish was a bit bitter. 

I really liked their bbq chicken, yum anything with lemongrass makes my taste buds happy. 

I enjoyed their fried banana with ice cream. The fried banana had a hint of cinnamon, a really nice touch. 

I'd definitely would come back to try their other dishes.
author: Mandy D.

description: Quite disappointed with this place. I thought I was going to be stepping into a Khmer restaurant, instead the people were Siamese/Thai. I ordered the grill beef stick and that wasn't up to par either. I should have known, since most Khmer people reside in Oakland instead of San Francisco.
author: Chan T.

description: All we tasted was the pumpkin curry special and a beef+peanut dish. Pumpkin curry was amazing, probably the best pumpkin curry I've ever had. The beef dish was good too, but didn't blow my mind. Overall the place is nice and the wait staff is friendly. Would definitely return.
author: Laurent L.

description: Tasty food, quick service, calm atmosphere, very subdued. I had a sauteed beef and vegetable dish with a nice level of spice to it. I will definitely be back!
author: Rajesh S.

description: Delicious and well priced! I ordered the hot and sour soup with beef: it was delicious and perfect for a cold night. The pumpkin curry was enjoyed by everyone in our party as was the mango sticky rice for desert. The Cambodian crepe wasn't as great as the rest of the items. It will be a goto pick place going forward.
author: Nasrin M.

description: I have to say, I was a little disappointed when the spinach leaf appetizer came to the table, some assembly required. That was just my heavy bias though because I had just run a half marathon that morning and really wanted food served to me without having to do any work myself. I had the ahmok with shrimp (fish + shrimp mousse). The waitress recommended the version with shrimp over the fish alone. I was happy with this recommendation and thought it was pretty good. Overall, a pretty good restaurant, I thought the bill was a little expensive for what it was.
author: Stephen S.

description: the place is tiny and the decor nothing special but the food is AMAZING and the service is friendly. Enjoy it every time I go!
author: Asher B.

description:
This place is better than most of the Cambodian food that I've eaten in Cambodia.  The mock duck curry is my personal favorite dish, with exactly the right amount of fish sauce.  The larb and the ribs are also both excellent.

If you haven't had Cambodian food before, its similar to Vietnamese.  My Vietnamese wife prefers this to any of the Vietnamese places we've tried in the Mission.  I'm sad they stopped delivering, I used to order from here at least one, often twice a week.
author: Sam E.

description: Asked them three times if they would deliver to me. They said yes. Then I asked again to make sure, they said yes. And I put in my order. Five minutes later I was called and told they couldn't deliver it. Then I was confused because they said they could deliver it over the phone. The man on the phone responded "We can deliver it for $15." And then I got really annoyed and hung up. Stay away. They are a scam. This place is a joke.
author: Bert D.

description:
Spinach leaf appetizer was delicious. It was the first time I had ever had it though, so perhaps I am a bit biased; I mean how hard is it to chop up the veggies and put everything on a tray?

Clay pot mock chicken was fabulous as well, no strange textures or anything with the faux meat.  My mom loved the mussels (I HATE mussels, so I didn't try them). She said they were fresh and that the sauce was perfect. 

Good prices...I would frequent this place if I lived nearby.
author: Adrienne R.

description:
Read Connie C's review. 

The dried beancurd is a great vegetable dish!
author: Helen Y.

description:
This is your typical, dime a dozen Cambodian restaurant.   ;-)

Seriously speaking, this place is great.  It's authentic, family-run and a nice change of cuisine from your typical Mexican/Italian/Chinese/Thai fare that are a dime a dozen.

Came for dinner on what happened to be Valentine's Day (of course, looking around it didn't look as if anyone was really celebrating V Day.  Not that surprising as it's casual and not really the type of place you'd think of for a fancy or romantic dinner).

Still, our hostess and server (who, by the way, was waiting on all the tables and quite efficiently, I might add) was dressed festively in red and went around lighting candles.  Sweet.

Even sweeter was the food.  Loved the spinach leaves appetizer: individual spinach leaves served with little bowls of chopped lime, nuts, spices and dried shrimp.  You can literally taste every flavor and texture in this dish.  Amazing.

Also loved the Cambodian crepe appetizer: spiced meat and veggies wrapped in a light, flaky crust that soaked up all the juices.  

The spicy hot and sour soup with shrimp was also delicious with just the right amount of tanginess from the lemongrass.

Finally, we had the pumpkin curry.  This one here was one of the nicely presented versions I had ever seen.  The serve the curry inside a half a peeled pumpkin bowl so that you can literally carve the pumpkin and have it gush out onto a larger bowl.  Beautiful and the curry was really good as well.

Reasonably priced and now a neighborhood favorite.  Can't wait to go back.
author: F. P.

description:
I can't believe I haven't tried this place sooner! I've never had Cambodian food before so I went in with no expectations. Now, any Cambodian restaurant I go to will have to be compared to this one (mostly because I've never had Cambodian food elsewhere before). All of the dishes were flavorful, the staff are very friendly and the bathroom felt homey and clean.

My two favorites were the crispy rice chips with dip and the ahmohk (fish mousse). You HAVE to try them! JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
I absolutely LOVE Angkor Borei!!!!  I guess I used to take it for granted back in the day when I lived over on Day and Sanchez in outer Noe Valley....

I swung by tonight (since I was in the neighborhood) and was so blown away I had to praise them!!!!

We ordered the Veggie Spring Rolls, Mock Chicken Salad, the spinach, the mock ginger chix (mock chix not mock ginger), and the mock chilie chix.

PHENOMENAL!!!!!  Oh my god!!!!  The mock chicken is tender and seasoned and so moist and flavorful!!!  Something else:  Fresh.  This place as I remember it, and as I eat tonight ... always uses fresh ingredients!!!  Fresh ...like you see the bright green of the spinach and green beans still =)  You know how some other places just kill the vegetables past recognition or boil them till their pale..... not here.... they keep everything fresh and delicious =)  Yum!!

I love this place for it's amazing service and cozy ambiance as well.  I'd even go as far as categorize this one as a romantic date restaurant for sure.  The staff are super attentive and so polite ~

I won't stay away this long again Angkor Borei!!!  I love you!!!
author: Christine G.

description:
I'd never had Cambodian food before.  I love it!

Amanita P.'s review pretty much says it all.  The Cambodian crepe appetizer was absolutely delicious.  If we weren't in public, I'd have licked the plate.  As it was, I seriously had to restrain myself.  It wasn't easy.

Fried fish was another winner.  Light, crispy coating.  MMM.  Beef curry: savory, hearty, warm, sigh.  

Black sticky rice for dessert, with fresh mango.  I'm new to sticky rice, but really liked it.  As I mentioned to Amanita P., it's sorta oatmealish.. warm &, um, oatmeal-type textured.  In a good way!  Sweet, but not overly.. a great dessert for someone who doesn't have much of a sweet tooth.  But also sweet enough to satisfy my yearning for sugah.  Mango was ripe & yummy.

I was sort of surprised by just how much I LOVED all the food here.  It was all warm & comforting & delicious.  Yes, comforting.. I was surprised, too!  The interior of the restaurant is also cozy, with warm, earthy colors & soft lighting.  AB is a solid favorite already; I can't wait to return!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Super bomb!

Vegan Claypot Duck is the best.
author: Nathan U.

description:
My first time trying Cambodian food was a success!  On the recommendation of Yelp we ordered the crepe appetizer to share...was not disappointed!  In fact, I was a little jealous that one of my dinnermates had ordered the crepe as his meal.

But, then my seafood pumpkin curry came out and I was envious no more.  It wasn't really different from other (Burmese) pumpkin curries I've had...but all pumpkin curries I've had have been absolutely delicious.  So, win-win.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Disclaimer: not familiar with authentic Cambodian.  But overall pretty flavourful, prices comprable or slightly higher than similar class SE Asian, attentive service.  Came for Sunday dinner with one friend, not terribly busy, 4-5 tables of folks.

Dishes:
- cold Cambodian noodles
- pan fried fish fillet with three flavour spicy sauce
- vegetable red curry with mock chicken

Pros:
- service: everything happened quickly without feeling rushed, refilled water and served our rice, extremely polite, warm demeanour
- strong flavours in the fish: I happen to like my food on the intense side, so that was great, went well with brown rice
- ambiance: quiet, subdued, perfect for dinner with a friend or two when you actually want to chat and not have to shout, or a date :)

Cons: 
- portions on the small side compared to most SE Asian places
- cold noodles were...meh.  The ground fish didn't have a distinctive or particularly noteworthy taste

Would come back, if a friend drove me again, haha.
author: Marco C.

description:
Just got delivery from these folks (probably the 20th time over the past year) and I honestly think this may be the best delivery food in all of North America.

The food is outstanding, they always get our order right, the price is reasonable and they always show up fast.

If all delivery was this good, the world would be an outstanding place
author: Jim K.

description:
Went here for dinner with Rebecca M. last night for dinner. Wow, what a great place. The only other Cambodian restaurant I'd been to was Angkor Wat in the Richmond (now closed I think) ten years ago. This place is less fancy but the food is as good or better. 

We had the Cambodian crepe app - a nice light eggy crepe filled with ground pork, bean sprouts and other veggies with a nice spicy/sweet fish sauce. We ate every speck of it. 

Then we had pan-fried fish with ginger, cellophane noodles and a bunch of veggies. It was very gingery and the fish very light and flaky - again we ate every bit.

We also had the beef curry. Very similar to Thai Massaman curry but a little less sweet. It was fanfuckingtastic. We didn't finish it because we were getting full and figured it would be good for left overs (I think I may mosey on over and have it for breakfast now!).

For dessert we had black sticky rice with mango, very cozy, oatmealy, delish dessert.

This is a fantastic place, the service was great as well and I'm sure we'll be back a bunch of times in the future.
author: Sam P.

description:
HOLY CRAP I love the Hot and Sour Vegetarian soup, the Vegetarian Crispy Cambodian Crepe appetizer, Iced Lemongrass Tea and the Tofu Pumpkin Curry! Angkor Borei is the only place I have ever had Cambodian Khmer food so it is hard for me to make comparisons but the food is similar to Thai food but lighter and less dependent on coconut milk, the flavors are earthy. I also recommend avoiding the faux meats such as faux duck meat and faux chicken, the texture is truly disturbing- I think it is flavored seitan, I am not a fan. 

My dining partner was in love with the (#48) Fish Ahmohk, a curry fish mousse dish served in a banana leaf. Prices are reasonable for the awesome food, expect to spend around $40 for 2 people with drinks. 

The lunch combo specials are very well priced at $7.25 but are not vegetarian friendly and the lunchtime house soup had chicken broth the day I came for lunch.  

They also have free delivery within 2 miles of their Bernal Heights location.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
So, one hungry night, me and my roomie go driving around the Mission to look for stuff to eat. He's not sure what he wants, and I'm not either, except that both of us have just about had it with taquerias. I notice the Angkor Borei sign, and we decide to go in. 

VERY GOOD DECISION. Do not regret it. Now, I'm no expert on what 'proper' Cambodian food's supposed to taste like, but whatever Angkor Borei is, it's pretty awesome. 

I had the peanut mock chicken, which was pretty bomb, especially with the sticky rice. The mock chicken texture's pretty chicken-like, although it's got its own fake-veggie-food charm, if you know what I mean. It's always good to see a restaurant with real vegetarian options other than 'oh, let's just remove the meat from our non-veggie options'. I've already gone twice and plan on going more often when I have the money to be eating out at actual restaurants.

Congratulations, Angkor Borei, on getting one of my few five-star reviews.
author: Finn G.

description:
Cruised out to bernal heights after a long crazy B2Bbrkrs day. 
had a big party so called ahead and got right in. 

we tried the cambodian crepe as a starter, a lot like Larb in a crepe, tried some of our friends Larb (solid, very thai tasting), and got the chicken curry - everything was good, like a delicate, toned down thai. 

it was a good meal with unique, tasty flavours - everything tasted quite fresh, but the portions were very small and overall, i think i'd rather hit up a nice thai or vietnamese place the next time i'm craving SE asian fare. not bad, but nothing very standout about the experience
author: Ben B.

description:
Yumm!  We had the Yelp Special - the faves on Yelp -
Spinach leaf Appetizer
Pumpkin Curry with Chicken
Ahmok fish mousse

Totally satisfying and pleasing to the senses.  The waitress was very sweet and friendly, too!  Definitely a SF Neighborhood Gem.
author: Ravi C.

description:
Really debated between three stars and four, but our last experience pushed us to a three. 

Pumpkin Curry- thought it was good but not sure what all the hype was about. A little too thick for my liking

Cashew Chicken- hubby liked it! 

Sweet and sour pork- it was alright but not enough pork and too over fried 

Spinach leaves- yummy!!

Beef Appetizer- beef was tender but didn't blow my mind

Fried crepe- yummy!

It's so close to us that we would def come back if we wanted an Asian fix.

Service is always attentive and welcoming!!
author: Candace D.

description:
Service: About average
Food Eaten: Beef salad, crepe, sour soup, sauted beef
Price: Pretty decent
Would I come here again: Probably

Being part Cambodian myself, I already have an idea of what certain foods should "taste" like. Out of all of the things I have tried here, the sour soup hits closet to home. 

I do have to say that my mom is an excellent cook so its pretty hard to match/beat her cooking. I definitely come here if I am craving some more sour soup but a lot of the other stuff that my mom makes here isn't available...it would be nice if they expanded their menu a little.
author: Richard L.

description:
Tasty, cozy, and very vegetarian friendly.  And just plain friendly.  

We got the vegetarian cambodian crispy crepe (yum), which is very much like a vietnamese crepe with different flavors, mock chicken salad (also yum, and also much like a vietnamese salad), and mock duck in a clay pot with rice noodles and veggies.  

Ah, and brown rice.  I like places that serve me brown rice.  Oh, and singha.  You know I like places that serve me singhas. 

Definitely worth the small odyssey our trip to bernal turned into!
author: Dana S.

description:
It's been many years since I paid a visit to Angkor Borei and the place has changed a fair amount.  I do not know for sure, but I'll bet there was a change in ownership from Cambodian to Thai.  Loads of Thai items on the menu these days.

We sampled some old favorites.  Cambodian Crepe, Green Papaya Salad, Ahmok (fish mousse) and #50 tri-flavored fish.  We also shared the pumpkin curry (Thai dish).  

The pumpkin curry was excellent and I'd have that aain any day.  The curry is served in a kabocha pumpkin bowl and was delicious.

The tri-flavored fish was excellent, although next time I will ask if they can steam the fish rather than fry it. The sauce was excellent as I remembered.

The ahmok (fish mousse) was overly salty and I did not enjoy it as well.

Cambodian crepe and green papaya salad were average.  not bad, not spectacular.

The iced coffee was completely unremarkable.  In the old days it was more like a dessert, now it is barely flavored with coffee.

We ate pretty much everything and declared the meal to be A-okay.  Not what it once was, but still very tasty.  I saw a mussels dish on the menu I'd like to come back and try out.  If I'm out in the area, I'd certainly go back.  The service was attentive, friendly and the food was pretty good.
author: Donna H.

description:
I had only had Cambodian food twice before going here, once at Phnom Penh (overrated) and once at Battambang (absolutely phenomenal).

I was curious to see if San Francisco's only Cambodian restaurant could measure up to the amazing Battambang. 

In short, it absolutely can.

Two of the three dishes we ordered were real authentic cambodian food, the crepe and the fish mousse, and the beef curry was on par with the amazing curry at Battambang (how do those Cambodians get their curries to taste better than any other country's curry?)

Service was extremely friendly but not overbearing. We ordered a bottle of Riesling which was a perfect match for the food, and marked up less than twice retail price (how often do you see that?).

The only negative, and why I give the edge to Battambang, was dessert. Ordered the fried banana with ice cream, but instead of being crispy, it was chewy, which couldn't even be rescued by the amazing Mitchell's ice cream it came with (for the best rendition of this dish, go to Pagolac in the Tenderloin).

Nonetheless, Angkor Borei has phenomenally good yet affordable food, and should be at the top of anyone's list for Southeast Asian restaurants in San Francisco.

After tax and tip, two of us had enjoyed a gourmet feast of an appetizer, two entrees, dessert, and a bottle of wine for $72. Where else can you do that in SF?
author: Mark A.

description: Um, this place is Delicious!!! I usually order the chili chicken, but everything is good.
author: Cate L.

description:
Had dinner here as part of an exotic dining Meetup group. The Downside: You don't know what has been ordered for you. The Upside: Everything has been pre-ordered, so you just sit down and enjoy the feast!  Angkor Borei is a small, only about a dozen tables, family-owned and operated kind of place, in a predominantly hispanic area on Mission Street. Plenty of parking on the side streets. 

It was my very first taste of Cambodian cuisine, and started with "Nakhon" Beer, a brand new to me, and I thought much tastier than the ubiquitous  "Singha."  

We had Spring Rolls as appetizers, then a series of meat (Chili Chicken) and fish courses, "Ankhom" is this fish mousse, delicious! Finishing off with Mango Pudding with Sweet Sticky Rice. Everything was quite tasty, but again, can't tell you the names, as it was all ordered in advance for us.

If you enjoy Thai or Burmese cuisine, you'll also like Cambodian. Prices were very reasonable, and the menu was quite extensive.

We had somebody in our party who was Cambodian, and he said that there are more "authentic" Cambodian restaurants in the East Bay, but located in very rough neighborhoods, so go there only for lunch. 

All in all, pretty good dining experience, but would like to know how it compares to other Cambodian restaurants.
author: Ronald R.

description:
I was told that this is the only Cambodian restaurant in SF now.  The owner is this very nice lady who welcomes you with all smile.  When you go this restaurant, it's like going to an Auntie's home and always checking on you if everything is okay and if you want more food, hahah.  Very attentive.  

I would've rated it 4 because some dishes are decent, but nothing extraordinary.  But the extra star is for the awesome crispy rice and the $6.50 lunch deal.  

Crispy rice... well you get a lettuce leaf, put the crispy rice then the sauce then enjoy!  I would nonstop eat this!  

The $6.50 lunch deal.  You get a soup, not just broth but good soup with tofu and stuff with coconut milk, delicious.  Then you get to pick 2 dishes from different dishes that they have to offer for this deal. 

The crepe appetizer is good too.  I tried the prahok with the recommendation from my  Cambodian friends and that was awesome except I don't like some of the veggies.  

I've yet to try dessert... I'm always full after this or since Mitchell's ice cream is just right there... we always end up going there.
author: Claire J.

description: I've been coming here for years and only now thought to write a review. I would imagine I've eaten here at least a hundred times and I've never once been disappointed. The vegetarian menu is extensive, the fish always exquisite, the service impeccable, the decor cosy and understated. As good as it gets.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Things to order:

vegetarian spring rolls - delish! crispy, light, flavorfull and the sauce is to die for. Dip your little heart out.

red curry with chicken - probably the most boring thing on the menu, right? but you know what, it was really good. At first I was a little underwhelmed, but the more I ate the more I liked it. It was hard to not eat the whole thing though I was stuffed!

hot water - yes, I am serious. They put a little lemon at the bottom and it is so refreshing with the curry. 

PLUS - They deliver! No one delivers around here! This is almost too exciting to handle. Order away everyone!
author: Holly C.

description:
Boy do I want to be a fan of this place. There's nothing I cherish more than coming to SF to eat exotic asian food, especially in far in the outskirts locations. Coupled with the glowing reviews on yelp as well as from trusted friends, I was really expecting something special. Unfortunately, each and every dish we ordered was about as meh as I could imagine.

We tried to order a smattering of the recommended items from other yelp reviews, baring the fish based dishes (since as much as I'd like to enjoy fish, for some reason I simply cannot unless it is raw).

To start, we had the spinach leaf appetizer. This came with toasted coconut, lime slices, peanuts, dried shrimp, ginger, peppers, and some sweetened lime / fish-sauce (similar to what you'd get at a Thai restaurant for dipping the fresh spring rolls in). Nothing here was that amazing, and I didn't find the sauce to really stand out. I did enjoy the lime wedges coupled with the dried shrimp, but half way through the app I had to stop, simply too bored to continue eating.

Next they brought out the ginger mock chicken. We're not vegetarians, but I love seitan as much as the next man (hail seitan), and have been known to enjoy mock chicken/duck as much or more than the real thing at some Thai restaurants (well, not more than, but as a better chewy protein based option than chicken for some particular dishes). This dish actually reminded me of something you'd get out of one of those Thai frozen dinners that people in my office seem to love--bland, unimaginative, and not very tasty.

Then, the charbroiled pork. This one was the favorite of the night, but only relatively. This one had some flavor that I couldn't place exactly, but in a good way. Overall pretty dry and not much dimension to it, but a satisfying porky chew. The mrs. loved the combination of the cabbage and pork (but as someone that grew up in a Russian household, of course she would).

Finally, some pineapple fried rice came out. This was under salted and pretty bland. My pineapple fried rice kicks its ass up and down the street.

Now, I have never been to Cambodia (but am dying to go) and have only heard amazing stories of the people and the food. Maybe tonight's experience was due to fish based dishes being the best on the menu (or the pumpkin that everyone raved about, but I couldn't bring myself to order due to my general distaste for pumpkin anything), or maybe it was due to too high expectations. Regardless, I'm not recommending this place nor will I be returning.

Still four more nights of SF goodness and looking forward to tomorrow :)
author: Josh H.

description:
Skip it. It's not good. 
My friend and I ordered takeout here the other night. I came here once last year in the summer and had a great meal. This time I had a very different experience. I'll keep it short because I hate how people sometimes drag on. Basically we called for delivery. Twenty minutes later the food arrived, which seemed a little too fast and leads me to question the freshness. Once we opened everything (wee got three dishes, and sweet and sour chicken dish, a cashew chicken dish, and a tofu vegetable curry), there seemed to be literally half the cashew chicken dish missing (an $11 dish). We just said whatever and started eating because we were starving. Basically the whole meal was awful. The chicken was so overdone it was tough and hard to chew. Half of the sweet and sour dish was onions. Nothing tasted that great, and the quality was nonexistent. We paid $40 for a terrible meal. 

Definitely don't bother with this place.
author: Jenna K.

description:
Even though I have been meaning to visit Angkor Borei for some time, it's hard to not want to go back to one of the other great restaurants that are located in Bernal (Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, Blue Plate, Front Porch, just to name a few). 

Determined to be adventurous on a rainy Saturday night, we had the SPICY HOT AND SOUR SOUP (with tomatoes, mushrooms, zucchini, lemongrass, lime juice, mint, & garlic) for appetizer. I ordered the CLAY POT MOCK DUCK (simmered with bean-thread noodles,, spinach, zucchini, carrot, mushrooms, tomatoes and bell peppers, spices and spearmint) while my friend had the AHMOHK (which is a mild curry fish mousse served in a banana leaf basket). The word "mousse" is a bit misleading ... I think it was just cod or salmon fillet. Unfortunately I am a vegetarian and can't have any but it smelled great!

The soup appetizer was very flavorful as well although we shouldn't have gotten it "spicy" spicy. Even for someone like me, it was a bit much.

The clay pot mock chicken was a little different than what I had expected. I didn't think it was going to be as soupy and curry like. Still it was very tasty. Although I must say I not a fan of mock chicken therefore would just stick with fresh tofu the next time.

All in all, it' a great place. Can't wait to try other things on the menu ... but "medium" spicy only :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
HAIR IN OUR FOOD.  TWICE.

the first time was months ago--ordered food for delivery, found a hair in the bottom of the sour soup.  i was reluctant to order from them again, even though i understand that such an occurrence might've been a fluke.

but yesterday, convincing myself to try angkor borei again, we ordered food for delivery again.  this time, there was another long, wavy black hair in the larb--at least this time, we discovered it before we'd eaten anything.

never again.  

it saddens me to write this (is it possible to give zero stars?), as i so want there to be a good southeast asian restaurant in bernal heights.  but frankly, finding HAIR in my food (not once, but TWICE) is unacceptable.  makes me wonder what, other than refusal to wear hairnets, is going on in that kitchen.
author: jeanie c.

description: Pumpkin curry was flavorful and nicely spiced. Service was friendly. Reasonably priced.
author: M J.

description: After eating here for lunch many times, finally made it to dinner. Had the blanket shrimp with a squid salad for appetizer, Prahok, Ahmok,
author: Darren K.

description: first time eating Cambodian! if you haven't had it before, think Thai, Burmese and Vietnamese type flavors. we got the crepe appetizer, the duck curry and the peppered pork ribs with a side of rice. everything was just what i would imagine for Cambodian. even the friendly woman dressed in customary garb (much like you'd see at thai restaurants). i'd definitely recommend this place to anybody who wants to check out something a little out of the norm. i couldn't bring myself to order the fish mousse thing that people get. i had something similar in thailand and texturally it was gross so i couldn't fathom paying USD for it. still, if you're game, give it a shot!
author: Regina C.

description: Angkor Borei must mean delicious in Cambodian. I visited this restaurant after seeing it reviewed on Check Please: Bay Area, and because of an upcoming trip to Cambodia. I found everything delicious. The mixture of flavors definitely enhanced one another. We had the the Spinach Leaves appetizer, it was tasty and a lot of fun filling the leaves with the mixture of items.   The Ahmohk and the Pumpkin Curry were recommended to us, and I can definitely see why. I especially enjoyed the Pumpkin Curry, which we ordered with Tofu. It was unbelievable. The service was friendly and timely.  We also tried two different Thai beers, which were rather nondescript. I highly recommend Angkor Borei and I will be back.
author: Ken E.

description: I thought this place was truly excellent -- er, outstanding -- yes even for San Francisco. I went for a birthday dinner. I didn't even look at the menu - we ordered family style. Every dish I tasted was delicious -- from the tofu pumpkin with tons of pumpkin, to the mixed seafood plate, to the crepe, it was all good. The atmosphere was cozy, clean, even slightly upscale. But the prices were real good. And they let us bring a birthday cake. I would venture to say that this is a perfect place for a bday.
author: Andrew K.

description: I had to review them today. I ordered food delivery from Angkor and I got it twenty minutes after I ordered it. And it was delicious. I don't know how they did that. I think they might be time travelers.
author: Sergi A.

description: Decided to try this restaurant as it came highly recommended on Yelp. We ordered the cold noodles and crepe to start, followed by grilled pork, shrimp curry claypot and chili chicken. The food and service were both great. My favorite was the grilled pork ribs and clay pot. It wasn't very crowded on a Tuesday night -  good place if you would like to have a conversation. The neighborhood may not be the fanciest and parking was not tough to find. Good find, will go back or order take out.
author: Seema H.

description: This eatery is located in the heart of San Francisco. The eatery is small, but family owned. The same family has run this excellent tasty eatery for more than the five years I've known about it. The prices are affordable. The food is authentic. The food comes with a real Asian taste. Come here if you want real Asian food with a attentive family that strives to please their customers just as if they too were family. Prices range from $4-$9.
author: Harley G.

description:
This probably isn't the best thing to say, but it's true.  The food here reminded me of Thai food, and if you served me both, side by side, with a blindfold, I wouldn't be able to tell you which was which.  

We wanted to try something different in the area and decided on Angkor Borei.  I never had Cambodian food before and I'm always up for a new adventure.  We ordered some sort of noodle dish, egg rolls and a shrimp dish.  All of it came out well prepared and tasty, but there wasn't anything that made it stand out to me as a place I would need to come back to.

The place was pretty busy when we left and the patrons there seemed to be having a good time and looked like they'd been there before.  Again, nothing against the food (it tasted good and was prepared well), but it just didn't wow me.  When you're located in a city where restaurants are closing down just as fast as they're opening up, it's important to stand out from the crowd.  They just didn't do it for me.
author: Alison N.

description:
I don't which is nicer the food or the staff but you will be very happy with both.

Spinach leaf appetizer - Yum
Chili Chicken - Yum, Yum

Good clean food, great prices and a friendly 'local' atmosphere. 

Cambodian and Thai food are fairly similar so you'll have to pick a few of the house specialties if you want something strictly Cambodian.
author: James H.

description:
Ahh....how I miss thee!  I haven't been here for a while.  I should go back...

I am so happy that my friends and I decided to try this place.  I have been there 3 times now within the past 2 years.  It's on the other side of SF where I live, so I do not go there as often as I would like.  This is the only Cambodian restaurant I know of in SF.  I love it!

I grew up with Southeast Asians and really really miss the good food, especially home cooking!  Maybe I have a "big head" (figuratively speaking), but I know my Cambodian, Vietnamese, Thai, and Laotian food.  Their food is good.
author: Linda C.

description:
We had an amazing dinner last night here. The ladies serving us were extremely friendly and the food was terrific. 

We opted for the vegetarian items, which were excellent. We started with the fresh spinach leaves and spring rolls. The spinach leaves were really interesting as we had to make them (similar to lettuce cups) and were very tasty. 

For main courses, we had the pumpkin curry (with real uncut pumpkin, incredible!), rice noodles with mock chicken and chili tofu. All were extremely flavorful and well presented. 

I highly recommend this place - it's rare when food and service come together so well. The area seems off-putting, but is completely fine, and it shouldn't deter anyone from coming to this gem.
author: S S.

description:
MY FAVORITE RESTAURANT IN THE WORLD.
I HAVE DREAMS ABOUT THE CLAY POT SHRIMP.

But really, this is such a great place. My parents dated here, and 20 years later, it's still our family's favorite restaurant. Great service, great food, great atmosphere-- just great all around.

I always start with the spinach leaf appetizer, which really is the best way to possibly start a meal. 
I ALWAYS order clay pot shrimp (#52, not 53... although that's pretty good too).
All the pan-fried fish dishes are delicious! My favorite is #51, but they are all worth trying.

The family that owns and runs this restaurant is so friendly and they really love their customers. On birthdays, they usually throw in a free dessert (coconut ice cream and fried banana slices... my favorite!).

Sometimes it's hard to find parking in the area, but you can usually find parking in the Bernal streets off Mission. 

I left for college this year, and I cannot wait to go home and visit this restaurant! If you haven't tried this place yet, you should really check it out because it is one of San Francisco's finest.
author: Kenny L.

description: Rude service. Hung up on me when I asked if they did delivery. Yelp is wrong. They don't deliver.
author: Mima G.

description: I usually get the pumpkin curry which is amazing. Today I tried the mock duck clay pot everything was excellent as always the service is exceptional.  It's nice to know that whenever I go to the restaurant anything I'll order will be delicious.
author: Mike G.

description:
Get:
-Pumpkin curry (comes in a pumpkin!!)
-Veg. Crepe
--Chili Mock Chicken
-Salads

Still much to explore.  Lovely food.  Extremely kind owners and staff.  Fast delivery.
author: Sophia R.

description: What a pleasant surprise!  Found this place on yelp and tried it for lunch.  Pretty empty, but very nice and clean, with super friendly staff.   We ordered the spicy hot and sour soup with shrimp - all the vegetables and shrimp were very fresh (I usually find shrimp in tom yum kung to be overcooked and this was delicious), and the soup was tasty.  We also had a huge dish of the Cambodian curried pineapple fried rice with tofu and chicken - loved it.  We also ordered the amok fish which was served with a mousse - different from the amok we'd had in Cambodia but I actually liked it better and the fish was very tender.  Overall just a really great lunch and definitely will come back.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Da bomb. 
Delicious Lemongrass ice tea and super friendly enviroment+staff+low lights.
If you're a vegetarian, try the spinach leaf appetizer and the pumpkin curry. If you're not, try it too. Yummy!
author: Elisa S.

description:
Ended up here when my guy needed to get back home early and Emmy's wasn't open at 4:30.  No biggie, since this place was stellar.

The "crispy crepe" was delicious (with an amazing sauce - so good, my boy was almost licking it out of the bowl).  The papaya salad was great (more savory than you'd think...)  And the best piece?  We got the pumpkin curry (a daily special) that was SO good!  The pumpkin had the texture of sweet potato, but was slightly spicy.  The curry itself was delicious.  And we basically got four meals out of $40.  Yummy.
author: Adam T.

description:
This is a great relatively inexpensive place if you want something different from your average San Francisco Asian food eatery. I'm not really sure what Cambodia food is really like in Cambodia but I'd certainly gain about ten pounds in about two weeks if I went to Cambodia and the food over there is as good as it is at Angkor Borei.

The place is kind of small and there isn't a ton of space to wait and I suspect you usually will have to on weekend night but it is cozy and warm, even by the door. The "specials" menu had a pumpkin curry on it which I suspect is a special every night of the week. It is delicious and worth getting. You could get that Sunday night for dinner and probably have leftovers for lunch for the next week and a half.  I also tried duck which I usually do not like but their's was tasty.

I can't wait to go back. One thing it is probably not good for groups bigger than 5 or 6.
author: Nina B.

description:
Seriously not impressed.

The Hot&Sour Soup was so thin and watery, it was inedible. Also ordered the Sauteed Seafood Combo, which was full of seafood , as advertised, but lacked flavor and had mussels that tasted way past their serve by date.
The Larb Salad was good, but the Sticky Rice was incredibly dry.
Very disappointing.
author: peggi j.

description:
Great, fun food.

Make sure you get the spinach leaves appetizer - had the vegetarian version, and it was delicious - you could taste every ingredient overwhelming another.  So good, so fresh.

The fried rice wasn't too fried, definitely not too greasy.  The noodles were OK (tasted kind-a like Pad Thai), and the mock chicken was some of the best I've had in SF.

Definitely plan to go back.
author: Liz G.

description:
It's Mission St that I never knew existed - the Bernal Heights end.  It's almost as gritty, not quite as charming or full of worst-kept culinary secrets as the part that belongs to the Mission District.  

This place also had the 'neighborhood gem' look going - barely there signage, insanely small yet cozy dining area, and hipster clientele.

And just like any other highly-rated places in Yelp that I did not find to be quite all that, I would give them the benefit of the doubt by saying to my dinner date, as I walk back to my car, "Maybe I just didn't order the right dishes."

The appetizers were unfortunately the best part of the meal:
1) Cambodian crispy spring roll - which tasted a lot like the Chinese one often found in dim sum cart served with a side of sweet red sauce.  This one came with what tasted like the Thai sweet chili sauce.
2) Make-your-own spinach leaves - very similar to make-your-own lettuce cups, only with more ingredients and spices (ginger, peanuts, red onion, chili, and coconut sprinkle) and sans meat (unless you count the dried shrimp)
3) Nhoam lahong papaya salad with carrot, tomatoes and mint - very similar to the tangy Thai papaya salad.  I was a fan.

The entree was a medley of (almost) Chinese dishes - sweet and sour chicken with pineapple, ginger beef with onions and celery, and stir-fried vegetables.  These dishes are familiar-sounding because you can find them in your neighborhood Chinese joint - so not exactly something that I would pop my Cambodian food cheery with.  

The dessert was batter-fried banana and ice-cream.  Also bearing uncanny resemblance with a typical Chinese restaurant dessert.
author: Ange L.

description:
What a rip for 7 dollars of appetizer and you absolutely eat nothing. 
Seriously, I mean NOTHING. It made me feel so mad that I spent 7 dollars on things like that. Totally wasting money. If I can give O star, I would.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I went here on a Thursday evening and the place was mostly empty so it was nice and quiet. They do alot of take out business it seems.

GOOD:
- The AHMOHK (#48) fish mousse in a banana leaf was excellent! The fish was fresh and flaky and complemented its sauce very well. I would definitely get this again.
- The PRAHOK (#33) ground pork in coconut milk and anchovy was pretty good too. It is basically a sort of dip and you dip pieces of vegetable (cucumber, eggplant, celery, etc) into it. I guess you could put it over rice too. 
- The couple that runs this place is very sweet and nice. The service was excellent and genuine and the place is cute and tidy.

JUST OK:
- The sour soup #12 was very average. It was on the tangy side but there was nothing really special about it. It was like a boring version of tom yum soup. I wouldn't order it again.

BAD:
- The place was freezing. I don't know if they were skimping on heat to save on the utility bill but it was definitely chilly inside.
- Portion size was on the smaller end. Me and my date got 1 big bowl of soup and 2 entrees and 1 rice and it came out to be the perfect amount. I didn't think we would finish everything but the entrees are on the small size.
- The entrees don't come with rice. They are like $1.50-$2.00 a bowl but in my opinion, entrees at Asian restaurants should come with a free bowl of rice.

CONCLUSION: If you are looking for a good Southeast Asian dining experience outside of Thai and Vietnamese, this is a great place to go. Ask them what are authentic Cambodian dishes and they will tell you.
author: Alex P.

description:
interesting place in the middle of a mexican area that had nice authentic cambodian decor. the pork,beef,shrimp salad was probably the best dish we had there, it was very tasty and unique. the fried fish fillet with noodles, baby corn, mushrooms was simple, tasty and fried really well. the pumpkin curry was fresh and cooked well but wasnt necessarily the best tasting curry that we've had.
overall, i think if you like your food simple and homey(home-cooked, not too much msg), i think this is a good place.
author: Alex H.

description: Tucked away by Bernal Heights, simple, good, clean flavors. I've tried many different dishes here, and my favorites are the spinach leaves appetizer and the pumpkin curry (usually listed in their specials). And they don't skimp on the rice! Love it :)
author: Mal C.

description: We came here because BFF wanted to reunite with her friends. I wasn't particularly hungry so I shared the Pan Fried Fish Fillet with Garlic Fish Sauce. It was okay, but not really my thing. Everyone seemed to enjoy their food though. The hostess was also attentive and very kind.
author: Janny W.

description:
Good food... will need to try it out again. 
We went here the other night and had #47 Sauteed Seafood Combos with the Chef's Hot Sauce and the Pumpkin Curry served with duck. We started out with Spicy Hot and Sour Soup with shrimp. I had a Thai Iced Tea as well. 

The soup was delicious. It was enough for each of us to have several bowls. You have to be careful when eating it though ... as it was served with lemon grass and sliced ginger with the skin on.. which I suppose you could eat.. but was a bit to tough to chew. In any case, it definitely enhanced the flavor of the soup but it wasn't apparent until you put it in your mouth that it wasn't truly edible. 

My dining companion and I were very impressed with the Sauteed Seafood Combo .. although it was not as spicy as we expected it would be. It was served in a bowl and had mussels, shrimp, calamari, and fish ... all cooked to perfection. This dish was definitely worth coming back for. 

The pumpkin curry was decent, but the duck seemed slightly overcooked and just didn't enhance the dish. The curry is served in a kabocha squash bowl and the curry was pretty good. I might try this on another occasion and see if it is better with a different meat. I was expecting to love this dish based on previous reviews.. but we left half of it uneaten. 

The restaurant serves white, jasmine, and brown rice. We ordered white and brown rice, unfortunately they ran out of brown rice before they served our meal. They informed us of this and asked if white rice would be fine. 

The service was OK. They were not very prompt in refilling the water glasses. There was a time or two where we needed to flag them in order to request some condiments. I am not quite sure whether we were there on an off night or whether the waitress was just new. 

Overall it had a friendly atmosphere and the food was good. I will definitely try them again sometime.
author: Cat C.

description:
My first time, and they were very gentle. Like Thai food, but more spare, so that the individual ingredients stand out more. They deliver, and we'll be calling again soon.
Oh yeah, and they serve the pumpkin curry over the pumpkin, or rather they send the curry separately and you pour it on yourself, ala bread bowl. Instead of like pumpkin chunks in the curry, or something obvious like that.
Outstanding.
author: Jonny A.

description:
This was my first time eating Cambodian food, and I have to say, I wasn't all that impressed. We ordered a bunch of the tofu dishes, and to be honest, they all tasted pretty much the same. My favorite had to be the vegetable curry and spring rolls, but really, I wouldn't write home about any of it. 

To their credit everything tasted clean and fresh, but just uniformly the same. Yeah, I know Thai Basil has a distinct taste, but that's all anything tasted like. So if you like Thai basil, this place is for you.
author: Allyson S.

description: Having never had Cambodian food before I came to this restaurant, I have no way of measuring how authentic it is. But all authenticity arguments aside, I can certainly say that I had a phenomenally delicious dinner here, arguably one of the best on my week-long stint in San Francisco. My partner ordered a pork curry with vegetables and loved it, while I had the green beans with tofu, peppers and spearmint. Damn, I still have dreams about this dish. The tofu, while not fried, was still flavorful, which is a hard thing to accomplish. Green beans were super fresh and crunchy, the spearmint was unexpected and very refreshing. The flavors mixed together were like any other cuisine I've tried before and after washing it all down with an iced lemongrass tea, I was one very happy camper.
author: Reagan T.

description:
Dinner here was a delicious foray into Cambodian, my first here in the City.  The interior is ruddy and welcoming.  The staff was delightful, very eager to offer recommendations and we quickly made friends with them (it didn't hurt that someone in our party spoke Cambodian). Now onto the good stuff!

Crispy tofu  -  Delicious!  Pungent with a slightly sticky sauce that compliments the texture of the tofu.
Beef salad - Tad spicy but surprising mix of flavors, hot/cold  soft/crispy. I appreciated the balance.
Cambodian crepe - Crepe was thick, nutty and soft. A bit hard to share.
Ahmok - Curry fish mousse, say whaa!?  Presentation is artful.  Taste not as hard-hitting as I would've liked but still really good. 
Sour beef soup - Recommended proudly by the waitress as being typical Cambodian.  Good coupled with rice

Other tidbits:

They were out of dessert (or rather, mango) when asked, but offered sticky rice + ice cream as an alternative.
Portion sizes are rather small in general.  5 dishes for 5 hearty eaters will not likely cut it, although it seemed ample initially.
Inconvenient location (for us Sunset-ers, at least).

The verdict?  It's great for treating your palate to something new, but it's a hard pick if value's your main concern.  I say, what the hay, you're worth it.
author: Manny P.

description:
YAY, I am a fan,  the staff is super friendly,   the food was good, the prices fair.  But can I be honest?  Having just come back from Cambodia, the menu had few truly Cambodian dishes.  It has a severe lean towards Thai and Chinese cuisine.  They do have Amok and Lahong.  And those dishes we had were delicious.  The Sour Soup is awesome.  

All that said though, the rest of the menu really was pretty standard asian fare.., cashew nut chicken, basil chicken, sweet and sour pork, etc etc.   The beer selection is also decidedly Thai and Chinese - the only Angkor they serve is Anchor steam.

I know what you are thinking, it's all very close to the same region, and that is true.   But I was looking for something to take me back to Cambodia and it just didn't completely deliver.  Cambodian cuisine is largely fusion of vietnamese, burmese and indian, and I felt like I was in a Thai restaurant with a couple Cambodian dishes available to sample.  I'd love to see the friendly owners and capable chef's take some risks here and and add a few more exciting options.  

I thought it was good but not amazing, It really deserves 3.5 stars, it just didn't blow me away.  I'd would give it a fourth star only because I am grateful that there is at least one Khmer restaurant in SF and I'd love for them to be successful.
author: Rick R.

description:
Excellent food at a bargain price. I had a duck curry, which was quite good. Not a huge amount of food, but definitely enough for one person (some of the dishes were larger).

Not a huge restaurant. We had a big party (with reservation), and we had to wait a little while because they seated people at our table.
author: Dana L.

description:
I remember the first time I went here...

I was with a group many years ago.  I do remember that the food was very flavorful, nicely spiced, and just yummy! and that the prices were also very nice.

The people that work here are super friendly and always very accommodating. They are very vegan friendly -- they have a large vegetarian section toward the back of the menu which I'm sure is mostly vegan. So if you're unsure about a dish having egg in it (because they rarely if at all have dairy in their food), just ask...
I don't remember what the dish is called exactly, but it had cashews and tofu in it... Whatever it's called, that sauce is amazing!!! Just pour some of that on top of some rice, and yum... Mmm-mmm good!

Apparently, this place has been here for quite a long time... And seeing as how it's always good, I'm sure it'll still be here for a long time.
author: Miss C.

description:
I really like this place.

The people that work there are suuuper sweet and attentive. 

Tasty food. I especially recommend the pumpkin curry (I've had it with tofu and chicken, both were tasty). Crispy tofu appetizer also delicious.

One thing - the 2 times I've had "mock chicken" there I was not a fan of it and I usually like fake meat. It seems like other reviewers liked it so maybe I'm alone, but my opinion for vegetarian food there would be to just get it with tofu and you'll be set with a tasty meal & your protein.
author: Carrie S.

description:
Dined here twice within three years and on both occasions the food and service have both been spot on! The food does not come close to mom's cooking, but it will have to do while I am away from home. Some of the dishes I have tried are the squid salad, sour soup, ahmohk and duck prik king. All of the dishes I have had are traditional, but the duck prik king is something I have not had in that form (traditionally cold preparation as a vegetable dip). Not bad though... 

They've been in business since 1987, have free delivery with in a two mile radius, and the menu is a greatest hits of Cambodian cuisine. Worth a try if you are a fan of food that is a somewhere in between Thai and Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Bophan C.

description:
I visited this place twice, first time was about 2 years ago with a Cambodian friend and I went again tonight.
The food is definitely tasty, and although the portions were on a small side by American standards, I can't really say I was hungry when I left.
We had Larb as a starter - delicious - and then Ahmok and Chili pork, both really good too.
Now, I usually don't write about the service and just focus on whether the food was good or not. Basically, I don't care if the waiter/waitress refills my glass once, twice, or zero times. However today was one of these weird experiences that was annoying enough to be mentioned in a review..
I had asked for a "fresh young coconut" (on the menu they had both fresh and bottled). I received a glass that tasted very much like bottled coconut water, and to make sure I asked the waitress "is that the fresh young coconut?". Her reply was "No, we didn't have it so this is bottled."
Errrr .. Maybe you might have wanted to mention that BEFORE bringing it?
And maybe you might have wanted to say something like "sorry" at some point.
And maybe, you might have wanted NOT to charge it, since I never asked for it (and didn't drink it, because I don't like it).
Pretty weird. I don't think I'll be back.
author: Sarah B.

description: This place isnt bad. It's Americanize Cambodian food and it's kinda pricy. It's nothing close to home made Cambodian food but since I'm far from home this will do. The service is great and the chefs are Cambodian so that's a huge plus. I give this place 3 stars.
author: Sotheara Y.

description: good food. must try the pumpkin curry w/chicken - huge portion.
author: Siva M.

description: 3.5 stars.  I came here to try 7x7's fish dish (ahmok).  It's kind of like a giant fish ball steamed in banana leaves with spices.  This was delicious.  We also shared some lettuce cup appetizers and a chicken curry.  My only complaint is that this place is slightly overpriced for the portion size/ambiance/neighborhood.  Expect to pay 1.5x what you would at a standard Thai restaurant for similar food.
author: T Y.

description:
The Vietnamese and Cambodians don't really get along. In fact, we kind of hate each other. Apart from a shared interest of kicking "whitey" out of our countries, there is a long history of animosity that has lasted for centuries. Simply put, they tried to kill us and we tried to kill them. Can't we all just GET ALONG??

Surprise, surprise...when I found out there was a Cambodian restaurant in Bernal Heights. I was all set to hate the food and then write a scathing Yelp review using words like 'Kampucheass' and 'Pol Potlicious'. It was to be my own form of political protest. Pathetic, eh? I am John T, not John Rambo.

Instead, I found this restaurant to be quite charming. The food itself is an interesting fusion of Chinese, Thai, and Vietnamese influences. The appetizers quite simply are amazing. The cambodian crepe and crispy spring rolls come highly recommended. 4 stars.

Note: I hope this review does not offend any Cambodians, Whiteys, or John Rambo.
author: John T.

description:
5 stars for the friendliest service I have received in a long time. They were all smiles and constantly thanking us every time they asked us how things were and we said "It's VERY good!"

"Thank You! Thank You! Thank You!" all the way from our table back to the kitchen. Such humble people!

4 stars for the food. This was the first time I had tried Cambodian cuisine, and it was delicious. The dishes were very similar to Thai and Vietnamese food. Our group of six was very open to the server's suggestions, so we basically left the ordering up to her. 

For starters, we had the fresh spinach leaves which was served on a plate with 7 small bowls, each filled with different items: ginger, peanuts, lime wedges, red onion, chili, dried shrimp, toasted coconut. We filled our leaves of spinach with each item, topped it off with the chef's special tamarind sauce and popped them into our mouths. The items were all very complementary and the sauce gave it an extra kick. We also ordered the squid salad, which was very spicy and very tasty. My favorite starter was the crispy Cambodian crepe, the crepe skin was very crisp and the shrimp, ground pork, tofu, and bean sprouts inside were delicious.

For entrees, we got the chili chicken curry, charbroiled pork slices, ahmohk (a curry fish mousse served in a banana leaf), and dried beancurd with sauteed vegetables. The ahmohk was very unique, and I enjoyed the different textures. However, I don't think it was the winner at our table. Our server had suggested it, saying it was one of their most popular dishes. If you're looking for a different dish, then you should try it. The dried beancurd was so yummy that we ordered another one after we polished off the first one. The chicken and pork were also quite good, and are good "safe" items to order. 

For dessert, we got an order of their fried banana with coconut ice cream and sticky mango rice. I was already stuffed from our meal that I could only manage to take a small bite out of both. The batter for the fried banana was a bit to heavy for my liking. The coconut ice cream was creamy and smooth. The mango rice was good, better than the one I've had at Osha Thai. 

Our bill arrived and it came out to $17 per person. What a great deal for so much food! Definitely a good place to have a family style dinner with a group of friends. Drive out to Bernal Heights - parking is fairly easy to find on Cortland - and try this small gem of a restaurant.
author: Connie C.

description: Everything I've had from here has been delicious. The location is odd but I guess that keeps the crowds away. I've never seen more than 4 other groups there. It can also get really frigid on cold nights, maybe they don't have heating? But the food is fabulous: both meat and veg dishes.
author: Greg N.

description:
I'm calling Angkor Borei a new favorite restaurant although I've eaten only one dinner which was delivered to me less than 15 minutes after I placed my order over the phone with a very patient man who accommodated my search -- which seemed to last several minutes -- for both the address and phone number of my temporary San Francisco housesitting residence. (I hadn't planned on delivery; the option was presented to me when I placed my order for "pick-up". I was startled into accepting the offer by the ease and comfort of its promise.)

Checking the address on the outside of the house would take some time: doorway guards and 4 week old kittens to step over; stairs to descend; keys to add to the list of things to find in order that I might unlock the security gate, etc., so I searched a bit more...creatively. (I finally obtained the phone # after searching my email inbox - thank god for the gmail search function.) And he waited. I apologized and offered to call back after retrieving the information but he didn't accept the offer. So while I cannot review the restaurant's table service I CAN award the restaurant five stars for its exceptional telephone service.  

(Rest assured, the house address and phone # now reside in my address book for quick reference when placing future phone orders, or in the case of burglary or fire.)

One additional note on the delivery service. After I placed the order I was told I could expect my food in 30-40 minutes. After hanging up I reconsidered my options and called back 7-8 minutes later asking that they hold my dinner for pick up - I would stop by the restaurant afterall, on the way back from a quick stop at the drug store. (Plus I wanted to take a peak at the restaurant's interior.) 

"He's just left with your food." 

Truly, and I feel bad for thinking this now, I thought he was full of it. Figured he didn't want to change the order or track down the driver. But sure enough the buzzer rang 4 minutes later. How'd they do it? One reviewer calls this disconcerting. It's not disconcerting; it's f**king amazing. No stars will be deducted here for excellent food delivered in excellent time!!

So on to that excellent food.

I ordered off of the menu posted on the their website. The vegetarian menu is listed at bottom, following the to-be-expected chicken, beef, seafood and pork items and the requisite soups and appetizers. Oh, and the fried noodles, fried rice, traditional Cambodian Noodles, "Over Rice", Vegetables and "Vegetables and Meat" items. And the asparagus (gets its own section) items. Just scroll down, all the way down -- but not past the bolded, highlighted notice that reads: RESTAURANT CLOSED JULY 1st- JULY 5th EVERY YEAR. Mark your calenders.

The vegetarian options are many. I chose the Crispy Crepe off the appetizer menu and the Clay Pot Mock Duck off of the a la carte menu.

I tend to avoid the mock meat dishes because I am not a fan of them, generally, and I'm not a vegetarian who wishes to forget, however badly and briefly, that she's not eating meat. But I went with the mock duck after reading the positive reviews here and also because it contains both protein (the *duck* is wheat gluten) and noodles and I usually think about that sort of thing. The spearmint as listed ingredient also swayed me. I ordered the dish mild (it was; I might have chosen medium) and the mushrooms were left out of the dish as I'd requested. I poured it over my order of brown rice (nice to have this option) and marvelled all the way through it...that is, allowed numerous gasps of delight to astonish nobody in the house but myself and the crew of cats under my watch. 

The vegetables in the clay pot dish were cooked to perfection and the coconut sauce was tops. Not too heavy. I might have considered pouring it over my shredded oats the following morning had I not polished it off in one sitting.

These dishes aren't bogged down in oils and are definitely more akin to Vietnamese than Thai. You FEEL less bogged down after eating this food. The taste is lighter than I expected but still so pleasing as there is no compromise in flavor. I felt positively healthy at the last bite, buoyant almost, although perhaps I should mention that I was sucking on a helium balloon in between bites.

Garlic, ginger and mint were present but there were other spices at work which I couldn't identify because 1) this was my first Cambodian meal and 2) I'm no master of what constitutes a Cambodian kitchen.

The crepe was crispy around the edges but had a softer spongier center. Inside the crepe the bean sprouts were wonderfully crisp and the vegetables and tofu mingled nicely while each ingredient announced its individual presence. I felt satisfied after consuming this dish alone. 

Also - big bonus: the leftovers tasted excellent for lunch two days later which is not often the case with similarly prepared foods.

I greatly look forward to dining in the next time.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I know I may be such a 5 star whore that no one will take my 5 stars seriously, but I'd really like to give credit when credit is due, even when it's something as simple as Spinach Leaves to tip the scales towards 5.

After a raucous start to the year I'm settling into the nice easy lazy days that some higher being is offering to me currently as an apology for a cruel January.   

I go to yoga, I nap in the middle of the day, I enable the quiet slacker evenings in.

Life is good.  

Life is better when you can't stop stuffing yourself silly with spinach leaves stuffed with hunks of ginger, lime, toasted coconut and peanuts (green peppers and red onions were avoided due to my body's ability to transform into a human beatbox upon consumption of such things).

Dipped in tamarind sauce.  Everything is better dipped in tamarind.

ps. veggie noodle soup w/ mock chicken A-, more cilantro please.  :)
author: Jen I.

description:
My husband and I went here for the first time the other day - we were prompted by all the great yelp reviews and that it is right down the street from us.

What a find and pleasantly surprised on how nice it is given the busyness of this part of mission.  The restaurant is dimly lit and cozy , clean and tastefully decorated, and interesting menu.  It was our first time having Cambodian food - similar to Thai which we love - thus we really enjoyed this food as well.

Although we did have to wait sometime before we got our appetizer and main courses, but when we did get our food it was hot, and delicious.  The waitress did apologize for the wait - not sure if this is typical or if it was just a busy night.  We will certainly go back - the wait will not deter us.

The crepe appetizer is unusual...flavorful.  Perfect for sharing.  We had the pumpkin Curry and Chile Beef - both were delicious.
author: Gina C.

description: I LOVE this place! Cambodian food is really a treat and I appreciate it to the fullest! This restaurant is decorated very beautifully too with lots of detail. Very friendly and welcoming service. I love the sour soup with pineapple, tomatoes, chicken/shrimp and greens and beef skewers. The ginger beef is one of my favorites with plenty of celery and thick sauce. It's distinctively different from Thai, and the menu is detailed, so it's Cambodian-virgin-friendly. It's reasonably priced too. I see myself becoming a usual at this place.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
*** Update 4/14/08 ***

I can't really tell the difference between Thai and Cambodian, but no matter--any place that dishes out earthy duck curries and succulent shrimp in clay pots is ok in my book.  Especially when served at dive-caliber prices in a decidedly non-divey atmosphere that's cozy yet elegant (with plenty of wood and dark red walls), with the kind of matronly service that only a family-run joint can offer.  Thai fans looking for a little something different will definitely want to give Angkor Borei a try.
author: Wes M.

description: Tucked away from the Mission Street Madness, almost at Cortland in the outer Mission, this place is a Gem!  Went for lunch on Monday with out of town friends that used to frequent here at least twice a month.  I've never had Cambodian food, but I'm always up for trying something new.  We shared the crepe with shrimp, the sour soup, and the crispy fish with bean thread noodle.  AMAZING!  The owner even recognized my friends, even though it's been awhile since they've eaten here.  As we were leaving, another patron who is a 'regular', started chatting with us and asked if this was our first time eating here.  We continued our conversation outside on the sidewalk, where she shared with us a lovely story about the owner finding her sister in Cambodia after many many years of thinking she was dead.  What an uplifting and heartwarming experience!  I will definitely be going back here and hope to try more Cambodian delights!!
author: Janice T.

description:
The proprietors here are so friendly, you will be rubbing your eyes, wondering if you woke up in Happyland.

My favorite is the fresh spinach leaves. ("Food that YOU make!") It is what it says: spinach leaves, but a bunch of little bowl-ettes with ginger, peanuts, lime, dried shrimp, coconut, some awesome dressing, and a few other things. It's like a food mashup! You can combine the things in different ways for each spinach leaf.

I got the baked prawns, which is served in the belly of a tinfoil duck. ("Look mommy, that tinfoil duck is having... prawn babies!") The smiley owner performs the, well, birth in front of you and lord above is it awesome.

As much as I die for Front Porch, every once in a while I remember to go save a few dollars and eat with these guys.
author: Blake E.

description: Extremely pleasant service with well prepared dishes.  All five of the dishes at dinner were delicious; and nicely presented. The pumpkin curry is served in a hollowed out pumpkin...nice presentation!
author: Lucky L.

description:
This was the first time I had Cambodian Food and it was good and bad...I went here for dinner.

Pro's: Nice little gem in the mission. Ambiance is nice and warm with brick color walls and mahagony interior it seems...Food was all about $8-$12.

THier Red Curry Fillet is AWESOME GOOD! and their COLD noodles is very tasty (I pour the whole sauce in there)

Cons: The food was small to OK portions. Everything was a la carte BUT the food portions are good for 2-3 ppl MAX...One appetizer will NOT be able to split btw 4 -5 ppl... Parking can be dificult and the bamboo shoots are way to spicy unless yo let them know ahead of time to make it mild.

Not all the food here is great...You really have to know what to order to get the full tasty experience....

Order: Red Curry FIsh, Cold Noodles and sticky rice dessert

DO NOT ORDER...the spicy bamboo shoots, the chicken with green beans and bell pepper or the shrimp in claypot with lemon grass....

That's all folks...

Goodnight
author: Q A.

description: Absolutely the finest dining experience. The couple who owns Angkor borei attend to every detail, from accomidating a table of 16 on a Saturday night with one day's notice to executing every course perfectly. The Spinach Leaf appetizer and coconut iced cream with fried bananas could be served at any restaurant in the city, and the fact the same folks are responsible for each course is amazing. I can't recommend Angkor Borei more highly.  Of course, as some posters noted, if you aren't a fan of Cambodian food you won't enjoy Angkor Borei, but it seems unreasonable to fault a Cambodian restaurant for serving Cambodian food...
author: Charles D.

description:
Five stars, damn it...

Excellent food, friendly service, and great value for your dollar...

I asked for spicy, and I didn't get some lame Americanized heat.  Thanks for serving up the real deal...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Their site is http://www.cambodiankitchen.com

The food was excellent!  My husband and I had 

* the Crispy Spring Rolls $6.65
* the Spicy Green Curry with Fish Fillet  $8.65???
* the Chili Chicken sauteed with fresh chili, mushrooms, green beans, onions and sweet basil-medium $8.65

I've included the site for their menu
http://www.cambodiankitchen.com/Menu.htm

When the dishes came, I thought they were skimpy initially, but my husband was full after having the spring rolls (I got one whole one and he got the other two) and Green Curry.  I was satisfied having a bit of the Green Curry and the Chili Chicken.

My husband thought they were pushing the envelope in terms of Asian food.  $1.50 per person for rice seemed like too much to him.  Also, for him, he thought he should be charged less given the portions since they weren't fancy exquisite dishes... just normal "home cooking" dishes.

Over all, the dishes were very clean and fresh.  The Green Curry was spicy enough to impress me, but not so spicy that I couldn't taste the food.  It was all very well balanced.  

The owners were very nice...I mean genuinely nice.  It wasn't a "Vaseline on the teeth act." 

My husband says he liked the food, but it isn't as if he's dying to go back to eat there next weekend.  He'd prefer to find the cookbook and make the food.

I think it would make a lovely place to catch up with old friends and colleagues.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I am really perplexed by the reviews proclaiming Angkor Borei to be the best restaurant they've ever eaten at, and even more puzzled by the numbers of people who recommended the spinach leaf appetizer.

The spinach leaf appetizer consisted of 8 or ten small spinach leaves with tiny bowls of condiments, peanuts, cut up lime pieces, spicy ginger, nothing that exciting and a small dish of sauce. Honestly, the lettuce wrap at Cheesecake Factory is so much better and is big enough for two people to share for dinner.

The Cambodian crepe was the most interesting dish, though it too, was sparse in the filling department.

The Chili Beef was spicy, but the sauce not that exciting.

The restaurant itself, is nicely appointed and the staff are delightfully pleasant. That would not be enough for me to return.
author: Carla B.

description:
This family owned Cambodian restaurant is one of the first places I ever visited in San Francisco. They serve authentic Khmer food and they are willing to accommodate any dietary restriction you might have (i.e. Gluten Free)  

They have a huge selection including Mock Duck and other substitutes for meat (for the Vegan and not for the Celiac-Gluten Free people)

I always go back to taste the flavors of Cambodia with my Khmer friends from the Bay Area!

Sticky Rice and Mango a MUST have!
author: Mr. T.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants EVER!

Some of the thrills. . . 
a beautiful inside tucked away near the corner of Mission and Cortland behind an unassuming storefront

a vegetarian menu!

delicious, complex flavors, rich but not too rich, delicate almost, not oily, each bite was worth savoring

delicious tea

clean, sparkling clean restaurant with decent prices and cloth napkins

and oh so kind and lovely owners. . . 

only con, not the best parking ever.

I can't wait to go there again!!
author: Abi W.

description: Wonderful and friendly service and delicious dishes. My fav was the spinach leaves starter, very tasty esp the coconut flakes. The fish mousse, charbroiled pork and tofu skin/beancurd with stirfry vegetables were my favorite. The FBI (fried banana ice-cream) was tasty but the batter was lacking something. The mango sticky rice was great as well. Overall a great dining experience.
author: Yan M.

description:
This is potentially a 4 star place, but I have to base my rating on my dinner last night. We'll see what the future holds!

We had:
- crispy crepe - very bland and not that crispy. will not order again.

- hot & sour soup w/fake chicken - the broth tasted really odd, but that could be bc we got it with fake chicken. it seemed that they made it to order, which was nice.

- cashew fake chicken - excellent! a flavor bonanza! I really enjoyed this dish and it was the only thing we actually finished

- mock duck clay pot - bc we wolfed down the cashew chicken, we didn't leave much room for the clay pot. But what we did eat was tasty and it will be our dinner tonight. Came out really (oven) hot, which I always appreciate. Man said it reminded him of a Thai curry, which hopefully isn't a bastardization of this meal.

A note to the spice phobic/loving - we ordered everything medium spicy and it was barely spicy at all. So if you like it spicy, kick it up a notch!

Also, corkage is $10 and the wait staff is some of the nicest anywhere.
author: Shal J.

description:
This was my second time at this restaurant and my third time sampling cambodian food.  It reminds me of Thai but for me, it's not as tasty.  Maybe its because I'm not used to it but everything to me was good but not great.  There are however a few things that I've never seen before.  We had a couple appetizers that were pretty unique.  The cold noodles and the crepe.  The fish mousse entree weirded me out but apparently its a local favorite.  The owner is superrrr sweet and she will help you decide what to try.  The place is clean and inviting and if you're up for some new cuisine, try it out. 

Tip:  Papaya salad was my favorite dish hands down.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
A Cambodian Delight!

Jon A...sorry, but they do serve Ahmohk!  
Maybe you just need to learn how to spell.
And, as far as prices...are you kidding me?

Lunch's cost $6.95, which includes a choice of 2 entree's (from the special lunch menu), soup, rice and a drink of your choice.

This place is fabulous!

Dinners are always more at any restaurant...you typically get more food.

The owner and chef, Chin Han is a gifted and artistic gem.
Nobody prepares food better than her.
So, if you have been there when she is not in, your food may not have been as good.


Sour Soup - made as you like.  The lemon grass and varied flavors are savory and delicious.  It comes with Tofu too if you like.

Spring Rolls - crunchy, mouth watering, bursts of flavor

#48 Ahmouk - tender chunks curried mousse fish served in a beautifully arranged banana basket.

Rice - White or Brown rice

#43 Sweet and Sour Prawns in the Shell - plenty for two.  Fresh veges, flavorful, delicious!

We went to dinner the other night and ordered the above, along with three glasses of wine. 

Total cost = $60

We eat there frequently and bring all our friends too.
Everyone loves it!

It is a litte cool in there...but the warm friendly staff and the wonderful food make up for the temperature inside.  
Just bring a comfortable coat during the colder days.

Enjoy!
author: J. W.

description:
The spinach leaf appetizer is amazing... A+

The rest of the food is pretty good or okay. 

This is a great neighborhood place at a great price
author: Susan Y.

description:
I am Cambodian and I was missing my parents home-cook Cambodian food, so I went to Angkor Borei with my friend, who is also Cambodian. We were greeting by a friendly lady. I like the decor---nice tables, art work, and lighting. We ordered the beef larb--it is the best I have had. We also got the chicken curry and beef sweet and sour stew. Both were excellent. Eating here hit the spot!

I have to say that my parents makes better sweet and sour stew, but theyre great chefs =)
author: Chatree T.

description:
Maybe we picked the wrong things, but surely not going back
Stuffed spinach leaves - the best thing we had. Simple. Yummy. The ingredients were in very small quantities & they charge 75c for any additional ingredient. 
Chicken Salad - Not bad. But the chicken was too dry
Shrimp Clay Pot (#53) - we imagined shrimp in a yummy sauce cooked in a clay pot. It was boiled shrimp in a very clear broth. Not what we expected & quite disappointing. Had to add hot sauce & eat the rice with hot sauce
Chilli Chicken - okay. Better than Shrimp Clay Pot. But could be sooo much better
author: Nilofer M.

description:
Angkor-Borei is going on my seekrit crush list. Sweet personality, great taste, unpretentious, and definitely one of those dependable types you can always count on. Being a newbie, I was graciously steered in the right direction when I asked for some true cambodian delicacies, and it was TOTALLY worth it! Dove right in to some Stewed ground pork (PRAHOK) in coconut milk with anchovy, served with fresh dipping veggies. I was sad when it was all gone.
