Couldn't help also asking for Clay Pot Shrimp with noodles 'n' veggies in a yellow curry sauce. Slurped it up and asked for more. Downed a Singha on the side, apparently Cambodian beers are off the menu for now.

Thanks Angkor-Borei, for being gentle and loving with me my first time.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Very comfortable family run restaurant that makes you feel like you're a guest in their home. The curry dishes are exceptional here. The Rice Noodles, #62, are better than Phad Thai, and #32 ground pork & shrimp sauteed w/eggplant & sweet basil. 
You will need your parking karma.
author: Arlene C.

description:
Yummy yummy.  

The friendliest service in town (usually served up by the owner herself).  I've been here several times and everything I've tried has been great.  The fish mousse is soemthing different and wonderful.  The spinach leaves appetizer is also very good (you fill the leaves with an assortment of goodies).  And save room for dessert.  Excellent sticky rice with mango and also great fried banna with coconut ice cream.
author: B D.

description: I visited twice.  I always like to get a 2nd vibe.  The food is reasonable and tastes great.  I just wished that it was real Cambodia food.  All the employees were Thai.  And the food tastes like real good Thai food.  I went with my Cambodian friend that justifies that there are only a couple of dishes that were "Khmer" and my international room mate from Thailand was having a full blown conversation with all the workers.  My Khmer friend said she came a couple years ago and it was real authentic Khmer taste...but now it tastes like Thai.  Just giving you all the heads up....it would be disappointing....just in case any of you go to Cambodia and the food doesn't taste like what Angkor Borei's.  Go figure?
author: Poppy M.

description:
Delicious. I love this place. They have a huge vegetarian selection for a non-vegetarian restaurant. Everything I've had is perfect. Well spiced, fresh, perfect balance between subtle and intense. 

I especially recommend:
sour soup- I never thought I would love pineapple in soup
the tofu appetizer- tangy, crispy, covered in fried basil and tangy sauce, even carnivores love it

The mock chicken clay pot was good too, but only if you are in the mood for rich curry. 

The portions are not huge- if they were this would be a 5-star, but the food is 5-star.
author: Nadya K.

description:
I came here last night with a couple of friends for dinner. I never had Cambodian food before last night, let alone vegetarian Cambodian dishes. That's right...my friends prefer to kill vegetables (poor leavies)...oh I meant eat vegetables...so I kindly obliged even though I've been known to be 200% carnivorous...and to be technically correct, I'm more like 228% (my chinese superstition in numerology tells me that's a good number) omnivorous. 

We weren't too hungry so we decided to order an appetizer and two entrees to share. We started out with their Crispy Crepe (Vegetarian version)...it's filled with bean sprouts, tofu, ground peanuts, and some other goodies mixed inside the crepe and it came with some sweet and slightly tangy dipping sauce and was very light and tasty. 

As for the entrees, we had Clay Pot Mock Duck with bean-thread noodles (aka silver noodles) with mixed vegetables in a tasty coconut-based sauce together with some "mock duck" made out of gluten (pretty sure it is gluten). I love the texture of the "mock duck" and the taste of the dish. It's really quite good judging strictly by the taste of the dish despite the fact that it doesn't really taste like real duck, though I wasn't really expecting it to be the case. I'm sure my vegetarian friends didn't mind. The other entree was Chili Mock Chicken sauteed with chili, mushrooms, onions, green beans and sweet basil (medium spicy) - very tasty! Both entrees went really well with steamed rice. 

On another note, service is great and the ambiance is nice and cozy decorated with beautiful Cambodian arts and crafts. 

All in all, a lovely vegetarian meal for a MEAT lover! Will definitely go back again for some meat and seafood dishes next time...oh and perhaps some veggies just to make it a more well-balanced diet. :D
author: Jen L.

description:
One of my local faves for delivery as of last week. I've lived in lower Bernal/Outer Noe for almost 6 years now, and just ordered take out a week ago. Cambodian food to go is THE way to go! 
We had the ginger chicken, the crepe, and some kind of glass noodle. All dishes were flavorful, with a balance of spices (not as peppery as Vietnamese, not as oily as Chinese can be, not as spicy as Thai). 
My favorite part is that I was quoted a 45 minute delivery time, and they were at my house in 20 minutes.
author: Jennifer C.

description: very cheap, very good, very nice people in the hood. lunch is super cheap and you get alot. Curries are nice and not too spicy, also love the papaya salads.
author: Jef C.

description: I came here with my pal for lunch during the week.  It wasn't my choice, it was his, so I was skeptical at first.  I got wide noodles with tofu and veggies.  He got spicy lamb.  We were both super happy and the total was around 23 dollars.  The service was great.  I also love their decor--one of the women who works there's daughters drew some people and they're framed in white frames.  Quality!  I would recommend it to anyone who hasn't tried Cambodian food.  It's also quiet inside, which I always appreciate!
author: Julia D.

description:
I can't say enough good things about Angkor Borei.  The food is wonderful--clean, crisp tastes.  The spicy dishes are actually spicy, with wonderful notes of fresh chillies and veggies.  The meat is cooked perfectly, and everything is well seasoned.  And as my cholesterol has been high (which I feel I should be constitutionally entitled not to worry about if I am younger than 30), I have been eating a lot of their fake chicken of late.  It is great--it is firm and tasty, a perfect meat replacement.  

I would be remiss if I didn't also mention the pumpkin curry, which is sublime!  Also, the service was efficient and friendly when we dined in.  Their delivery is also reliable and fast, and they are always easy to deal with on the phone.  They have been a stand-by for us on many a night when we are too tired to cook for ourselves.
author: Casey H.

description: Yes yes and yes - super delicious, friendly staff, reasonable.  Went with Yelp reco's on the food and were not disappointed.
author: Ash A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city by far. Inexpensive, very friendly and the food amazing.

All the dishes my husband and I have tried have been great but my personal taste favorites have been the vegetarian Cambodian crepe and green curry. And the Singha. 

Always loved Thai and Vietnamese but had never had Cambodian before we moved out here and were blown away. We're planning on visiting Cambodia this fall and can't wait just for the food alone.
author: Tracy K.

description:
Upon coming in, the decor was very nice. Perhaps a little too dark though. After sitting down, I did not expect prices to be this low for a place like that but it was made up by the portions as they were smaller, making it overall resonable.

Its Cambodian food, so its a good change of pace from your regular Thai food. It's somewhat authentic as they had the vegetable dip with fermented anchovies. 

I was hoping for somehing MORE authentic as I've been to some "HOLE in the WALLS" down south that were AWESOME. I ofcourse bring my Cambodian girlfriend with me! 

I'd recommend it if asked about it, but not exactly somewhere I'd RAVE about as I like to put a bit more weight on food than just the decor. 

Overall, I had a good time... not GGGRREEEEAAATTT but good
author: Kelvin Y.

description: I'd never had Cambodian food before I came here so I won't claim to be any sort of expert, but it's one of my new favorite types of food now. The pumpkin curry is fantastic. As is the crispy tofu. I've heard their Basil Eggplant dish is delicious as well. Go!
author: Roxy B.

description:
Don't know why I'm one of the few to post a two star for this place, but I'll continue with this review.  The ambiance and staff were great and friendly.  Parking was tough, but then again it always is in the City.  

This was the last place we ate during my family's SF trip.  It was my first time trying Cambodian food as well.  There was quite some disappointment from my end.  Particularly the after-effects of eating this food.  I have two words to say: monosodium glutumate.  Tons of it.  Had the worst headache after eating the food here.  The clay pot was a waste of money.  I was expecting more from that dish.  There wasn't that kick as well with most of the dishes.  The one bright spot of the dinner was the Pan Fried Fish Fillet.  That was delicious and i recommend it if you like sweet dishes.

Anyways, that's all i got to say about this place.  I might have to give this place another try, but most likely not.   I rather get some Thai, Vietnamese, or Indonesian food.  But that's just my opinion.

Hope you don't get a headache ya'll.
author: Edmund I.

description: I went there on a Monday night. Found the ambiance very nice, and since it was a week night it was pretty quiet. The staff was cordial and efficient. We tried the hot and sour vegetable soup, spicy prawns, ginger chicken and the black rice with mango. Of the 4 dishes we tried, only 1 was great - the ginger chicken. Spicy prawns were under seasoned. Soup was just okay. Dessert nothing to write home about. Not a bad experience but average food.
author: N C.

description:
I am generally a fan of southeast asian food and this was my first chance to try Cambodian food, so I was really, really excited and my 5 star rating might be biased.

BUT.

Awesome!  We asked the waitress to recommend dishes specific to Cambodian cuisine and we loved what we got.  It was a while back, so I can't fully remember, but I know you have to get the crepe.  Please - just get that crepe.

If I lived in the city, I would frequent this place.
author: Patrick B.

description:
This place was low-key enough that I wouldn't want to go take a date there, but for a quick take-out, it was an affordable, tasty option. 

The waitress had a mix-up and accidentally served my take-out order to the people who were dining there, but was apologetic and very kind so I can't really fault her for that.

UPDATE:
I've gone there twice since my take-out experience for sit down meals, and I now love this place. Affordable, tasty, really fresh food and friendly service. My fav dish was the Clay Pot Shrimp with lemongrass and basil which is super flavorful and the seasonal sauteed asparagus   and shrimp.
author: Shannon R.

description:
The service here is so lovely and the servers so sweet that I want to give Angkor Borei an excellent review, but after eating here four times over the past two years I am forced to surmise that the good is decidely average.  Nothing is distinctive or surprising, and I'm going to stop going back hoping for something better.

I'm going to give it 2 stars simply because there are so many better options for southeast asian in this city.
author: Nate B.

description:
This place is pretty awesome. Owner IS friendly!
I got the signature dish- pumkin curry- a large piece of pumkin was made into a bowl . chicken (or shrimp if you choose) asphargus, string beans and bellpeppers and curry flowed out of the edible pumpkin bowl!
SOOOOOO deliciouss

the lunch combination was normal- good soup, rice two choices of 9 will be served for 6.50!  ITs good for the deal!

yummmmmmmyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy
author: Lily T.

description: Satisfied all cravings for pumpkin curry!
author: Brian S.

description:
Let's get one thing straight from the get go, I'm not very familiar with Cambodian food.  I'm yellow on the outside, but white on the inside...sorta like a twinkie...or a banana....  I rely on yelp and my other more "culturally in-touch" friends to lead me to good restaurants that serve more than just modern american cuisine (yes, yes, I'm a disappointment, I KNOW!!! JUST TALK W/MY JAPANESE MOTHER ABOUT IT).  

So, I thought that I was being really cool and innovative when I decided to celebrate Chris' b-day at this place.  I had done all the research (actually my boyfriend did). I knew that everyone was on a budget, especially me, and that after missing his actual b-day dinner (which fell on the same day as the Janet Jackson concert...sorry, Chris), I had to make it up to him.   Well...

DARN IT...  HE HAD ALREADY BEEN THERE!!!!

Okay, so the bill was pretty harmless.  Here is what I remember of what we partook of:
Appetizers (shared family style)
Cambodian Crepe
Crispy Spring Rolls
Fresh Spinach Leaves
Beef Kebab

Main Dish... (4 more main dishes)
Ahmohk
.....

and I can't remember what else we got...but it was a lot of food for 5 people, which  about $113.00 w/tax.  

The food was decent, but I don't think that there was anything really amazing.  It is a good value and the staff were very nice and were trying to be helpful with suggestions.

Parking in the area is hit or miss.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I used to eat here regularly when they first opened in the late 80s. Maybe it is just nostalgia, but the food was much better then than it is now.

We ordered the pork noodles and grilled chicken for lunch. The noodles were dry (little or no liquid) and rather bland. They were served with small bits of pork, some plain shaved cabbage and a bit of ground peanut. They lacked the interesting and complex (sweet, spicy, savory) flavor that I was expecting.  The grilled chicken was served with a small undressed green salad, with white rice and a dollop of sweet, spicy sauce. Both dishes were very plain, were relatively small portions, and lacked good flavor. 

The service was fast and friendly, but the the food sadly, and therefore the overall experience, was a disappointment...
author: Pete Z.

description:
In high school, one of my best friends was Cambodian. Her mom was a great cook. After school, she offered me some squid salad, and I never forgot that day.

Years later, while reminiscing, I yelped for a Cambodian restaurant, and found this one. Set out on a mission to the Mission to relive that after-school afternoon. We arrived at an odd time, and had to wait 30mins for dinner service. Hungry and determined, I patiently waited at a cafe across the street. 

When we got in, the place was quiet, clean and cozy. The server was sweet. We ordered the squid salad, cashew chicken, and baked prawns. Tender, pungent, salty, spicy, fresh..the squid salad took my taste buds back in time. Cashew chicken was tasty, and the prawns came out in a foil swan. Nice touch.

Would definitely recommend this resto for couples, or good friends that want to hideaway for flavorful food and intimate conversation.
author: Darlene S.

description:
2 thumbs way up! 

my first experience eating cambodian and i LOVED it. 

i came here last week for a friend's bday celebration and they accomodated a group of 14 of us. 

i wanted to order something unique so i decided to order from the specials menu- pumpkin chicken curry. my dish basically consisted of 1/2 of a pumpkin with a spicy chicken curry served inside of it. i love spicy food so this was heaven. the pumpkin was delish as well. i basically would scoop some out and eat along w/ the rice. Y-U-M-M-Y.

service was great but the timing of the dishes were off... i guess when having a party of 14 you can't please everyone! i'm definitely letting that small detail go though b/c i plan on coming back :-)
author: Rosy P.

description:
This place was recommended to us from a friend who's girlfriend is Cambodian.  The menu was had a nice variety of proteins and veggie friendly too.
My group tried a few items: fried rice, chicken curry, a beef dish, a noodle dish, and a skewer for our appetizer.
Drinks: Tiger beer!  
First time having Cambodian in a restaurant...and it reminds me very much of my own foods growing up.  It's a good place for an intimate crowd.  Service was quick and friendly and very attentive.  Please try it!
author: felix c.

description:
UGHs. this is the second time that i tried this place in the past 6 months and i am not impressed at all. i vaguely remember coming here about  4 years ago and enjoying the food, but that was a while ago. 

one star: edible enough, but you're eating it just because you have to pay for it. 

two stars: service is friendly but slow. the waitress filled our water glasses at the beginning of the meal, and it took a half hour to notice our empty glasses at the edge of the table. 

first time, we had the sour soup which i actually enjoy. the cambodian crepe is also good, but nothing like what my mom makes. the worst was the sauteed pork which was mostly bell peppers and onions. 

second time, again the sour soup because i craved it that night for some reason. had the ground pork stew which came with raw vegetables (raw eggplant on the platter? what??) we also had the pan friend fish fillet with bean thread noodle. the fish was bland and there wasn't enough sauce to give the fish any flavor. $40.00 for the meal including tax and tip. 

overall, i was disappointed both times, not WOWed. i really want to like this place and i feel that i may be ordering the wrong dishes. but really, trying 5 different dishes and not really liking of them says a whole lot. oh we were the only asian people in the restaurant both times we went, do you think that says something?

i don't think i'll be coming back here again.
author: Jean L.

description: Still SO good!  The pumpkin curry is the bomb! ! ! !  also, the spicy soup is delicious! mango w black sticky rice for dessert! ! ! also recommended is the spinach leave appetizer- very romantic and stimulating to the taste buds.  we are so blessed to have this restaurant in our barrio!
author: Tara R.

description: There's one dish where there are beef skewers sticking out of pineapple like a porcupine. It looks cool, but ultimately the meat quality isn't that great.
author: Kathleen M.

description: My first cambodian food experience.... amazingly good but it loses 1 star for service.... The waiter was too busy serving bigger tables and I was thirsty whole time.
author: Nick C.

description:
We started with the ground pork and rice chips appetizer. It was tasty, but a bit of a one-note wonder: coconut-sweet and not very complex. Still, it was undeniably tasty and fun to eat. 

My husband had the mixed seafood platter for his entree -- not terribly interesting in flavor, not very high-quality seafood, but plenty of mussels, squid, and shrimp. My entree, the beef curry, was very much like a traditional Thai massaman curry: Chunks of tender stewed beef in a coconut-based sauce with peanuts. It was good, but a little too much like the sauce of the appetizer in taste and consistency. I wish I would have known that when I ordered.

Service was a big issue. There only appeared to be one waitress (possibly the owner of the place) handling all the tables -and- all delivery  and to-go orders. It took a long time for her to take our order -- she apologized profusely and explained they just had too many to-go orders. Our food came out in about the time I'd expect, but our second round of beers never appeared. When she brought the check, she realized what had happened, and apologized again. There were a lot of cranky people in the room by this point, and the phone was ringing off the hook. As a result, we tried to be as nice to her as possible, and I left a nice tip. 

This was our first visit, so perhaps this was a one-off experience. Maybe someone called in sick, maybe they got a positive mention somewhere recently... I dunno. But the whole atmosphere was really, really awkward.

The food was good overall -- sort of like Thai with a few unexpected twists and not as much chile. We'll probably go back and see whether we caught them on a bad night, but the food wasn't worth the hassle if this is par for the course. I feel bad downgrading them for service problems -- especially because they're so sweet -- but ultimately this really dragged down the meal. If the service is better on our next visit, I'll revise this review accordingly
author: anita c.

description:
The to try list is always growing longer, even as I tick off places I've been meaning to try for years. That's not a complaint though, merely an observation. Angkor-Borei has been holding steady on the list for roughly 3 years. Cambodian cuisine is something I hadn't really investigated yet, so I was curious. As one would expect, close proximity to  Laos, Thailand, and Vietnam has produced dishes and ingredients that are familiar, but still different enough to constitute further investigation.

Did I mention the delivery option? That's what finally got me to sample A-B's wares, wanting someone to bring me something to eat.

I was helping the manfriend pack his belongings when we decided delivery was a must for the evening. The new owners at Rasoi aren't sure about delivery yet, so I pushed for A-B. We ordered red chicken curry ($8.50), chili beef ($8.25), and some steamed rice, dishes specified as spicy.  I'm intrigued by the curried fish mousse and some of the app.s, but I was looking for stuff that would travel well.

Coconut milk added the yummy richness to the curry that I love, however, it was a thinner consistancy than most Thai curries. The curry brought home some points for having chicken that was not at all dry despite its whiteness and for it's still crisp veggies. Well executed, somewhat spicy, nice flavors.

Chili beef was a stir-fry type dish with assorted veggies, basil, and chilies. This dish was also prepared with care, as all ingredients were presented with appropriate textures and a nice level of heat. 

Delivery time was a little bit quicker than originally quoted. A soild option for the hood and I'm looking forward to checking out the fish mousse.
author: Candice L.

description:
Angkor Borei was my first Cambodian Restaurant.  
Considering I haven't had much Khmer food before, I coudln't tell you if it was authentic or not.  I can only say that I thoroughly enjoyed their barbequed chicken and stir fried veggies.  Fresh!  As for the other stuff on the menu, it seems like seasoning with variations on what kind of meat you'd like.  

Anyway, lovely girl waitress; very mild and friendly; inviting.
PS - Yay for tamarind candy at the end.  Wish I coulda tried some kind of dessert...
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Being an Oakland transplant, I really found myself trying to find that place that could supplant those hankerings I often get for Phnom Penh (if you're in downtown Oakland give this place a try). 

I would have to say that I'm still on that journy. 

I've only had Angkor Borei delivery. The food was decent and the pricing a little higher than I would've liked, but getting this kind of food brought to your door is one of the great things about living in the city.

I'd return to them for another weekday night delivery but it's not the place I'd necessarily do on a regular basis.
author: Pete C.

description:
I walked by the other day and realized I hadn't been in a long while -- they repainted and changed the decor a bit.  I need to get back!

Angkor Borei is an amazing restaurant.  Great good, great people, very vegetarian-friendly, good prices.  Get the spinach leaves, ahmohk, curries -- everything is delicious.  For the more adventurous, there's a pork dish (stewed ground pork - prahok) that is kind of a vegetable dip and is excellent and unusual.  They're very consistent; I've been over 30 times, and it's always good.  It's one of my favorite places in the city, and if it weren't for the hassle of getting to Bernal, I'd still be there at least once a month.
author: Leo C.

description:
Really good food, sweet people, kid-friendly.  

NOT WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE. I mean, one could conceivably get into the place with someone holding the door, but it's tightly packed with tables, a pillar, and very little room to maneuver, and the bathroom is up two steps through a very narrow door with no handrail on the steps. 

Someone on crutches or a cane could probably hack it, but even a light and maneuverable wheelchair would have you frustrated and mad in no time. 

Not harshing on the owners; the restaurant clearly opened before the new accessibility requirements were put into the code. Just a heads-up, because the above business info says that this place is wheelchair accessible, which it isn't.
author: Jamey M.

description:
Went here last night for dinner with my boyyyy, Kevin. I will preface the review with saying that my boyfriend just got back from Cambodia and had amazing meals out there. 

The place is really mellow. Good place for a date, not so much for a party unless you plan on bringing the ambiance/entertainment. 

The food was average. Ordered crispy spring rolls which I enjoyed but not sure if its the most authentic Cambodia appetizer. 

I ordered the red chicken curry, which I enjoyed. Kevin ordered the mock beef something which I did not like, but he did. 

Staff was very nice and friendly, food was average, price was cheap, ambiance was extremely mellow (which was fine).

I MIGHT go again to try completely different dishes, but that's about it. To me it seemed like a more healthy Chinese Restaurant.
author: Art A.

description:
As someone who is Khmer, I must say that Angkor Borei is a pretty good representation of what traditional Cambodian food is like.  That being said, I only gave it four stars because nothing ever beats the food your family makes at home unless you head out to the Motherland.  I'm not sure what kind of restaurants Manny stumbled upon, but my experience in Cambodia was nothing like that in regards to the food.  

Just had dinner there today and it totally hit the spot.  My boyfriend and I ordered four dishes between the two of us: pan fried fish w/ garlic fish sauce, chilli chicken, ahmok, and a beef stew (which I know the name of in Khmer but can't recall what it is on the menu).  The ahmok is to die for.  Even in Cambodia, it's hard to find something this good and it's definitely a traditional dish.  It's basically steamed fish prepared in a banana leaf with coconut milk.  The pan fried fish was also really good, but I must say that their "spicy" is not really spicy at all.  

If you don't have any Cambodian friends who will invite you over for a home cooked meal, then this place is definitely the next best thing.
author: Mira C.

description:
Thanks to the Yelp folks for pointing out this gem.  Wandered in here at 9:30 one night and even though the place was about to close the servers were very nice and attentive.  The real story, though, is the food.  Granted, I may not know what Cambodian food is supposed to taste like, but the food here was just plain good.  The bf and I ordered the spicy green curry with barbequed rabbit and the pan fried fish with bean noodles.  Both were really tasty, fresh, and had just the right amount of heat.  I'd definitely go back or try the delivery service.

Update: Now that I'm in LA I so miss this place.  The last few times that I dined here or ordered their food (try their delivery -- it's super fast) I received the same happy service, and enjoyed delish food.  As my friend put it, their food makes the mouth happy.
author: Helen C.

description:
This place sucks, if your used to real cambodian food, do not go here. .   

Its overpriced and some of the dishes, i ordered were thai dishes. This restaraunt is not an accurate representation of Khmer food at all.
author: Rod S.

description:
Angkor Borei is a decent place to go for southeast Asian cuisine.  My primary gripes were:

1. Lack of the most common Cambodian dishes I encountered while traveling there (Lak Lok, Amok, etc.)

2. Not a great value for the money - it's on the pricier side of this kind of restaurant (about $9 per entree) and the serving size was relatively small.

The atmosphere was friendly and it appears to be owner operated.  The service was good.
author: Jon A.

description:
I've been here three times now. The food is excellent and the staff is friendly and attentive.

So far I've had:
The Cambodian Crepe - very good. 

The Crispy Rice noodles - really interesting. Clumps of crunchy dry rice, I think it's fried, with lettuce leaves and this amazing shrimp, pork tamarind dip/sauce.

The Squid salad - excellent.

Ahmohk - If you have never had this you gotta try it. Excellent I guess it's the national dish of Cambodia.

The lemon grass tea goes great with everything.

The Thai beer is good. 

And the black stick rice with mango is warm, gooey, and delicious.
author: Brian D.

description: For those who think Cambodian food is spicy and boldly flavored like Thai or Vietnamese, it's not.  It is milder and nuanced yet piquant, utilizing a lot less chili and a lot of coconut milk in a wide range of curries and noodle dishes, fish and fresh vegetables, as well as the ubiquitous prahok which is the uniquely Cambodian fermented anchovy paste.  My trip to Cambodia in 2005 opened me up to a whole new cuisine that I've quickly come to love.  First and foremost, the vibe at Angkor Borei brought me back to Cambodia from the decor to the incredible friendliness of the owner and staff.  However it was the food that takes center stage and brought back fond memories.  For a taste of something authentically Cambodian try the Stewed Ground Pork in coconut milk with spices and a touch of prahok, served with raw vegetables to dip into the stew.  Very good!  The owner recommended the Squid Salad.  Again not as spicy as the Thai version but damn tasty.  Also go for the Ahmohk, a mild curry fish mousse with prahok served in a banana leaf basket.  Another winner!  The service is wonderful and the owner is this very sweet and friendly woman with an infectious smile.  It was a great experience and I will definitely come back!
author: P.J. D.

description:
Hm mm! 
Wow! What a gem! 
It's quite rare for me to make my way to far up Mission but last night we finally made it there. The restaurant is pretty without being overdone. I appreciate the attention to details on each table. 
A love the mix of sweet & savory. The Pineapple shrimp curry was delicious. The stuffed crepe is simply amazing. Simple but so flavorful. My favorite is the pan fried fish with clear noodle & vegetable on top. The rice is perfect. 
It seemed to me this is a family business. Service was great and friendly. 
To top it all off... it's is so affordable.
author: William D.

description:
This review is for one dish only -- the divine amhok -- I've long wondered why this city hasn't paid its due respect to the brilliance of this dish. Finally this year 7x7 included it in its 100 best dishes to try. I can't bring myself to order anything else on this menu (although the crepe appetizer and the pumpkin curry are both excellent). But the amhok is the dish that I dream about when I am back home and away from the bay area. The fish is perfectly steamed and the banana leaf imparts just the right amount of earthy sensuousness. It's reminiscent of the Parsi "patra ni machi" albeit with different flavors. But the banana leaf adds so much -- it reminds me of the smell of the earth just after a summer downpour. The basil, vinegar, and curry spices just add to the depth of flavors. Paired with some fresh coconut water (which, unfortunately, they run out of very often -- what's up with that??!), this could be my last supper and I would die with a perfectly contented soul (and belly). I bow down to your culinary brilliance -- thank you, amhok, for adding beauty to a cruel world. 
note -- they make this to order, so it will take a good 15-20 minutes. But boy is the wait worth it. Order it with a side of rice.
author: Crushed Wi Cardamom C.

description:
As for delivery, they rate top on my list.

They are never hurried or dismissive when they take your order, always on time, and the food is consistently delish!

Our faves are the squid salad (no chewy, plasticky squids here), the tofu and asparagus in red curry, and the "special" fish in garlic sauce. Whenever I ask, "What's especially good today?" They always say the fish in garlic sauce. So since the first time, it's never been a surprise. Still it's always yummy.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Cambodian cuisine isn't as common as other Southeast Asian food (Thai, Malay, Vietnamese), but its definitely just as tasty. I think its the hidden gem of the area's cuisine.

Flavors here reflected the food I had in Cambodia (except at10x the price). I had the Ahmohk, which is like a fish curry thing. It tasted great and the presentation was wonderful, but the portions were a bit small for me (or maybe I'm just an overeating fatty). 

One guy that worked there was very attentive (like leave me alone and let me eat kind of attentive), but it was all genuine.

I'd come back to try more for sure, maybe to try one of their lunch specials. Give it a try, you might be converted from the every popular Thai to this lesser known (but just as delicious) cuisine.
author: Rocky K.

description:
Ordered delivery from here last night.  If you look at the yelp reviews on this place, the vast majority are from people who ate the mock meat dishes.  Having gotten food poisoning from a different restaurant that serves mock meat, I've tried to stay clear of it. 

I ordered the Ahmohk - and yes, it's really as good as everyone says.
Had the cashew chicken and it was hella DRY. 
Also ordered the papaya salad and I have to say Suriya makes a much better version of this.  

All in all it's one of the better delivery options but I was hoping for more considering how die-hard some of the reviews sounded.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
The spinach leaves appetizer was ordinary, but the crepe app was good. The red curry, tofu dish were boring, but the mock chicken dish was okay. Nothing was spicy enough. The door says "bathrooms" but there's only one. Also, $3.50 for a 12 ounce bottle of beer certainly seems steep.

Nothing wrong with it, but certainly nothing special. I wouldn't go back.
author: Adam Z.

description: I love this place.  As a cambo girl, I appreciate the authenticity.  At the same time, the food can still appeal to a foreigner's palate.  Trust me, it'll be different but GOOD.  I love that it's a mom and pop shop because it makes the dining experience more personal and intimate.  The service is so friendly and warm and they are always open to make a suggestion.  I think my fave dish is the crispy rice chips but really, everything is delicious.  Glad that the only cambo restaurant in SF is a great one :)
author: Karen N.

description: This review is long past due. Usually walk up to this cozy place for an incredibly unique dinner, but last night got delivery because it was raining and nasty outside. Cambodian food tastes like a cross between Thai and Vietnamese, and it's no wonder since the country is situated between the two countries. Personal faves include the pork larb, eggplant and tofu saute, fresh Spinach leaves- finger food that you make by filling bite sized leaves with ginger, peanuts, lime wedges, red onion, chili, dried shrimp, toasted coconut and the chef's sauce, squid salad, and butternut squash curry (a whole squash hollowed out with coconut milk curry). Love this place. People are so friendly and a great value with fresh and unusual food to boot!
author: Amy L.

description: In trolling for what to order in on a cozy evening in, I found this place.  I'd never had Cambodian food before, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect.  I asked the woman who was taking my order what appetizer she would recommend.  She recommended the fresh spinach leaves.  Wow.  I would have never thought to put fresh ginger, toasted coconuts and dried shrimp in spinach leaves.  Yum.  For entrees, I ordered the chili shrimp.  How can you go wrong with good shrimp, basil, mushrooms and onions?  Lastly, my order was delivered within a half hour of my placing it.  I'll definitely order from here again.
author: Jen D.

description: Having tried everything from Burmese to Indonesian in my years in SF, I finally got around to trying Cambodian. I ordered the blanket shrimp and the ginger pork with jasmine rice. I can't really rate it very highly. The pork was almost dry and the shrimp, while crispy, weren't exceptional. Service was slow, especially for a midweek night, early. Nothing I'd rush back to.
author: Alex N.

description:
Spinach leaf appetizer was fantastic.
We had some type of glass noodle dish which was cooked to perfection.
Great neighborhood place!
author: Pug P.

description: Pumpkin Curry is where it's at. Oh yeah! It's even served in a pumpkin shell, well okay they cheated there, it was some other kind of squash, but you get the idea. Gourdeous. Brown rice, check. Whatever soup my friend had was good. And uh, the fish dish we got was also good, sorry don't remember which one. Thumbs up.
author: Ken L.

description:
We're from Bernal - and have been going to this restaurant for about 6 years.  The food is consistantly excellent.  We're waiting for someone to take it to "check please" on KQED..The owners wait on you so they always have great suggestions re - daily specials and/or vegetarian suggestions.  The food is fresh and spicy - delicate and delicious.
The ambiance is warm and pleasantly authentic
author: jaime r.

description: Try the pumpkin curry and marinated beefs kabobs. Delicious!
author: James C.

description:
The soup here (#12 i believe, the first on their soup list after the appetizers, I got mind with chicken) was fantastic.  The flavor was very warming and sophisticated and the quality of the ingredients seemed very high.  The waitress was also very kind and welcoming.

So why only 3 stars?  The price was quite high.  While I wanted to try this place out and really enjoyed the experience, I will probably never return because I can't pay $10 for a soup.

When you lower your price, I (and many others) will be coming by all the time.


Also, a side-comment, I think the $20 minimum for using a credit card is rather high.
author: john s.

description:
I was craving Cambodian food since I had it earlier in the week, but was left somewhat unsatisfied by Kampuchea. 

We ordered the crepe appetizer and two dishes the waitress recommended - the clay pot and a tofu/asparagus + brocolli veggie dish. I don't really know Cambodian, but what we ordered, I liked. The only down side was that we ordered our food spicy, but came out mild. A little chilli powder helped that area out.

Also ordered the mango and black sticky rice... yummy! The mango was super ripe, which was a good way to top off a tasty dinner.
author: R H.

description: It was....ok.  This place has been in business for over 25 years and it looks very well kept and extremely clean.  This was my first time trying Cambodian food so maybe I'm not used to the taste yet?  Very similar to thai cuisine but I like thai much better.  Could just be my preference.  Plus, the lady was suuuuuuuper nice but she kept us in conversation for the majority of our meal since we were the only patrons in the restaurant.  I would say 3 stars for the actual food and 4.5 for ambience and service.  I'd come back...but only if someone else suggested it.
author: Emily L.

description:
One of our favourites. Parking not bad and worth it. Charming and somewhat quiet. Inexplicably uncrowded. It is one of our celebration/date night spots.

Recently updated decor elegant. Mom and Pop very charming. 

Every dish is delicious. Love the fish mousse  (not a mousse texture had chunks of tasty fish wrapped in banana leaf). All the fish dishes are excellent. 

Papaya salad nice. Spinach leaf appetizer a must-have. 

Sticky black rice, mango sesame seed a nice finish. 

Love it, love it, love it.
author: Soul M.

description: This is delicious food. I forgot the name of the dish but the spicy shrimp with bamboo is awesome. The staff is always friendly when you come and it's a great spot and their delivery is convenient too.
author: Ben L.

description: Came to this place on the weekend of New Years. I wanted to try something new, and Cambodian food was an option. Like many restaurants in San Francisco, this place was a whole in the wall. It was a decent place, just a little too dark inside for me. To start off I ordered the spicy hot and sour soup followed by some pad thai noddles and a dish of B.B.Q. chicken. I was expecting everything to be so delicious as I was told by couple of friends and family members that have been there plenty of times. Hmm.. well not exactly.. The noodles were great but the soup and the B.B.Q chicken not so great.  My friends and family were very surprised that it did not taste as usual.  I was a bit disapointed, not only they rushed to take our order they also kept dimming the lights from high to low about every ten minutes. That just gave us a clue to hurry up on eating and leave asap! RUDE! The waiter actually came too many times and that was annoying.  I dont know if I would like to visit this place again when Im in town.  Theres plenty of other restaurants in the city to enjoy, Im sure.
author: Lulu G.

description: Stopped by early Saturday evening after visiting the California Academy of Arts. My wife wanted to eat Cambodian food so we searched Yelp. I was surprised it was not the restaurant that she would usually tell me was good when she was a kid. The place was nice and the service was good. But the rice seemed like it was a day old soggy. We had the Americanized food. The table next looked like they ordered more authentic food. Which looked better. My wife thought the food was good. She would know, since she is Cambodian. I could not get over the rice. I think Chez Sovan is better. No need to drive to the city. Maybe Oakland would be worth the trip.
author: Bill M.

description: Angkor Borei has been a fave of mine for many years now, and I've never been disappointed.  If you don't love their crispy Cambodian crepe, there is definitely something wrong with your taste buds.
author: Julie T.

description:
See C.L.'s review below because we ate here together.  I really liked the perfect level of spice in the dishes and the nice service.  I've had Cambodian before in Oakland and in Cambodia, but nothing really memorable.  Well, to be fair, in my first visit to Cambodia, I got really sick so I couldn't really remember , and in my second visit, I was in a tour bus with Thai people and we ate at a THAI restaurant and buffet places in Siem Reap!  Sad, yeah.  It was a free trip for me though.

So, anyway, finding parking near Angkor Borei sucks.  I'll be here next time, but I'll take the 49.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description:
So you show up, you've already had a couple of beers and you're waiting to be seated.  Now would be a perfect time to use the restroom, right? You walk through a door and suddenly you get the feeling that you're in the wrong place, but you're not.  You keep walking, take a huge step up, and you're there.  You use the huge industrial lock to make sure nobody barges in on you, and you feel pretty good.

The curry mock duck made me feel good, too.
author: steve m.

description: Delicious! This is the best option in the neighborhood if you like Thai food. The vegetarian crispy crepe was my favourite! It's cheap too!
author: David E.

description: I love this place and keep going back for more.  Their dishes are full of veggies and fresh ingredients with yummy spice combos that are a cross between Thai and Vietnamese flavors.  Strongly suggest.
author: Melissa C.

description:
When I read about Angkor Borei's "mock chicken" in the Chronicle's 96 Hours I knew I had to prioritize going there. Don't get me wrong, I love chicken, but I also love restaurants that offer veggie alternatives, especially cambodian-themed ones in bernal heights. I was on 14 Mission quest to check it out.

Mission accomplished this weekend, and I was very, very pleased. For starters, the service was awesome. Totally friendly, and rather than giving me some weird look when I asked for no oil, the host said no problem and went back to relay the info to the cook. I was also really impressed that the version I wanted, sweet & sour sauce with veggies and pineapple, was listed on the menu as coming with mock duck, and they had no problem swapping in the mock chicken. It was customization with a smile.

The verdict? Assuming this was indeed mock chicken and there was no oil, it was unbelievably flavorful. I loved it, and will definitely return to try their other mock creations. I can see why the Chronicle had such effusive praise, and Angkor Borei can consider me their newest fan.
author: Jason B.

description: Angkor Borei is a hidden gem in Bernal Heights.  While living in the neighborhood I frequented it regularly and still make pilgrimages for the fantastic food.  It's a place where both meativores and vegetarians will have a plethora of yummy choices.  The staff is friendly, it's very reasonably priced with a pleasant decor.  I personally love their mock meat choices.   I've tried many items on their menu and my favorites is the mock duck clay pot - which features fresh spring veggies, mock duck and tender rice noodles in a complex and richly flavored sauce. I'd also recommend the fresh spinach leaves appetizer - it's fun especially with a group.  Over the years I've brought many people here and people always enjoy it.
author: Valerie S.

description: My second experience was quite good; I think they deserve an update for delivery speed. I ordered the fish in garlic sauce and the peanut beef. I also got the vegetarian spinach appetizer... it was unexpectedly raw spinach served with peanuts, bamboo, green bell pepper, some kind of crispy flakes, with a sweet and sour sauce. I wasn't too psyched about it. It was different though. The fish was excellent. The delivery came in 20 minutes, amazing.
author: Michael S.

description:
I have traveled quite a bit and I've noticed that when people go to Cambodia it's generally after having spent some time in Thailand. I mention this because you can't help noticing that you can get delicious food everywhere in Thailand, even from street carts, but once you get to Cambodia the food choices are dreary. Can I tell you about the time I got rice left over from another table and soup made from the bones of someone else's chicken? How about the time I ordered a chicken and saw them catch, kill, and cook a giant rooster that ended up being inedible tough. Or the numerous times I've eaten grey chunks of buffalo. Cambodia is a poor country and when you travel there you learn pretty quick to look for the expensive by Cambodian standards Chinese restaurants or the cafe's catering to western customers and even then you still get plenty of surprises, if you ever see a sign in Cambodia that says "happy pizza" on it go in and order a pizza with extra happy.

The reason I'm going into this whole tirade is because I can't tell you if Angkor Borei is authentic Cambodian food or not, it is not by my experience but I don't know what well off Cambodians have their cooks make for them or what the food was like before the country was ravaged by war and the Khmer Rouge. 

We ordered the crispy Cambodian crepe; I thought it was interesting but just ok. The spicy green curry with BBQ duck that was not spicy, barely had a bite, and the duck was tender but we only got the boney parts. We ordered the seafood special which was the most expensive item on the menu and I was alarmed at how small the portion was, not enough for three people to each get get a decent taste. Finally since the portions were smaller than expected we ordered the Cambodian noodles. These noodles come with a bunch of vegetables and a sauce that you mix together yourself. I didn't care for it but my dinner companions did.

Quite honestly I'd rather go to Pad Thai down the street and if it's Wednesday, Pad Thai's day off, I'd rather just go somewhere else.

Angkor Borei is a decent restaurant but not really good enough to put in regular rotation.
author: Manny F.

description: Very good Cambodian food.  Extremely reasonable prices.  It's all good - but my favorite is the Clay Pot Mock Duck (I am not even a vegetarian!)  Always tasty - and the service is very pleasant.
author: R F.

description:
***Lunch Review****
As I walked by, just having gotten my nails done, I saw the sign that said "baby coconut"....well, obviously, I marched right in.....LOVE COCONUT!
We were greeted by perhaps the nicest woman in existence, and lo and behold, they had a lunch special....$6.50!!! Finally, I'm eating somewhere on my "plan" for eating for less than $10!
The lunch special has 9 choices, you pick two, and get rice and soup....what a deal! Perfect for people like me who like to try everything. Between the two of us we had the spring rolls, BBQ chicken, spicy pork and some sort of chicken....I wish I had written down the names, because everything was DELISH!!!
The baby coconut drink was excellent.... I found myself slurping coconut juice, and then attacking that poor coconut like my life depended on it....you know, to get all the baby meat out....(I'm sound like a cannibal.....hey it's a fruit.....).
Needless to say, I left feeling happily fat, and wishing I had a bigger tummy so I could have tried dessert...but I'll be back....it was SOOOO GOOD! ....and cheap!
author: Bianca L.

description:
We left San Francisco twelve years ago, and I've pretty much never regretted it - except every once in a while, like this past Thanksgiving weekend - I realize how much I miss it.  We lived in Bernal Heights, a neighborhood that everyone kept telling us was going to be "the next Potrero Hill!" for about ten years, and it finally happened just as we were pulling up stakes to roll about 400 miles southward.  Another thing that happened just as we were leaving?  We discovered that right down the hill, on Courtland and Mission, was a Cambodian restaurant called Angkor Borei.  Cambodian - sort of like Thai, right?  Well, yeah, sort of, but really something quite different, too; at least the way they do it at Angkor Borei - lighter, subtler, with slightly different spicing.  It's a modest place, but when you go inside, they've got Cambodian art and portraits of Cambodian royalty and Buddhist statuary and assorted kitsch to round out the decor.  

Try the dried shrimp appetizers, (spinach leaves with aforementioned shrimp, garlic, chiles and lime), the Cambodian crepes with shrimp, pork, chicken, mint, cabbage and other goodies that I've forgotten.  Best of all, it's all so exotic and new, and the service is so nice and attentive, that you think you're spending a lot of money...until you get the bill and wish you'd ordered more, because you're getting out of there way cheaper than you thought.  Everything we've had there has been great, and there are lots of other good things that I haven't tried because we just don't get back to the City often enough, but Christmas is coming, and what says "Ho Ho Ho" better than Southeast Asian delicacies in the Mission District?
author: Ken N.

description: The service is always attentive and the food comes out almost disconcertingly quickly. The food is so delicious I don't even care if they're microwaving it back there! Extensive vegetarian menu -- get the crispy crepe appetizer. The broccoli with tofu sounds boring, but it comes slathered in a rich peanut curry sauce that I want to be buried in. Yum! They even deliver. I'm not sure why people are calling it a "hole in the wall." It's a nice place with tacky decor but a nice ambience. Definitely worthy of a date, if you're not the type to be scared of the outer Mission.
author: Wendy C.

description: It's my first time to try a Cambodian food and it turn out pretty good. The food is so good , and the Spinach Leaf is the "must" try, I love it. The decor of the restaurant is nice and cozy, staff is very friendly and attentive. Definitely I will be back soon.
author: christy l.

description:
if this is an accurate representation of cambodian, then i might be a little biased since to me, the food here is a less refined version, more primitive form of thai and vietnamese dishes.  for example, the crispy crepe, with its thin shell and ground meat inside, is a less sophisticated version of banh xeo in terms of taste.  tried the amok, which was presented classically but missing coconut milk?, and described as a mousse, but tasted more like an omelet in texture.
the shrimp pumpkin curry and beef curry were both decent, with a lot of pumpkin and mild spice as well as soft beef, less coconut milk.  the complexity of curry flavor a bit lacking compared to thai.  (in any case there must be some overlap)  an explanation of the spinach leaves of how much to add of each ingredient might have helped.  toasted coconut was nice.  finally, also had the crispy sliced catfish with basil, which was decent, like a thai dish.  not sure if we ordered the right things...did i miss kroeung?
author: Rob C.

description: Always delicious. I generally order for delivery and I've never been disappointed. It takes about 30 to 40 minutes, but it's worth the wait. This family run business is a neighborhood gem.
author: Bada B.

description: Just off Cortland Ave. lies Angor-Borei, a restaurant featuring Cambodian cuisine.  Other than one dish, their lunch special doesn't cater to veggies.  But they do offer a variety of mock meat dishes a la carte.  I tried their mock duck which turned out to be quite tasty.  (Though, I can't say how much it resembled the actual thing as I've never eaten real duck.)  I was satisfied off the crispy crepe appetizer alone.  Service was great.  It was a nice switch to all the Thai restaurants I've been eating at lately.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
When I first came here, years ago, the food was more flavorful and tasty.  This last time I was quite disappointed at the incorporation ( it wasn't subtle in taste) of celery into a beloved dish: samlaw machou.  It was the first time I had ever had the soup--here and in Cambodia--where celery was used.  Additionally, our chicken with ginger dish was more on the dry side--they decided to use white meat, and I've only had it with dark meat, so the meat seemed to be over cooked and not well integrated with the other spices and ginger strips. Perhaps the appeal is to a different clientele--not for those craving and wanting to taste a traditional home cook Khmer meal, away from home.  Please bring back a stronger presence of kroeung and flavorful dishes.  Cambodian is noticeably distinct and different from its neighbors: Thai and Vietnamese, for example.  It seems that the dishes are moving away from its base.  
On a positive note, the two desserts, ice cream and mango were superb--keep the ripeness of fruits and high quality ice cream coming.
author: Frieda K.

description: First time I had Cambodian food, so I can't judge for authenticity. (To me it was kind of like Thai food, but with slightly different spices.) They were really patient with our party of 5 (all 20-/30-somethings, loud and slow to decide...hey, we were tired), and they provided amazing service. (We always had bottles of Singha on our table and our water glasses were always full). Their mock chicken dish was super good, and the pan fried fish fillet (#51) was incredible, probably the best fish I've had in a southeast asian restaurant in SF. Very reasonable prices, which was a change from the trendier places along Valencia in the inner Mission. I'll go back when I can eat more slowly.
author: Josephine J.

description: Why fuck around with superlatives? I have but four words for you: CLAY POT MOCK DUCK. Take your vegan friend for a short walk to Maggie Mudd afterwards, and you're bound to get major props. Edit: RIP Maggie Mudd.
author: Erin M.

description: When I was little, my mom tried to entice me to eat my spinach by telling me it would help me grow strong like Popeye and put color in my cheeks.  This didn't go over so well because I really didn't want mutant sized forearms, nor did I want green cheeks.  What would have worked better is if she took a cue from Angkor Borei and made little choose-your-own-adventure fingerfood packets from fresh spinach leaves.  Who knew raw spinach could taste so good AND be so fun?!?  I would come back here just for this lovely little appetizer.  Then I would stay for the shrimp clay pot (gorgeously ginormous shrimp that 'snap' when you bite into them) and the Ahmohk (more like a fish pate than a fish mousse, but delicious just the same), and round out my meal with some fried bananas with coconut ice cream.  Mmm mmm good!
author: Cindy W.

description: Cambodian is a mix between Burmese and Thai. We had the cold noodles, the spinach leaves and the pumpkin curry. The spinach leave was my favorite. There are like 13 different ingredients that you put in a spinach leaf. It was fresh and tasty. The cold noodles were good but didn't have a strong flavor. The pumpkin curry was very good...You actually get a whole pumpkin with it. It was creamy delicious and filling.
author: Ginny M.

description: Pretty decent Cambodian restaurant in the Mission.  The quality of the meat is just average but they use a lot of tasty veggies and spices.  I would give it 4 stars if they bump up the quality of their meats.  Lots of choices for vegetarians or vegans.  The soup was ok, I also had a spicy curry which was tasty with some brown rice.  It, although, made me run home for the bathroom ;)
author: Mitch A.

description: This is absolutely one of my favorite hole-in-the-wall restaurants.  Both the spinach leaf appetizer and the green papaya salad are two of my favorites. The Cambodian menu here is similar to Thai food, but slightly more interesting, in my opinion. At Ankhor Borei you will find an extensive menu with grilled seafood dishes, curries, and a huge selection of vegetarian dishes. The Vegetarian Clay Pot Duck is vegetarian "duck" in a rich curry sauce that will win over even the most strict carnivores. Very reasonably priced.
author: N B.

description: Perhaps it was an off day. Based on the reviews on this site, I recommended this restaurant to a friend for lunch today. The lunch special menu seemed a great bargain (two choices plus soup and rice for $7.95). The soup had a nice flavor, but my entrees were both sub-par. The shrimp and cabbage consisted of two medium shrimp on a bed of soggy cabbage and the pork with vegetables was overcooked meat and undercooked green beans. To top it off, a cockroach crawled onto our table mid meal. I won't go back but if you do, hopefully you'll have a better experience.
author: julie t.

description: I never had Cambodian food until today and I have to say that it was very good! When you enter this place the place is very ambiant and the staff greet you with a hello and a smile (which is always great!) I came to celebrate one of my bestest friends' bday and the staff are accomodating in regards to seating large parties. The food caters to both meat eaters and vegetarians which is great! The dishes I had were rich and saucy and had lots of good flavors. I would definitely come back--loved it!
author: Mel P.

description: The meal began promisingly with the Fresh Spinach Leaves appetizer: a finger food consisting of dried shrimp, ginger, lime, fried coconut, peanuts, and tangy chili sauce wrapped in fresh spinach leaves. Not much "cooking" or prep involved here, but props for the novelty of spinach tacos and the mixture of disparate toppings. We had the spicy hot and sour soup next. The broth was zesty, but the ingredients should have been cut into smaller bite size pieces. The entrees were lacking in complexity. A yellow curry: too sweet and watery. Ahmohk, a fish mousse wrapped in banana leaves: too salty. A stir fried vegetable plate with overly bitter mini corn. Reasonably, priced, I would wager this is a decent lunch place, but I wouldn't go back for dinner.
author: dave y.

description: excellent local option, well executed dishes, competent, well run restaurant.
author: Neil A.

description: I drive past this place all the time and live nearby and just went in for lunch for the first time. The first thing I noticed was it was freezing cold inside, it was warmer outside and we were the only prople in there, we almost got up and left and then this smiling waiter came out to greet us and gave us menus. I am so glad we stayed, it was so good and very inexpensive. We ended up meeting a woman who was either the owner or manager and she could not have been nicer. Our lunch was fantastic and we cannot wait to go back.
author: James S.

description: This place is soooo good! The pumpkin curry is AMAZING...end of story
author: Liz C.

description: Aside from my other favorite Cambodian joint in Oakland, this is also my favorite. I love their claypot and their curry. This place is fairly packed and the setting is so Cambodian-Like. Love it
author: Rose G.

description:
an incredibly FUN place to eat.  the service is so good that you keep forgetting there are no white tablecloths.  cambodian crepes and spinach-anarchy appetizer (where you roll dried shrimp, peanuts, sauce, onions, lime juice, etc. in baby spinach leaves) are moan-worthy.  

my favorite entree is the clay pot mock duck because i'm one of those people that craves interesting vegetable-in-sauce dishes. the mock duck is, of course, centuries more advanced and delicious than real duck.
author: Kris P.

description: Good selection of vegetarian dishes with good service.  Traditionally dressed wait-staff plus some Cambodian art dispersed here and there to complement the tasty food.  From the vegetarian menu, I had the Clay Pot Mock Duck that's simmered with bean thread noodles, spinach, zucchini, carrot, mushrooms, tomatoes, bell peppers and spices.
author: ITesh J.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  My family and I have been going there since 1987, and the food is consistently excellent.  It's a must visit for out of town guests, who universally love it.

The food is similar to Thai food (but less agressively spicy) and Vietnamese food (but with more depth of flavor) with an emphasis on lemongrass, thai basil, mint, fish sauce, peanuts, and chilis.

If you go with a group, definitely try the spinach salad, which is delicious and fun to eat.  Other must try appetizers: beef kabobs, chicken salad, cambodian crepe, spicy tofu.   The spicy hot and sour soup is amazing, the green curry is deceptively mild at first, but packs a powerful cumulative heat punch, and the ahmohk (fish mousse) is a little taste of heaven in a banana leaf.

The service is warm and welcoming, and the price is right.  Try it, you will love it!
author: Dorothy S.

description: Just got back from a trip to Vietnam and Cambodia and totally loved the food, so fresh, so tastey, so cheap.  Went to Angkor Borei expecting to have something that was at least recognizably Cambodian but that didn't happen.  Split three different dishes with my boyfriend and most were overburdened with flavorless sauce, brown rice was luke warm, and spring rolls could've easily been served at a very cheap Chinese restaurant.  The only reason I gave it two stars is because the people were so nice, which definitely reminded me of Cambodia.
author: Kevin M.

description: This place is great! I've been here twice now and I just can't get enough of it. Try the clay pot shrimp; just delicious. The hint of coconut gives it a great flavor. I also really enjoyed the boneless chicken curry the last time I visited. You really can't go wrong though; all of the dishes I have tried have not disappointed. This restaurant has a great friendly atmosphere. Not too loud or overwhelming, and the staff is extremely friendly and attentive.
author: Britt H.

description: My first Cambodian restaurant. It was awesome friendly service from the owner.  It's been a while since I ate here. I recall ordering a crepe with veggies, meat, and shrimp with an awesome lime based sauce.  The noodles and curry were also very delightful. I'd go back for the overall experience with the nice setting, great service, and great meal.
author: Hebert J.

description: Eh, it was just okay.  I had the lunch special with chicken curry.  The fried banana dessert was great.
author: Lauren S.

description: My mom  used to take me here and we used to have quiet little dinners filled with great tea and skewers. MMM peanut sauce. I order from here from time to time and it is just how I remember it. It's cute inside and a nice  escape from Mission  St. The  squid salad makes me happy.
author: haley d.

description:
don't know what authentic cambodian is, but i doubt it's like thai or japanese.   the waitress recommended a BBQ chicken dish and it tasted exactly like teriyaki chicken that you get at thousands of americanized japanese restaurants.    The other dishes were very similar to thai, although blander and less spicy.    

The decor is nice and the service is friendly and efficient.
author: Mikey T.

description:
the mock chicken claypot is truly delightful and totally worth a visit. it was bathed in a yellow curry-type sauce which was thankfully not super sweet - the flavors were balanced with sweet, sour, savory elements in perfect proportion, unlike many thai/cambodian curries served in the states. also, the sticky rice used in the sticky rice/mango dish is black rice, which i love! this place is a new neighborhood fave for me. the staff is also really sweet and helpful with efficient service.

i knocked a star off because the crepe appetizer was not amazing, but i will totally be back for that mock chicken deliciousness!
author: Leona K.

description: Thai out - Cambodian food, in. This place is a little hole in the wall down in the Mission by Cortland, and the food ain't bad. You've got to try #7 in the appetizers - it's spinach leaves with little delicious wrapped yummies. It's the first time I've seen this dish anywhere!
author: Peter S.

description: Had the spinach leaves to start, followed by the ginger chicken.  The spinach leaves were excellent and the chicken also very good.  Service was good, and reasonably fast.  Love it!   I'll be going back!!
author: Fiid W.

description:
We went there last week after reading the reviews on Yelp. I have to say that the owners are really humble, very attentive and constantly smiling (and thanking us). 

The food is very good, but I have to say that I was slightly disappointed with the mock duck dishes (someone here mentioned it was not that great and I should have paid heed to that). However, the curry flavors were simply excellent. The vegetarian spring rolls were the best I've had in a really long time. 

I highly recommend this place!
author: Rahul A.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. The food is always delicious. The wait staff are all kind and helpful. The couple who own the business are warm-hearted people who really care about their customers and want to provide a truly pleasant meal experience. They have been in business there for more than 20 years --- which in the competitive restaurant environment of SF means that they're good. For those who don't know what Cambodian food is, it's similar to Thai food. It's a very down-to-earth place, nicely decorated. If you call ahead, they can set up tables comfortably for a group of 10, 12, or so. It would be a little small for a really big group. It's on Mission Street, just north of Cortland Avenue, on the edge of Bernal Heights. Parking is a little tough (as it is almost everywhere), but we always find a spot. Buses #14, 49, and 24 stop very nearby. (Sadly, the doorway is too narrow for some wheelchairs.)
author: Susan K.

description:
very fresh
affordable
very friendly

I was pleasantly surprised on my last visit to this Bernal Heights gem. We ordered the pumpkin curry with veggie meat (huge and delicious), the veggie spicy green curry (good and spicy but not great), a pan-fried fish dish (delicious! highly recommended), vegetarian crepe (pretty good), sweet and sour chicken (OK), and green papaya salad (don't bother).
I had a great time, the veggie things were delicious. I came here a couple years ago and hadn't been back because it was less than wonderful. I'm glad to say that's changed. I was a little bummed about the papaya salad- it's so mild, not the spicy, limey concoction I'm used to. 

I'm glad to find a good ethnic place in the hood because there aren't many. I'll be going back soon!
author: nattles l.

description: Nice little restaurant with cambodn decorations. The food was crackin. I've eaten enough cambodian food to know what's good. If you're a big fan of coconut juice in your food the try this.
author: Cedric F.

description: The food here is so amazing. I love the variety of veg options on the menu, and everything is so fresh. We were in pumpkin curry heaven when we were there last. I highly recommend Angkor Borei--affordable and very tasty!
author: Kristin S.

description:
We started with the green papaya salad--which was great. I also tried the lemongrass iced tea, and it was light and refreshing. It had a hint of mint.

The pumpkin curry is amazing. Made with green beans, pumpkin, and asparagus, it is perfect. I had it with mock chicken. My husband had the chili chicken--the layering of flavors made this also a wonderful surprise.
author: Suzanne H.

description: I am officially a fan of cambodian food. I had dinner here with a large group of 10+. The service was great, atmosphere exoctic and food - OFF THE HOOK! Everything we ordered (and we shared family style) was great. My personal favorite was the seafood clay pot. mmmm. If it's this good a second time I will upgrade to five stars.
author: Kathryn T.

description: One of my favorite weekday lunch spots.Yum!
author: Jenni O.

description: Yum. We ate here one thursday evening and it was really good. i would maybe say 4 1/2 stars but i rounded up to 5. it was kind of an early dinner, so they seemed to have just opened but seated us right away, then moved us when b was too hot. i had lemongrass iced tea which b and j didnt like but i thought was so yummy.  the spring roll apps were great and as were all 3 of our meals. i had something chicken.... i forget now... wish i remembered... but we ate everything up! and mango sticky rice for dessert yum.  i'm not sure i'd had cambodian food before, but it reminded me of thai with a twist. anyway, i'd definitely come back here again.
author: Merredith L.

description: Came here with a friend who's Cambodian and his family. The decor of the restaurant is very nice and the woman serving us was Cambodian and speaking to my friend's family in Cambodian so I didn't understand what was going on. All the food they ordered were really good and I had no complaints. I would definitely go back again!
author: Lily K.

description: I didn't try everything, but the amok had such a small portion, and was expensive.  And why is it so friggin dark in there?
author: Bobby L.

description:
The food was incredible and flavorful.  I ordered the spicy green curry with tofu, vegetarian crispy rolls, and steamed rice for take-out.  It was ready when I arrived, and the people were the nicest!  One gentleman in particular greeted me with a huge smile on his face that made me feel very happy and at home.  The rolls had the perfect flavor and crispness, and the sauce to go with it was good.  I loved the complexity of flavors in the curry, and the spicyness and amount of liquid was perfect!!

The only drawback was... there was a HOLE in the bottom of the friggen plastic container holding the curry.  So it leaked half of my beautiful precious curry all over the inside of my bag.  T_T  It took me until I was halfway home (waiting for the 29) to pinpoint the source of the leak.  FAWWWWKKKKK!!!!  Oh well, at least the plastic bag didn't break, though the paper one inside it sopped up most of the curry anyway.  I still managed to enjoy it, albeit messily.
author: Yvea E.

description: we tried their lunch special. cheap but did not enjoy the meal. i have faith i would like cambodian food if i tried the right dishes. next time i'll avoid the lunch special and order some real dishes!
author: Helen L.

description:
i agree wholeheartedly with a previous reviewer who commented on how much the staff says, "thank you." it's amazing how attentive service makes food taste better, isn't it?

i live near here and was, until last night, unaware that this place existed. sorta like thai, sorta like chinese, sorta like vietnamese... cambodian food is a new favorite. 

the meals are affordable, and vegetarians and vegans, you'll love this place! they have an entire separate menu for you green-lovers, including "fancy" veggie options like fake duck meat. great spot for a casual, reliably good meal.
author: Marla W.

description: I absolutely love this place. The service has been exceptional the few times I have been here. The food is prepared very quickly and the portions are generous. How does it taste? Fan-****ing-tastic. Great vegetarian and vegan options.
author: aaron f.

description:
I attempted eating at this restaurant at LEAST 4 times..the first 3 times I got there and the place was closed.  i was starting to feel like it was never actually open, but the 4th time i got lucky.  

Since I'd never had cambodian food before I let my friend choose everything so I can't say what I had, but it was all very good and yummy and the service was lovely.  Think Thai food but...not.
author: jozilla w.

description: Coconut, curry, anchovies, pork, spinach leaves, papaya, raw slices of eggplant, altogether sounds like a jam session of flavorful sensations
author: Alex A.

description:
We just finished the most amazing lunch at Angkor Borei. There was a huge parking trauma and we were ready to give up and head home when all of a sudden there was a huge yellow zone right in front of the
restaurant and we were in the TRUCK! The truck eased on into the spot
and we were in the door and seated by a lovely smiling waitress. The place is colder than Siberia but I can't deduct any points for that because everything else was spot on. The spinach leaf appetizer was  a great starter. Not a morsel left when the plate was taken away. The crepe was crispy and delicious, filled with ground pork, bean sprouts and other wonderful tidbits. The noodle dish we ordered was not very interesting looking but it turned out to be a very tasty dish. It has rice noodles with egg, bean sprouts, green onions and tofu. Next to the noodles was a pile of shredded cabbage and chopped peanuts to add to your serving. A very clever and fresh tasting dish.
The finale was the fish ahmook. I'm drooling just trying to describe it.
It is a fish mousse with a mild curry sauce poured over it, inside a folded banana leaf. The entire thing is steamed and then served with another sauce made from lime, garlic, red chile and green chile. The smiling friendly waitress recommended that we try the claypot on our next visit. Maybe tomorrow?!
author: Cindy J.

description: The most cordial staff ever! Try the amok a lot of flavors with just little fish sauce that comes with it. They renovated the place and it looks Fabulous! I've had Cambodian food before and this is definitely  catered to the white taste buds. A lot of the strong aromatic ingredients like pahok is missing. But nonetheless its good. But I wouldn't call it a real Cambodian Restaurant, I mean if you want real go to Long Beach, CA.
author: Gwen D.

description:
food was great- throughly recommend the Ahmohk- Fish Mousse-  watch out for the sauce(!) everything was very flavorful and beautifully presented.

service was excellent- we were given a brief introduction on how to mix and serve-I guess we looked a little lost when the plates came out.

would definelty go back if i was in the area.
author: Sushi Y.

description: So glad this is in the neighborhood. Pumpkin curry with shrimp was delicious with ample amount of shrimp and perfectly cooked green beans. Serving size was healthy too - I got two substantial meals out of it.
author: Cath S.

description: I love this place, I believe it is the only Cambodian restaurant left in the city.  Anyway, the staff waitresses are super duper nice.  They are like super friendly women, which always make experiences better.  But regardless, their food deserves a full 5 stars too, we had ordered their pumpkin special dish, which came out in a pumpkin and that was awesome even though I don't care too much for pumpkin.  We had ordered a few different soups before, I do not remember them that well, but every we ordered was always really good.  One was a more sour soup which was delicious with rice dumped in there.  We ordered a fish before and it came out fresh smooth soft and full of flavor.
author: John L.

description: Great Cambodian food.  You feel like you are eating in a temple. The papaya salad is very good. The Ahmok is a must - this is a light curry fish mouse baked in a banana leaf.
author: Jerry W.

description: This place was tasty!  My boyfriend just got back from a 2-month trip to cambodia and he was excited to measure up the fare at angkor borei.  We had sour soup, beef with bell peppers and green beans, and the traditional cold noodles with fish sauce.  all of it was pretty yummy and i've never had cambodian food in my life.  The soup was particularly awesome, and really sour at that.  Overall the service was very nice, the food was good and the atmosphere was cozy.  it was a little chilly to be honest, but i had a sweater on.  only 1 star off because the prices were a little high.  Lunch for the two of us ran $30, and for two college kids thats pretty steep, especially knowing the stuff costs .50 in cambodia.  next time i'd go back and just have the $6 sour soup.  that stuff was goood.
author: E S.

description:
Good food, nice service, friendly and price fair.  I do not know if the food is truly Cambodian or catered to people's Asian taste, but I really like everything I had.
They are super friendly to kids and it was easier to go out with small children for lunch.
author: Miinno N.

description:
Yes.

Good food, good service, and never a problem getting it vegan.

Been going here for years and years and years and will continue to do so.
author: Currently A.

description: This place serves up outstanding food at very reasonable prices and stays open late!  10:30 Friday and Saturday nights!  The cashew chicken is some of the best food I've eaten, delicious, delicious delicious!  They also have many options for vegetarians with tofu or seitan.  A 1/2 carafe of a pretty decent house red for about 7 bucks filled four glasses.  Crispy spring rolls are also great, available in pork or tofu.  Do yourself a favor and go get some dinner there.
author: Melissa R.

description: Lots of great dishes here at a good price.  Nice atmosphere without pretension.  The food is not smothered in sauce like cheap Chinese often is.
author: Matthew K.

description:
I've eaten here a couple of times now, and can't believe I didn't hear about this place before.  The food is delicious, fresh, and elegantly spiced.

I particularly recommend the Nhoam Lahong, which is a delightful variation of the Thai salad "Som Tum" with basil and a more subtle, complex, and less overwhelming flavor.
