The Fish Mousse is scrumptious.  It's a kind of creamy, baked mush with chunks of moist fish and peppers, not just pureed fish.

They have brown rice, and their curry and saute dishes are carefully prepared and fresh.  The chicken is moist, not overcooked as at many cheap asian restaurants.  The sauces are light but very flavorful.

Thumbs up for Borei Angkor!
author: Aaron C.

description: Yes the spinach leaf appetizer is good.  I like this place.  Overall I'd say the seafood is better than the chicken.  Great flavors....definitely worth trying.
author: chadmalik ..

description:
This was my first experience with Cambodian food.  It was awesome.  I had a sweet and sour prawn dish.  Really tasty.  The sauce in this dish really made it memorable.  Though my favorite part was the lemon grass tea.

A really homey feel.  Nice little place.  Highly recommended.
author: Daniel K.

description:
The owners were super friendly and the service was great, but the food was ok- not bad, not great.  For $25 a person I could've had a more substantial and better-tasting meal elsewhere, without going out of my way to drive to this end of Mission.  We may have ordered wrong items, but what we had didn't really excite my taste buds.  I'd be willing to go back to try different dishes, but I wouldn't make it a point to do so unless one of my friends wants to try Cambodian food.

My friend and I ordered the following:
spinach leaf wrap appetizer - a platter of sweet/spicy sauce and chopped up onions, jalepenos, ginger, peanuts, lime, and dried shrimp meant to be wrapped up in a spinach leaf.  The ingredients were fresh and the flavor different, but nothing special.  The decor is tastefully decorated and the setting is casual.

ahmok (fish mousse) - this was very nicely done. I was half expecting this to be fishy, but it wasn't fishy at all and the consistency was perfect - not chewy, not too mushy.  Subtle hints of spice but IMO not enough spice or sauce.

#38 (can't remember the name) - the server recommended this - ground pork in a curry like coconut milk sauce.  A little too coconutty and sweet and not enough spice for my tastes.  

mango and sticky rice - pretty standard fare.  nothing special here.
author: Irene W.

description: Got takeout for the first time from this place last night.  They delivered to me on Potrero Hill on a Saturday night within 30 minutes, first of all.  Second of all, I thought the food was excellent -- a great moist flavorful chili chicken -- not that deep-fried mess you get at Chinese places -- but all light and delicious.  Good Viet-style BBQ pork -- GREAT fried spring roll -- and an out-of this world squid salad.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
had the amok my only time here, just before going to cambodia.  after my trip, i'd still get it again in a second, holds up to the local food i had.  i'd bump it this to a five star once i make it back and have something else that matches the amok.

inexpensive by sf standards, and tasty, so don't be picky folks! go to slanted door or something if you want  fancy pants se asian food.
author: marc c.

description:
I've eaten here probably a dozen times. The soups and salads are all really good. The Papaya Salad is the best I've had anywhere. 

Great choices for vegetarians. 

Very sincere service. They make you feel right at home. A treasure in the mission.
author: John W.

description: I must say, I was a bit disappointed with you Yelpers, as I did not enjoy the food here very much.  There is one huge reason: the texture of the fake meat.  It was disgusting, and I am a very enthusiastic fan of meats of the faux variety.  The other things -- the noodles, salad, etc. were pretty well flavored.  The soup had a little too much of something -- tasted like cilantro.  The service was great and the atmosphere was pleasant, but I will not eat here again.  So, if you are a discriminating lover of fake meat, try Golden Era, Sparky's Diner, and the like.
author: Rhea S.

description: Great food. This is my default delivery food place when I'm too lazy to cook or I haven't been to the grocery store in a while. All the dishes I've tried are delicious. Favorites include: cashew chicken, curry shrip and pineapple and Cambodian crepe. Must get: spinach leaf wrap for appetizer and mango black sticky rice dessert
author: Maggie K.

description: This little Cambodian restaurant has excellent  vegetarian dishes with just the right amount of spice (flavor and hotness).  I ordered the green curry with mock chicken and the Cambodian-style crepes.  The green curry dish reminded me of the mock-meat I ate while traveling through Cambodia.  I took home my leftovers to savor the next day.  Highly recommended.
author: erin h.

description: the service is super sweet, and the lunch specials are the bomb. heart-shaped rice. ok? and if you're vegetarian or vegan, you will be stoked. they have so many mock meat and tofu options, you can pretty much make any dish work for you. and it's all delicious, authentic, and totally different from other places. i'd never had cambodian food before but now this is one of our favorite neighborhood spots. also, my friend once got the pumpkin curry for dinner there and it was insanely beautiful and super delicious. everything is good, and i love the crowd.
author: Jessica C.

description: Although I love Thai and Vietnamese, this was my first experience with Cambodian food.  We loved this restaurant.  Four of us went for dinner last night and ate family style.  Everything we had was great.  I totally disagree with another reviewer that all the food "tastes the same."  Our dishes were all unique and all delicious.  We had the spinach leaf appetizer which I recommend everyone start with.  It is bursting with such an array of flavors.  Then we shared Panang Beef, Shrimp claypot, spicy chicken, and lemongrass tofu (new on the menu).  Service was great and our waitress was funny and charming.  And no one tried to kick us out as we sat there as the only remaining customers, having paid our bill an hour earlier, and all the staff well ready to leave.  And how excited am I to see that they deliver?!   Will be using that service frequently!
author: Kari G.

description: This is a small intimate place, nicely decorated and you can actually hold a conversation without yelling!  Food is yummy and tasty,  they have a  variety of items on the menu and lots of vegetarian options and they also have brown rice (a plus).  The lemongrass Ice tea was refreshing, especially b/c my dish was spicy!  The staff is very sweet and if your not familiar they are happy to recommend something!  I'm a fan of this place and will be back.  Overall  I had a Yummy experience!
author: Pattie s.

description: Love, love, LOVE this place. Why is it almost always empty when I go? It's so good! I like the crepe the best. Yum.
author: Esther L.

description:
cambodia.  what to say, really.

when i think of cambodia, i think of a former french rule (sorry, protection) and narcotics-related corruption.  this is pretty much the extent of my knowledge.  oh, and it's about the size of oklahoma...i remember that from julie mathieson's 8th grade report.  however, cambodia as a beacon of culinary marvels?  i mean, i couldn't say one way or the other.  

until last night, that is.  because last night, my friends, i ate at angkor-borei.  the fact that i am craving mock duck at 9 am the next morning should tell you that cambodian food is off the motherfucking chain (btw, i'm trying to use the word, "motherfucker" -- or any of its derivatives --  in every review from now until september 15th.  it's a personal best challenge.)  

i was a little freaked out when i sat down to the menu and the first few of pages were just meaty meat meat but then when you hit the last couple of pages, it's strictly vegetarian...even featuring mock meats!  so exciting!  we had the crispy crepe (delicious), peanut mock duck (delicious), um...some sort of bean curd (delicious.  michael, if you are reading this, what was that called?  and hello!), and um...one other thing.  oh yes,  a mock chicken salad  (delicious).  

all of this deliciousness has sparked a new curiosity in me to learn more about this fantastic little country.  i will share my knowledge with you because i am a knowledge seeker and a knowledge spreader, it's just how i do.  also, if you substitute the word "std" for "knowledge" in the above sentences, it is pretty funny. 

Most Cambodians consider themselves to be Khmers, descendants of the Angkor Empire that extended over much of Southeast Asia and reached its zenith between the 10th and 13th centuries. Attacks by the Thai and Cham (from present-day Vietnam) weakened the empire ushering in a long period of decline. The king placed the country under French protection in 1863. Cambodia became part of French Indochina in 1887. Following Japanese occupation in World War II, Cambodia gained full independence from France in 1953. In April 1975, after a five-year struggle, Communist Khmer Rouge forces captured Phnom Penh and evacuated all cities and towns. At least 1.5 million Cambodians died from execution, forced hardships, or starvation during the Khmer Rouge regime under POL POT. A December 1978 Vietnamese invasion drove the Khmer Rouge into the countryside, began a 10-year Vietnamese occupation, and touched off almost 13 years of civil war. The 1991 Paris Peace Accords mandated democratic elections and a ceasefire, which was not fully respected by the Khmer Rouge. UN-sponsored elections in 1993 helped restore some semblance of normalcy under a coalition government. Factional fighting in 1997 ended the first coalition government, but a second round of national elections in 1998 led to the formation of another coalition government and renewed political stability. The remaining elements of the Khmer Rouge surrendered in early 1999. Some of the remaining leaders are awaiting trial by a UN-sponsored tribunal for crimes against humanity. Elections in July 2003 were relatively peaceful, but it took one year of negotiations between contending political parties before a coalition government was formed.

class is dismissed, bitches!

**had a pretty bad day yesterday and it was still 5 stars delicious.  that's just an fyi**
author: Laura B.

description:
the worst place i must have visited in my life....
n people in the restaurant beg n demand for tip.
the food was horrible.... n so v paid little less tip n those people asked for more tip.... that was the worst thing i came across.
i wil never go there again n tell my friends not to go thr....
author: cute b.

description: I dig their food AND they deliver.  Our favorites are the fish amohk, crepe, sour soup and shrimp clay pot.  The sour soup is sour and loaded with vegies...not super tangy or overly sour, if that's what you're looking for.  The shrimp clay pot is mild but flavorful and loaded with vegies, shrimp and noodles.
author: Freedy H.

description: I love this place.  I've been going to Angkor for 8 years and have never been disappointed.  Everything has a "fresh" taste - not pre-cooked.  The spring rolls are terrific.  My favorite is the ahmonk (sp?).  Wine for $5/glass?  Wow!
author: Mark L.

description: oh mock peanut duck, how i wish i could eat  you ever single day. along with your friend, the cheap wine menu. you rock.
author: Lily S.

description: Tasty vegan options, including a great curry dish served in an entire, edible pumpkin!
author: D. B.

description: This place HANDS DOWN makes the best green curry in the city, and the family who owns the place is quite possibly the nicest family on the planet (unconfirmed).  Its a great neighborhood place that always has a seat for you and consistently delivers great service and curry.
author: Abby G.

description: my first trip here more food ended up on my shirt than in my mouth.  thank goodness for the tide pen.  the service is delightful and if you've never had cambodian food, all you have to do is ask and you will get a lesson on what to eat and how to eat it.  and apparently they deliver- which means you can eat the food in your birthday suit and not have to worry about unsightly stains or running out of ink in your tide pen.
author: Samantha W.

description: cashew mock chicken dreamboat.... was pretty hooked on this place for a while (vegan cambodian delivery!?)....kind vibes and good grubbin for sure..
author: aerin w.

description: Food was great and atmosphere pleasant.  Curry dishes were very good and a fair sized portion.  Spinach appetizer was interesting but we wished we had ordered the spring rolls instead.  Definitely worth trying if it's your first time.
author: Rafael D.

description: some of the best food ever! nice setting. really friendly owner.
author: Dave H.

description: Angkor Borei is a diamond in the rough not only because of its delicious and unique food, but because unlike most every other restaurant in this city, they deliver. When I'm too tired to trek out to the foothills of Bernal Heights, I call Angkor Borei and within an hour, I have an incomparable Cambodian meal waiting on my doorstep. I always start with one of their delicious appetizers, like the crispy rice chips with ground pork, super-fresh green papaya salad, delicious crispy crepe, or beef kabobs with a tangy peanut sauce. For mains, I love the beef curry in a thickened coconut milk with peanuts, the red curry shrimp with spinach, the fried fish fillets with garlic sauce, and the cashew chicken. You really can't go wrong with anything there, although I have found a few of the seafood dishes to be, as Calvin Trillin says, not highly seasoned. Add some Cambodian noodles on the side and some of the best white rice I've ever had (chewy, nutty, and delicious) and you're set. The service, both over the phone, at your front door, and at the restaurant, is attentive.
author: Jon L.

description: the broth of their noodle soup with the ground pork, shrimp, squid, bean sprouts and noodles that they serve at lunch kicks ass!  very clean tasting comfort food.
author: X X.

description: I love this place!! i have been coming here with my parents since i was a little kid, and the owner is always so excited and welcoming to see me when i come in. food is great, and the price is even better!!. I suggest coming in for lunch time. they have a great lunch special menu thats cheap and gives you plenty of food! if you want some good food, and friendly service this is the place to go!!
author: Carolyn G.

description: Fantastic place!!!  Great vegetarian options.  The clay pots are fantastic.  Warm hosts and waitresses.  Good place to have long drawn out dinner conversations with old friends.  Reasonable prices.  Can't recommend it highly enough.
author: Aimee D.

description: Did you know this is the only Cambodian restaurant in the city according to Yelp?  I've never had Cambodian food before but my friend had spent a week there last year.  Overall, we thought it was a good dining experience, especially for the price.  All of the staff were friendly and attentive considering how busy they were.  The fresh spinach rolls were cool because you make it yourself.  All of the ingredients--roasted coconut, ginger, lime, jalapeno, dried shrimp, red onion, peanuts and sauce--came in little bowls for you to add to the spinach and then roll yourself.  The combination of flavors was really good.  The sour beef and ginger chicken were good but didn't seem like they were the signature dishes.  Next time I'll have to try something else.  One reviewer said there was MSG but we didn't think there was much, if any.  It's worth checking out, especially if you live in the general area.
author: Jason G.

description: After first eating at this restaurant i was amazed how good Ankor Borei's food was. Now seven years later, the food is still as good as it was the first time when my cambodian girlfriend took me there. My girlfriend so happens to be the restaurant owners daughter, but my biased cannot be persuaded by my taste buds. My favorite is the sour soup(dont remember the name). Pour that over your rice and you have a unique blend of flavor that ive never experienced before. As i am fairly new to many other cultural foods I usually stick to the typical american-thai/ cambodian food, but they have things on the menu for all those adventurers out there also. People shouldn't expect to taste authentic cambodian/thai food if they order something as simple as curry chicken as most restaurants cater to the usual eating styles in order to keep a broad customer base. But anywho, I love coming to this place and am always pleased how pleasant the workers are about accomodating all needs.
author: Jay S.

description: Very few places merit a five star, but the sweet family that runs this places and puts their heart and soul into cooking the yummiest food ever deserves a 5 star.  I want to go there now.
author: Batia L.

description: Everything was yummy, but the rice had the texture of day-old rice, which was disappointing.  The staff and service was great and I loved and would recommend the spinach leaf appetizer and the fish mousse, but with the shrimp added.  With each item going into the spinach leaf  carrying a strong flavor, they melded together perfectly.
author: marie h.

description: Superb food at this little outer Mission hole-in-the-wall, run by the sweetest and warmest Cambodian family.  When my family comes from Los Angeles to visit, their first stop is Angkor Borei.  It's restaurants like this -- moderately priced, small, family-run places -- that makes San Francisco the food capital that it is.
author: John M.

description: Please make sure you order what you see online.  Also ask the waitress what's popular serve by this restaurant.  Order whatever she recommended.  Don't order something out of your mind.
author: zcx p.

description: this place is great.  We always get delivery and there has never been a problem.  The fish Amok is great and so is the green papaya salad.  The black rice and mango desert is also a winner, fresh and not too sweet.
author: Kerry L.

description: Very yummy and easy place to go on a Monday night.  Great service - everyone was very friendly!  We really enjoyed the spinach leaf appetizer!  Everyone enjoyed their meals.  Th Clay Pot Shrimp with lemongrass and basil was very good and the dipping sauce that came with it was fantastic and just spicy enough!  The Chili Tofu was excellent and was spicy!  So ask for mild if you don't want spicy!   Dessert was good.
author: Maria D.

description: We just got back from San Francisco and had  a late lunch at this restaurant. We started with the cold noodle salad with some kind of fish dressing, it was really good and different. Then we had the Ahmohk which I ordered based on other yelp suggestions, it was amazing, very flavorful and the texture is not bad as any mousse would be. We also had a ground pork dish in a curry-type liquid, it was good but not as good as the fish. The waiter recommeded we have some dessert, stiky rice with mango, but this was not your typical thai white rice, it was black rice which gives it a nutty flavor that is better than the thai version. this all went down with shinga, super good!
author: Ivette M.

description: A great neighborhood place with extremely nice and friendly owners. The Fresh Spinach Leaves appetizer here is actually better than at some more expensive Thai/Cambodian restaurants I've been to. Great for a low-key dinner where you just want to catch up with a friend over good food in a friendly atmosphere.
author: Ben L.

description: This used to be one of my favorite restaurants! Did it change owners?  I hadn't been in a couple of years - and I don't know if I went on a bad night - but I was embarrassed for gushing how delicious the food was only to receive some very undelicious food.  Maybe they have a new cook? The food didn't even look the same. The tofu with chili sauce, used to have the most yummy red chili-paste sauce, but I received tofu covered in a clear bland slighty spicy sauce.
author: Lynn R.
